revision.text:
{{MedalTableTop|sport= Men's [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]]|country_code=CAN|medals= {{Medal|Competition|[[Commonwealth Games]]}} {{Medal|Bronze|[[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1962 Perth]]|[[Athletics at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|Shot put]]}} {{Medal|Gold |[[1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1966 Kingston]]|[[Athletics at the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|Shot put]]}} {{Medal|Gold |[[1970 British Commonwealth Games|1970 Edinburgh]]|[[Athletics at the 1970 British Commonwealth Games|Shot put]]}} {{Medal|Competition|[[Pan American Games]]}} {{Medal|Bronze|[[1967 Pan American Games|1967 Winnipeg]]|[[Athletics at the 1967 Pan American Games|Shot put]]}} }} '''David Lorne "Dave" Steen,''' (born 2 January 1942)<ref name=Brink>[http://trackfield.brinkster.net/Profile.asp?ID=6340&Gender=M Dave Steen]. Track and Field Brinkster. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> is a [[Canadian]] former [[track and field]] athlete who specialised in the [[shot put]]. He was a two-time gold medallist in the event at the [[Commonwealth Games]] in 1966 and 1970, breaking [[List of Commonwealth Games records in athletics|games records]] both times. He had won the bronze medal at the 1962 event. His personal record was {{T&Fcalc|19.21}}, set in 1970.
He was a nine-time national champion in throwing events at the [[Canadian Track and Field Championships]]. Also among his honours were a shot put bronze at the [[1967 Pan American Games]] and two bronze medals in the shot and discus at the [[1969 Pacific Conference Games]]. He was coached by [[Bill Bowerman]] within the [[Oregon Ducks track and field]] program and was part of the winning team for the 1962 American collegiate NCAA title.
==Career==
===Early life=== A native of [[Burnaby, British Columbia]],<ref>Andrews, Ron (1963-06-26). [http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Jamestown%20NY%20Post%20Journal/Jamestown%20NY%20Post%20Journal%201963/Jamestown%20NY%20Post%20Journal%201963%20-%204948.pdf American Trackmen Smash Records In Canadian Meet]. ''Jamestown Post-Journal'', p.30. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> he became interested in [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] through the exploits of his older brother [[Don Steen]], who became the national [[decathlon]] champion in 1955.<ref name=OC>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19661020&id=_cgyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=P-0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1900,7664185&hl=en How the Fitness Council Helps Canadian Sport]. ''Ottawa Citizen Weekend Magazine'', no.43, p.64. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> - Oct 20, 1966 His brother later named his son [[Dave Steen (decathlete)|David Steen]], who continued the family's athletic tradition.<ref>[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/st/dave-steen-1.html Dave Steen] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407122148/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/st/dave-steen-1.html |date=2015-04-07 }}. Sports Reference. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref>
He had his first achievements in the shot put while at Douglas Road Elementary School in Burnaby, winning the school title at age eleven.<ref name=OC/> At [[Burnaby South Secondary School]] he established himself as one of Canada's best young throwers by setting national age-group record in the shot put.<ref name=HOF>[http://www.burnabysportshalloffame.ca/02athlete.htm Burnaby Sports Hall of Fame 2002]. Burnaby Sports Hall of Fame. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> Steen grew to be a tall man, at six-foot and four and a half inches, and as his physique developed he reached a weight of 235 pounds.<ref name=OC/> He went on to study at the [[University of Oregon]], where he became part of the [[Oregon Ducks track and field]] led by coach [[Bill Bowerman]]. A central team member in the throw events, Steen placed fifth at the [[NCAA Men's Division I Outdoor Track and Field Championships]] in 1962 and competed in the preliminaries of the [[discus throw]]. His contribution helped Oregon to the NCAA team title.<ref>Maloney, Jim (2012-09-03). [http://fishduck.com/2012/09/1962-the-year-the-tigers-roared/ 1962 Track & Field Champions: The Year Oregon’s “Tigers” Roared]. FishDuck. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> The following year he had his best placing in NCAA competition, coming second in the shot put final.<ref name=HOF/>
===International career=== Steen won his first national title as a teenager in 1960, winning the [[hammer throw]], which was not very developed at a national level at that point. His first national title in the shot put came at the [[Canadian Track and Field Championships]] in 1962. His winning mark of {{T&Fcalc|17.20}} was by far the best ever performance in the competition's history at that point.<ref name=NC>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/nc/can.htm Canadian Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> This earned him his first major international call-up for the [[Athletics at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]], held in [[Perth, Australia]]. There he had a throw of {{T&Fcalc|17.90}}, which would have won all previous titles but on this occasion was a close third behind [[Martyn Lucking]] and [[Mike Lindsay]].<ref name=CWG>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cg.htm Commonwealth Games]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref>
In the 1963 [[track and field]] season he achieved a [[Canadian records in athletics|Canadian record]] of {{T&Fcalc|18.88}},<ref name=Brink/> having previously become the first Canadian to clear the sixty foot mark. This mark ranked him seventh globally that year.<ref name=HOF/> He was among Canada's top prospects for the [[1964 Summer Olympics]], but in 1963 he criticised the attitude of officials at the [[Canadian Amateur Athletic Union]], saying that they were not sufficiently concerned with the well-being of the nation's athletes.<ref name=Varsity/> Suffering heavily from [[infectious mononucleosis]], he ultimately missed the entire 1964 season, including the Olympic competition. The launch of the [[Canada Fitness Council]], supported by the [[Royal Canadian Legion]], marked a turnaround in his fortunes. Steen credited the organisation with improving his career by assisting with living costs and subsidising travel to international competitions.<ref name=OC/>
Steen returned to form in 1965 with a second career title at the Canadian Championships and a season's best of {{T&Fcalc|18.52}}. He also won his first national title in the discus throw, doing so with {{T&Fcalc|51.62}}. The following year he set a new shot put personal best of {{T&Fcalc|19.12}} to win the Canadian title in a championship record. This mark ranked him eleventh in the world that season and went unbettered nationally until [[Bruce Pirnie]]'s 1972 win.<ref name=Brink/><ref name=NC/> The [[Athletics at the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] in [[Kingston, Jamaica]] saw Steen became Canada's first ever shot put gold medallist at the competition. His winning throw of {{T&Fcalc|18.79}} was a large improvement on the [[List of Commonwealth Games records in athletics|Commonwealth Games record]] set by Lucking four years earlier.<ref name=CWG/> In addition to the shot put, he competed in the discus event and placed fourth.<ref>[http://www.thecgf.com/games/results.asp?gameid=3036&sportid=1469-publisher= 1966 Results for Athletics - Discus Throw - Men]. [[Commonwealth Games Federation]]. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref>
He took a shot put and discus double at the 1967 national championships and his best throw that year was {{T&Fcalc|18.55}}.<ref name=Brink/><ref name=NC/> He came close to that seasonal peak at the [[Athletics at the 1967 Pan American Games|1967 Pan American Games]], which were held on home turf in [[Winnipeg]], Manitoba, Canada. He was the bronze medallist behind two Americans who were world leaders at that point: [[Randy Matson]], who was Olympic champion the year after, and [[Neal Steinhauer]], the top ranked putter in 1969. Steen's 1967 medal was Canada's first in the Pan American men's shot put (his compatriot [[Nancy McCredie]] won the women shot that year).<ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/pag.htm Pan American Games]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref>
Steen was Canadian champion in the shot put in both 1968 and 1969, solidifying an unbeaten run from 1965. The latter title was his last at national level.<ref name=NC/> He was selected for the Canadian team for the inaugural [[1969 Pacific Conference Games]] and a performance of {{T&Fcalc|18.54}} in the shot put and {{T&Fcalc|54.94}} in the discus brought him two bronze medals. His teammate [[George Puce]] was the discus winner at the event in [[Tokyo]].<ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/pcg.htm Pacific Conference Games]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref>
He returned to defend his shot put title at the [[Athletics at the 1970 British Commonwealth Games|1970 British Commonwealth Games]]. The 28-year-old successfully topped the podium again, winning the gold medal with a new games record (and lifetime best) of {{T&Fcalc|19.21}}. He was the first man to defend that title since [[Harry Hart (athlete)|Harry Hart]] did so in 1934.<ref name=CWG/> He again competed in the discus throw as well, and ranked tenth with a mark of {{T&Fcalc|50.64}}.<ref>[http://www.thecgf.com/search/athlete.asp?athleteid=38445 Dave Steen]. Commonwealth Games Federation. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> This was the last major competition of his career. He was inducted into the [[Canadian Olympic Hall of Fame]] in 1977.<ref>[http://olympic.ca/canadian-olympic-hall-of-fame/ Canadian Olympic Hall of Fame Members]. Olympic Canada. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref>
===Writing and coaching=== After his retirement from competition he began coaching young athletes in the 1970s. This included novelist [[Lawrence Hill]]—a keen teenage runner—whom Steen advised to focus on writing after a poor outcome of a fitness test.<ref name=Hill>Hill, Lawrence (2014). ''[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=AJ2cAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72&dq=David+Steen+shot+put&source=bl&ots=rgRog0Wy0V&sig=OpZOiyseQxcYZOvOirP4AvBX6qs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=C3seVc2dAoirPNXsgYAH&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=David%20Steen%20shot%20put&f=false Blood: A Biography of the Stuff of Life]'', p. 72. Oneworld Publications. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> Steen himself wrote several books, starting with the ''Canadian Pilot's Fitness Manual'' in 1979 before moving into [[youth sport]] with ''Aerobic fun for kids'' in 1982 and ''Exercise is fun'' a decade later.<ref name=WorldCat>[http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-no2008045341/ Steen, David 1942- ]. World Cat. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref> He became a print [[sports journalist]], reporting for the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' and ''Toronto Mirror''.<ref name=OC/><ref name=Hill/> He married Margaret Daly, also a journalist, in [[Chicago]] in late 1963.<ref name=Varsity>Kollins, Rick (1963-10-11). [https://archive.org/stream/thevarsity83#page/100/mode/2up/search/steen Fistaminations for a Quiet Wednesday]. ''The Varsity Toronto'', vol. 83, no. 8. Retrieved on 2015-04-03.</ref>
==International competitions== {| {{AchievementTable|Event=yes}} |- |1962 |[[Athletics at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] |[[Perth, Australia]] |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd |[[Athletics at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games – Men's shot put|Shot put]] |17.90 m |- |rowspan=2|1966 |rowspan=2|[[Athletics at the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] |rowspan=2|[[Kingston, Jamaica]] |bgcolor=gold|1st |Shot put |18.79 m {{AthAbbr|GR|Commonwealth Games}} |- |4th |Discus throw |54.24 m |- |1967 |[[Athletics at the 1967 Pan American Games|Pan American Games]] |[[Winnipeg]], Manitoba, Canada |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd |Shot put |18.51 m |- |rowspan=2|1969 |rowspan=2|[[1969 Pacific Conference Games|Pacific Conference Games]] |rowspan=2|[[Tokyo, Japan]] |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd |Shot put |18.54 m |- |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd |Discus throw |54.94 m |- |rowspan=2|1970 |rowspan=2|[[Athletics at the 1970 British Commonwealth Games|British Commonwealth Games]] |rowspan=2|[[Edinburgh, Scotland]] |bgcolor=gold|1st |Shot put |19.21 m {{AthAbbr|GR|Commonwealth Games}} |- |10th |Discus throw |50.64 m |}
==National titles== *[[Canadian Track and Field Championships]] **Shot put: 1962, 1965, 1966, 1967, 1968, 1969 **Discus throw: 1965, 1967 **Hammer throw: 1960
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Footer Commonwealth Champions Shot Put Men}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Steen, Dave}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Burnaby]] [[Category:Canadian male shot putters]] [[Category:Canadian male discus throwers]] [[Category:Oregon Ducks men's track and field athletes]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games competitors for Canada]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games medallists in athletics]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games gold medallists for Canada]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1970 British Commonwealth Games]] [[Category:Pan American Games medalists in athletics (track and field)]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1967 Pan American Games]] [[Category:Canadian newspaper journalists]] [[Category:Canadian male journalists]] [[Category:Canadian sports journalists]] [[Category:Toronto Star people]] [[Category:Canadian exercise and fitness writers]] [[Category:Pan American Games bronze medalists for Canada]]

{{cleanup reorganize|date=December 2015}}<!--mishmash of paragraphs--> {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} The '''Duplessis Orphans''' ({{lang-fr|link=no|les Orphelins de Duplessis}}) were children victimized in a mid-20th century scheme in which approximately 20,000 [[orphan]]ed children<ref>{{cite news| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111022154328/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20040619/duplessis_orphans_040618/ | url= http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20040619/duplessis_orphans_040618/| author= CTV.ca News Staff | title= Duplessis orphans want Mtl. burial site dug up| date= June 19, 2004 | publisher= CTV News |archivedate= October 22, 2011}}</ref> were falsely certified as [[mentally ill]] by the government of the province of [[Quebec]], Canada, and confined to [[Psychiatric hospital|psychiatric institutions]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/society/youth/the-duplessis-orphans/a-dark-history-revealed.html The Duplessis Orphans] at CBC Archives</ref> The Catholic Church has denied the allegations, and disputes the claims of those seeking financial recompense.<ref>http://www.cbc.ca/archives/entry/duplessis-orphans-the-church-refutes-charges</ref>
==Overview== The 1940s and 1950s were considered a period of widespread poverty, few social services, and Catholic predominance in Quebec. The [[Quiet Revolution]] of the 1960s had not yet occurred, so the [[Roman Catholic Church]] still held major social power.<ref name=Farnsworth>{{cite news|last1=Farnsworth|first1=Clyde H.|title=Orphans of 1950s, Telling of Abuse, Sue Quebec|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/05/21/world/orphans-of-the-1950-s-telling-of-abuse-sue-quebec.html?pagewanted=2&pagewanted=all|accessdate=February 3, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=May 21, 1993|ref=power}}</ref>
[[Maurice Duplessis]], the [[premier of Quebec]], was a strict Catholic. The Church in Canada, as elsewhere in the world, was inclined to be a caretaker of the poor, alcoholics, unwed mothers, and orphans.<ref name="Ref 3">{{cite book|last1=Pauin|first1=Marguerite|title=Maurice Duplessis: Powerbroker, Politician|date=2005|publisher=XYZ Publishing|location=Montreal: QC|isbn=1-894852-17-6|page=46|ref=orphans}}</ref> He put the schools, orphanages, and hospitals in the hands of religious orders, noting he "trusted them completely". He signed an [[order-in-council]], changing orphanages into hospitals in order to provide them with federal [[subsidies]].<ref name="Ref 4">{{cite book|last1=Pauin|title=Maurice Duplessis: Powerbroker, Politician|page=196|ref=subsidies}}</ref>
Many children were admitted to orphanages because they were abandoned by their parents, not because they were orphans, but often because their parents were unmarried. Children born out of [[Marriage|wedlock]] suffered from poor care.<ref name="Ref 2">{{cite journal|last1=Thifault|first1=Marie-Claude|last2=Perreault|first2=Isabelle|title=The Social Integration of the Mentally Ill in Quebec Prior to the Bédard Report of 1962|journal=Canadian Bulletin of Medical History|date=2002|volume=29|issue=1|page=130}}</ref>
The Quebec government received subsidies from the federal government for building hospitals, but hardly anything for having orphanages. Government contributions were only $1.25 a day for orphans, but $2.75 a day for psychiatric patients,<ref name=Farnsworth/> providing a strong financial incentive for reclassification.
The ''Loi sur les Asiles d'aliénés'' (Lunatic Asylum Act) of 1909 governed mental institution admissions until 1950. The law stated the [[insane]] could be committed for three reasons: to care for them, to help them, or as a measure to maintain social order in public and private life. However, the act did not define what a disruption of social order was, leaving the decision to admit patients up to the psychiatrists.{{sfn|Thifault, p.133}}
The doctors falsely{{Citation needed|reason=This claim needs a reliable source of when the diagnosis was declared "falsely". |date=October 2017}} diagnosed the children with various [[mental illnesses]] while ignoring their actual mental state. Children in Quebec orphanages were therefore declared "mentally deficient". Schooling stopped, and the orphans became inmates in a mental institution where they were sexually, physically, and mentally abused by lay monitors and nuns. Children who complained about the conditions were sent to local [[reform schools]].<ref name=Farnsworth/>
Seven religious orders participated: the [[Sisters of Providence (Montreal)|Sisters of Providence]], the [[Sisters of Mercy]], the Gray Nuns of Montreal, the [[Sisters of Charity of Quebec]], the [[Little Franciscans of Mary]], the [[Brothers of Notre-Dame-de-la-Misericorde]], and the [[Brothers of Charity]].<ref name=Farnsworth/>
A [[:wikt:commission|commission]] in the early 1960s investigating mental institutions after Duplessis' death revealed one-third of the 22,000 patients did not belong.<ref name=Farnsworth/>
The Bédard report of 1962 put an end to the outdated concept of an "asylum," while many of the orphans reached adulthood and could leave the facility.{{sfn|Thifault, p.133}}
Years later, long after these institutions were closed, the children who had survived them and become adults began to speak out about the harsh treatment and [[sexual abuse]] they endured at the hands of some members of institutions and medical personnel.<ref name="Ref 13">[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1WNWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EvIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6929%2C5814760 Protesters in straitjackets demand inquiry of Duplessis Orphans era February 19, 1999]</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DeceAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WHsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6753%2C1774080 Allegations of child abuse April 2, 1993]</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lT9TAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A4UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6732%2C2759782 Orphans sue Catholic orders over mistreatment May 21, 1993 B/W Photo of Denis Coque, Silvio Day, Hervé Bertrand, Yvette Gascon]</ref>
In a psychiatric study completed by one of the involved hospitals, middle-aged Duplessis Orphans reported more physical and mental impairments than the control group. In addition, the orphans were less likely to be married or to have a healthy social life. 80% reported they had suffered a traumatic experience between the ages of 7 to 18. Over 50% said they had undergone physical, mental, or sexual abuse. About 78% reported difficulty functioning socially or emotionally in their adult life.<ref name="Ref 14">{{cite journal|last1=Sigal|first1=John|last2=Christopher|first2=J.|last3=Rossignal|first3=Michel|last4=Ouimet|first4=Marie-Claude|last5=Boucher|first5=Sophie|last6=Paré|first6=Nikolas|title=Health and Psychological Adaptation of les Enfants du Duplessis as Middle-Aged Adults|date=July 31, 2002|pages=15–16|ref=life}}</ref>
==Legal recourse in the 1990s== By the 1990s, there remained about 3,000 survivors and a large group formed to start a campaign. They called themselves the ''Duplessis Orphans'' after Maurice Duplessis, the Premier of Quebec during that time whose government was responsible for their plight. In addition to government and Church responsibility, the College of Physicians of Quebec came under fire after some of the orphans found copies of their medical records that had been falsified. Labelled as mentally deficient, many of these children were subjected to electroshock, a variety of drug testing and used in other [[Human experimentation|medical experiments]].<ref name = "CBC Digital Archives">[http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/society/youth/the-duplessis-orphans/medical-experimentation.html Medical Experimentation] at Duplessis Orphans' CBC Digital Archives</ref> Released upon reaching the legal age of maturity, they were uneducated and ill-equipped to cope with life as adults.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}}
At first, the [[government of Quebec]] [[wikt:stonewall|stonewall]]ed them, but after they started gaining widespread publicity in March 1999, the ''[[Parti Québécois]]'' government made a token offer of approximately $15,000 as full compensation to each of the victims. The offer was rejected and the government was harshly criticized by the public and even the provincial Ombudsman, Daniel Jacoby, came out saying that the government's handling of the situation had [[minimisation (psychology)|trivialized]] the abuse the victims alleged.<ref name = "CBC 1999">[http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/society/youth/the-duplessis-orphans/a-modest-offer-and-apology-rejected.html Modest Offer, Apology Rejected] at Duplessis Orphans' CBC Digital Archives</ref> Nevertheless, the government still refused to hold an inquiry. In 2001, the claimants received an increased offer from the Quebec government for a flat payment of $10,000 per person, plus an additional $1,000 for each year of wrongful confinement to a mental institution.<ref name = "CBC">[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2001/06/30/orphans_010630.html "Duplessis orphans accept Quebec's final offer"], CBC News, July 1, 2001.</ref> The offer amounted to approximately $15,000 per orphan; however, it was limited to each of the surviving 1,100 orphans the government had labeled as mentally deficient, but did not include any compensation for victims of sexual or other abuse.
The offer was accepted by those eligible while the remainder received nothing.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} The vote on the offer was taken by a show of hands in a closed-door session overseen by Committee chief, the author [[Bruno Roy]], one of very few orphans who enjoyed a successful career following the traumatic experience of youth detention. The results of the vote were later bitterly contested by a group which believed the victims should have received more.<ref name = "Mirror2002">{{cite news| url= http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/2002/070402/ncity.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120603155543/http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/2002/070402/ncity.html |title= Orphans oust controversial |work= [[Montreal Mirror]] |archivedate= June 3, 2012 }}</ref> Many believe that justice was not done and criminal wrongdoing was allowed to go unpunished.<ref name="Perry">[http://91.190.232.206:8080/predmet/inostr/deti-siroty/Children.pdf "Seven Institutionalized Children and Their Adaptation in Late Adulthood: The Children of Duplessis"J.Christopher Perry, John J.Sigal, Sophie Boucher, and Nikolas Paré] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407065319/http://91.190.232.206:8080/predmet/inostr/deti-siroty/Children.pdf |date=April 7, 2014 }}</ref>
The Quebec Government declined to prosecute the criminal cases.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2245&dat=20010703&id=Eto0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=JCEGAAAAIBAJ&pg=7064,243210 Orphans accept settlement July 3, 2001]</ref> Opponents of the judgment led by [[Rod Vienneau]] of [[Joliette]], Quebec, pointed out that three of the bureaucrats running the compensation program were being paid over $1,000 per day of work,<ref name = "Mirror2003">{{cite news| url= http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/2003/070303/front.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120630174514/http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/2003/070303/front.html | work= [[Montreal Mirror]] | title= Everyone gets rich except Orphans |archivedate= June 30, 2012}}</ref> whereas the orphans themselves received the same amount for an entire year of their childhood confined illegally to insane asylums.
The Catholic Church publicly announced that they played no responsibility in the orphans' situation and refused to apologize.<ref name=ref>{{cite journal|last1=Campbell|first1=Victoria|title=The Duplessis Orphans at the Canadian Museum for Human Rights: Healing through Representation|journal=Peace and Conflict: Journal of Peace Psychology|date=2013|volume=19|issue=4|page=377|ref=apologize}}</ref> The representative for the seven orders, Sister Gisele Fortier, called the allegations "upsetting ... but very much sensationalized, and needs to be put into context."<ref name="ref 2">{{cite news|last1=Farnsworth|title=Orphans of the 1950s, Telling of Abuse, Sue Quebec|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/05/21/world/orphans-of-the-1950-s-telling-of-abuse-sue-quebec.html?pagewanted=2&pagewanted=all|ref=context}}</ref> [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|Cardinal]] [[Jean-Claude Turcotte]], [[archbishop of Montreal]], asserted that the religious orders "deserve our respect and have a right to their good name." This offended many of the Duplessis Orphans. In 2006, one of the Orphans, Martin Lécuyer, stated "it's important for me, that the church, the priests, that they recognize they were responsible for the sexual abuse, and the aggression. It's not for the government to set that peace ... It's an insult, and it's the biggest proof that the government is an accomplice of the church."<ref name="ref 3">{{cite journal|last1=Campbell|title=The Duplessis Orphans at the Canadian Museum for Human Rights|page=376|accessdate=February 3, 2015|ref=government}}</ref>
==Aftermath== In 1999, Researchers Léo-Paul Lauzon and Martin Poirier issued a report arguing that the Quebec government and the Roman Catholic Church made substantial profits by falsely certifying thousands of Quebec orphans as mentally ill during the 1940s and 1950s. The authors made a conservative estimate that religious groups received $70 million in subsidies (measured in 1999 dollars) by claiming the children as "mentally deficient," while the government saved $37 million simply by having one of its orphanages redesignated from an educational institution to a psychiatric hospital. A representative of a religious order involved with the orphanages accused the authors of making "false assertions."<ref>[[Léo-Paul Lauzon#Other writings]]</ref>
==Fate of the remains== In 2004, members of the "Duplessis Orphans" asked the Quebec government to unearth an abandoned cemetery in the east end of Montreal which they believed held the remains of orphans who may have been the subject of medical experiments. According to testimony by individuals who were at the Cité de St-Jean-de-Dieu insane asylum, the orphans were routinely experimented upon and many died. The group wants the government to exhume the bodies so that autopsies may be performed.<ref name = "CBC 2004">{{cite news| url= http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2004/06/18/duplessis_cemetery040618.html | publisher= CBC | title= Duplessis orphans seek proof of medical experiments |date= June 18, 2004 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100409014034/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2004/06/18/duplessis_cemetery040618.html | archivedate= April 9, 2010}}</ref> On December 13, 2015, a new interview with one of the survivors was conducted on RT.<ref>[https://www.rt.com/shows/in-the-now-summary/325769-duplessis-orphans-atrocity-children/ Duplessis Orphans (S3E8)]</ref>
==See also== *[[Child abuse]] *[[Child sexual abuse]] *[[Religious abuse]] *[[List of Indian residential schools in Canada]] * [[Léo-Paul Lauzon#Other writings|Léo-Paul Lauzon]], in 1999, Lauzon and Martin Poirier issued a report on the money collected by the Quebec government and the Roman Catholic Church who falsely certified thousands of Quebec orphans as mentally ill.

A Historical, Political and Literary Approach.'' In: ''Teaching Canada – Enseigner le Canada'' Ed. Martin Kuester, Claire Köhling, Sylvia Langwald, Albert Rau. Wißner, [[Augsburg]] 2017, pp 165–175

[[Category:Political scandals in Canada]] [[Category:Victims of human rights abuses]] [[Category:History of psychiatry]] [[Category:Medical malpractice]] [[Category:History of Catholicism in Quebec]] [[Category:Political history of Quebec]] [[Category:Roman Catholic Church sex abuse cases in Canada]] [[Category:Anti-pedophile activists in Catholic sex abuse cases]] [[Category:Psychiatric false diagnosis]] [[Category:History of human rights in Canada]]

'''Extracellular digestion''' is a process in which [[saprobionts]] feed by secreting [[enzymes]] through the [[cell membrane]] onto the food. The enzymes catalyze the digestion of the food into [[molecule]]s small enough to be taken up by passive diffusion, transport, or [[phagocytosis]]. Since [[digestion]] occurs outside the cell, it is said to be extracellular. It takes place either in the [[lumen (anatomy)|lumen]] of the [[digestive system]], in a gastric cavity or other digestive organ, or completely outside the body.
The prefix "extra" means "outside", and indicates that extracellular digestion must occur outside the cell. During extracellular digestion, food is broken down outside the cell either mechanically or with acid by special molecules called enzymes. Then the newly broken down nutrients can be absorbed by the cells nearby. Humans use extracellular digestion when they eat. Their teeth grind the food, enzymes and acid in the [[stomach]] liquefy it, and additional enzymes in the [[small intestine]] break the food down into parts their cells can use.
Although [[fungi]] do not have a digestive tract like humans, they still use extracellular digestion. Fungi and other decomposers utilize nutrients derived from breaking down the substrate they grow on. Another example of extracellular digestion being used is in the [[Hydra (genus)|hydra]], or [[sea anemone]]. A large cavity, called the [[gastrovascular cavity]], fills the center of the animal, with one opening for both food and waste. When unsuspecting prey swim into the opening, [[stinging cell]]s paralyze the prey. The hydra uses its tentacles to push the prey further into the cavity, where enzymes are secreted to break down the food. Once the food is broken down extracellularly into nutrients, the cells of the hydra can absorb it for energy.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Morris|first1=James|title=How Life Works|date=2013|publisher=Macmillan|location=New York}}</ref>
Extracellular digestion is a form of digestion found in all saprobiontic [[annelids]], [[crustacean]]s, [[arthropod]]s, [[lichen]]s and [[chordates]], including [[vertebrates]].<ref>Advanced Biology Principles, p296, fig 14.16—Diagram detailing the re-absorption of substrates within the hypha.</ref><ref>Advanced biology principles, p 296—states the purpose of saprotrophs and their internal nutrition, as well as the main two types of fungi that are most often referred to, as well as describes, visually, the process of saprotrophic nutrition through a diagram of hyphae, referring to the Rhizobium on damp, stale whole-meal bread or rotting fruit.</ref><ref>Clegg, C. J.; Mackean, D. G. (2006). Advanced Biology: Principles and Applications, 2nd ed. Hodder Publishing</ref>
== In fungi ==
Fungi are [[heterotrophic]] organisms. Heterotrophic nutrition means that fungi utilize extracellular sources of organic energy, [[organic material]] or organic matter, for their maintenance, growth and reproduction. Energy is derived from the breakdown of the chemical bond between carbon and either carbon or other components of compounds such as a [[phosphate ion]]. The extracellular sources of energy may be [[simple sugar]]s, [[polypeptide]]s or more [[complex carbohydrate]].
Fungi can only absorb small molecules through their walls. For fungi to gain their energy needs, they find and absorb organic molecules appropriate to their needs, either immediately or following some form of enzyme diminution outside the [[thallus]]. The small molecules are then absorbed, used directly or reconstituted (transformed) into organic molecules within the cell.
When a [[skeletonization|skeletonized]] leaf is seen in the litter, it is because [[wikt:recalcitrant|recalcitrant]] materials remain and digestion is continuing. The fungi that utilize a variety of energy sources usually absorb the simplest compounds first, then the more complex. For instance, the formation of [[cellulose]] is repressed by high concentrations of [[glucose]] in the [[cytoplasm]]. On depletion of primary sources of glucose, enzymes to degrade more complex molecules such as cellulose and [[starch]], are then released. Thus soluble sugars and [[amino acid]]s are removed first from a leaf released from a tree. Starch is then broken down and absorbed. Subsequently, [[pectin]] and cellulose are digested. Finally, [[wax]]es are degraded and [[lignin]] [[Redox|oxidized]]. The staggering of energy acquisition results in the efficient utilization of available energy.<ref>{{cite book|last1 = Ingold|first1 = C. T.|title = The Biology of Fungi|date = 1993|location = London|publisher = Chapman & Hall|first2 = Harry J.|last2 = Hudson|isbn = 978-0412490408}}</ref>
== Detection of digestive enzymes in fungi ==
The regulation of nutrient acquisition appears to be controlled by general phenomena. Only a small group of enzymes, mostly [[hydrolase]]s, can be detected in the culture filtrate of well-fed fungi. This suggests that specific inducers control the manufacture and release of enzymes for degradation. The most common complex carbohydrate available in the environment is cellulose. In the absence of glucose, detection of cellulose, for instance, induces the expression of celluloses. As a consequence, fungi specifically target the breakdown of the cellulose in their environment, and do not waste energy on the unnecessary formation of enzymes for degradation of molecules that may not be present. Fungi have an efficient process to gain energy.
Because of the huge range of potential food sources, fungi have evolved enzymes suitable for the environments in which they are usually found. The range of enzymes, though wide in many species, is not sufficient for survival in all environments. Fungi require other competitive attributes to ensure continued survival.
The opposite is also true. Some fungi have highly specific metabolic capabilities which enable occupation of specific habitats, utilizing molecules which are unavailable to other fungi. Further, utilization of a common and abundant [[Substrate (biology)|substrate]] has led many fungi to evolve a range of highly specific degradative enzymes. Among the fungi are species that are generalist in their nutrient requirements, some that have specific nutrient requirements, and many that are in between.<ref>{{cite book|last1 = Jennings|first1 = D. H.|title = The Physiology of Fungal Nutrition|date = March 1995|publisher = Cambridge University Press|location = Cambridge|isbn = 9780521038164}}</ref>
== Execration of digestive enzymes ==
[[File:Single lycoperdon perlatum.jpg|thumb|''[[Lycoperdon perlatum]]'']] Enzymes are manufactured close to the hyphal tip. Some are packaged in vesicles associated with the [[Golgi apparatus|Golgi]] and then delivered to the hyphal tip. The contents are released at the tip. Some enzymes are actively excreted through the [[plasma membrane]], where they diffuse through or act in the cell wall. Note that the enzymes released from the hyphal tip require an aqueous environment for release and subsequent degradative activity.
=== Absorption of digested products ===
The molecules absorbed through the plasma membrane tend to be smaller than 5,000 Da, so only simple sugars, amino acids, [[fatty acid]]s and other small molecules can be taken up following digestion. The molecules are taken up in solution. In some cases, the molecules are processed by enzymes located within the cell wall. For instance, sucrose inverters have been localized in walls of yeasts. Glucose appears to be the sugar preferred by most fungi. Uptake of other sugars is repressed when glucose is available. Similarly, [[ammonium]], [[glutamine]] and [[asparagine]] regulate the uptake of nitrogen compounds, and [[cysteine]] of sulphur compounds.<ref>{{cite book|first1 = Neville J|title = Fungal Ecology|date = 1995|location = London|isbn = 978-94-010-4299-4|page=278|first2 = John|last = Dix|last2 = Webster|publisher = Chapman & Hall}}</ref>
== Joint intracellular and extracellular digestion in cnidarians ==
[[File:Cnidarian Polyp.jpg|thumb|Cnidarian polyp]] Joint intracellular and extracellular digestion In hydra and other [[cnidarian]]s, the food is caught by the tentacles and ingested through the mouth into the single large digestive cavity, the [[gastrovascular cavity]]. Enzymes are secreted from the cells bordering this cavity and poured on the food for extracellular digestion. Small particles of the partially digested food are engulfed into the [[vacuole]]s of the digestive cells for [[intracellular digestion]]. Any undigested and un-absorbed food is finally thrown out of the mouth.<ref>{{cite book|last1=B. Reece|first1=Jane|title=Campbell Biology|publisher=Wolher and creck company|location=United states|page=276|edition=9th}}</ref>
== Invert digestive systems are bags and tubes == [[Single-celled organism]]s as well as [[sponge]]s digest their food intracellularly. Other [[Multicellular organism|multi-cellular organisms]] digest their food extracellularly, within a digestive cavity. In this case the [[digestive enzyme]]s are released into a cavity that is continuous with the animal's external environment. In cnidarians and in [[flatworm]]s such as [[planarian]]s, the digestive cavity, called a gastrovascular cavity, has only one opening that serves as both mouth and anus. There is no specialization within this type of digestive system because every cell is exposed to all stages of food digestion.
Specializing occurs when the digestive tract or alimentary canal has a separate mouth and anus so that transport of food is one-way. The most primitive digestive tract is seen in [[nematode]]s (phylum Nematode), where it is simply a tubular gut lined by an [[epithelial]] membrane. Earthworms (phylum Annelids) have a digestive tract specialized in different regions for the ingestion, storage, fragmentation, digestion and absorption of food. All more complex animal groups, including all vertebrates, show similar specializations.
The ingested food may be stored in a specialized region of the digestive tract or subjected to physical fragmentation. This fragmentation may occur through the chewing action of teeth (in the mouth of many vertebrates) or the grinding action of pebbles (in the gizzard of earthworms and birds). Chemical digestion then occurs, breaking down the larger food molecules of [[polysaccharide]]s and [[disaccharide]]s, fats, and proteins into their smallest sub-units.
Chemical digestion involves [[hydrolysis]] reactions that liberate the sub unit molecules—primarily [[monosaccharide]]s, amino acids and fatty acids—from the food. These products of chemical digestion pass through the epithelial lining of the gut into the blood, in a process known as absorption. Any molecules in the food that are not absorbed cannot be used by the animal. These waste products are excreted, or defecated from the anus.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Susan|first1=Singer|title=Biology|date=2009|publisher=Library of congress cataloging|location=Harvard University|page=92|edition=ninth}}</ref>
== Extracellular digestion in other animals ==
=== Annelids ===
[[File:Pontobdella muricata.png|thumb|A piscicolid leech]] The [[echiuran]] gut is long and highly convoluted, and there is no gut in [[Siboglinidae|pogonophoran]] adults. Among other annelids, the gut is linear and unsegmented, with a mouth opening on the [[peristomium]] and an anus opening at the posterior end of the animal ([[pygidium]]). Food is moved through the gut by cilia and/or by [[muscular contraction]]s. Digestion is primarily extracellular, although some species show an intracellular component as well.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pechenik|first1=Jan|title=Biology of the Invertebrates|date=1976|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=Tufs University|page=305|edition=4th}}</ref>
=== Arthropods ===
The [[arthropod]] digestive system is divisible into three areas: the fore gut, mid gut, and hind gut. All free-living species exhibit a distinct and separate mouth and anus, and in all species, food must be moved through the digestive tract by muscular activity rather than [[cilia]] activity since the [[Lumen (anatomy)|lumen]] of the fore gut and hind gut is lined with [[Arthropod cuticle|cuticle]]. Digestion is generally extracellular. Nutrients are distributed to the tissues through the hemal system.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Susan|first1=Singer|title=Biology|date=2009|publisher=Library of congress cataloging|location=Harvard University|page=374|edition=ninth}}</ref>
=== Molluscs ===
[[File:Chiton-bottom-view.jpg|thumb|Bottom view of a [[chiton]]]] Most [[mollusc]]s have a complete digestive system with a separate mouth and anus. The mouth leads into a short [[esophagus]] which leads to a stomach. Associated with the stomach are one or more [[digestive gland]]s or digestive [[Cecum|caeca]]. Digestive enzymes are secreted into the lumen of these glands. Additional extracellular digestion takes place in the stomach. In [[cephalopod]]s, digestion is entirely extracellular. In the most other mollusks, the terminal stages of digestion are completed intracellularly, within the tissue of the digestive glands. The absorbed nutrients enter the [[circulatory system]] for distribution throughout the body or are stored in the digestive glands for later use. Undigested waste pass through an intestine and out through the anus. Other aspects of food collection and processing have already been discussed where appropriate for each group.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pechenik|first1=Jan|title=Biology of the Invertebrates|date=1976|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=Tufs University|page=257|edition=4th}}</ref>
=== Humans ===
[[File:Aparato digestivo.jpg|thumb|Extracellular digestion in humans occurs from the ''boca'' to the ''estómago'' (mouth and stomach respectively in Spanish)]] The initial components of the [[gastrointestinal tract]] are the mouth and the [[pharynx]], which is the common passage of the oral and nasal cavities. The pharynx leads to the esophagus, a muscular tube that delivers food to the stomach, where some preliminary digestion occurs; here, the digestion is extracellular.
From the stomach, food passes to the [[small intestine]], where a battery of digestive enzymes continue the digestive process. The products of digestion are absorbed across the wall of the intestine into the [[bloodstream]]. What remains is emptied into the [[large intestine]], where some of the remaining water and minerals are absorbed; here the digestion is intracellular.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Susan|first1=Singer|title=Biology|date=2009|publisher=Library of congress cataloging|location=Harvard University|page=989|edition=ninth}}</ref>

revision.text:
The '''glass delusion''' is an external manifestation of a [[Mental disorder|psychiatric disorder]] recorded in Europe mainly in the late [[Middle Ages]] and [[early modern period]] (fifteenth to seventeenth centuries).<ref>{{cite journal | last=Speak | first=Gill | title=An odd kind of melancholy: reflections on the glass delusion in Europe (1440–1680) | journal=History of Psychiatry | year=1990 | volume=2 | issue=2 | pages=191–206 | doi=10.1177/0957154X9000100203 }}</ref> People feared that they were made of [[glass]] "and therefore likely to shatter into pieces". One famous early sufferer was King [[Charles VI of France]] who refused to allow people to touch him, and wore reinforced clothing to protect himself from accidental "shattering".
==The delusion==
Concentration of the glass delusion among the wealthy and educated classes allowed modern scholars to associate it with a wider and better described disorder of scholar's melancholy.<ref name=LIC1>Speak, "El licenciado...", p.850</ref>
==Contemporary accounts== [[Robert Burton (scholar)|Robert Burton]]'s ''[[The Anatomy of Melancholy]]'' (1621) touches on the subject in the commentary as one of many related manifestations<ref>{{cite book | author=[[Robert Burton (scholar)|Robert Burton]] | title=The Anatomy of Melancholy | year=1621 }}</ref> of the same anxiety: "Fear of devils, [[Thanatophobia|death]], that they shall be so sick, of some such or such disease, ready to tremble at every object, they shall die themselves forthwith, or that some of their dear friends or near allies are certainly dead; imminent danger, loss, disgrace still torment others; that they are all glass, and therefore will suffer no man to come near them; that they are all [[Cork (material)|cork]], as light as feathers; others as heavy as [[lead]]; some are afraid their heads will fall off their shoulders, that they have frogs in their bellies, Etc."<ref>Burton, Com.1 Sec.3 comment no. 52</ref>
[[Miguel de Cervantes]] based one of his short ''[[Exemplary Novels]]'', ''The Glass Graduate'' ({{lang-es|[[El licenciado Vidriera]]}}, 1613), on the delusion of the title subject, an aspiring young lawyer.<ref>{{cite book | author=[[Cervantes]] | title=The Glass Graduate (also known as ''The Glass Licenciate'', ''The Glass Lawyer''; Spanish: [[El licenciado Vidriera]]) | year=1613 }}</ref> Thomas Rodaja fell into a grave depression after being bedridden for six months subsequent to being poisoned with a purportedly [[aphrodisiac]] potion. He claimed that, being of glass, his perceptions are clearer than those of men of flesh and demonstrated by offering witty comments. After two years of illness, Rodaja was cured by a monk; no details of the cure are provided except that the monk was allegedly a miracle-maker.
Dutch poet [[Constantijn Huygens]] wrote a ''Costly Folly'' (1622) centered on a subject who "fears everything that moves in his vicinity... the chair will be the death for him, he trembles at the bed, fearful that one will break his bum, the other smash his head".<ref name="LIC1"/>
French philosopher [[René Descartes]] wrote ''Meditations on First Philosophy'' (1641), using the glass [[delusion]] as an example of an [[Insanity|insane]] person whose perceived knowledge of the world differs from the majority.<ref>{{cite book | author=[[René Descartes]] | title=Meditations on First Philosophy | year=1641 | isbn=0-87484-893-8 }}</ref>
In modern times, the glass delusion has not completely disappeared. There are still isolated cases today. "Surveys of modern psychiatric institutions have only revealed two specific (uncorroborated) cases of the glass delusion. Foulché-Delbosc reports finding one Glass Man in a Paris [[Bicêtre Hospital|asylum]], and a woman who thought she was a potsherd was recorded at an asylum in [[Merenberg]]." Andy Lameijn, a psychiatrist from the Netherlands, reports that he has a male patient suffering from the delusion in [[Leiden]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The people who think they are made of glass|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-32625632|website=BBC News|date=8 May 2015 |accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref>
==Tchaikovsky== The neurotic behavior of the nineteenth-century Russian composer [[Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky]] seems reminiscent of the glass delusion, centering as it did around his difficulties caused by his belief that his head would fall off while conducting if he did not hold his chin. While the legend may be exaggerated, it seems to have some basis in fact:
{{quote|In March 1868 in his first attempt [at conducting], Tchaikovsky conducted dances from ''[[The Voyevoda (opera)|The Voevoda]]'', "and had felt that his head would fall sideways unless he fought to keep it upright" ... (per David Brown, ''The Final Years'' page 97) ... and so he avoided conducting ... In October 1886 Tchaikovsky pointed out to his patroness "all my life I have been tormented by awareness of my inability to conduct. It has seemed to me there is something shameful and disreputable in not being able to stop myself trembling with fear and horror at the very thought of going out in front of the public with a baton" ... However on Jan. 31, 1887 Tchaikovsky in his third attempt overcame his fear and conducted the premier of ''[[The Enchantress (opera)|The Enchantress]]'' ... as a further inducement "he was not unaware that a conductor could enjoy more celebrity in his own time than a composer."{{cn|date=June 2017}}<!--appears to be a copyvio of http://www.tchaikovsky-research.net/en/forum/forum0079.html, quoting "Tchaikovsky, The Quest for the Inner Man" by Alexander Poznansky-->}}
== Notes == {{Reflist}} == References == *{{cite journal | doi=10.2307/3732644 | last=Speak | first=Gill | title='El licenciado Vidriera' and the Glass Men of Early Modern Europe | journal=The Modern Language Review | volume=85 |date=October 1990 | pages=850–865 | issue=4 | jstor=3732644 }} * {{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/northyorkshire/content/articles/2005/12/05/glass_music_feature.shtml | title=Music for a glass man | date=December 5, 2005 | publisher=BBC }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Glass Delusion}}
[[Category:Abnormal psychology]] [[Category:Culture-bound syndromes]] [[Category:History of mental health]]

revision.comment: CS1 maint - template details, consolidated repeated citations.
revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Glossitis | synonyms = | image = Scharlach.JPG | caption = Glossitis in a person with [[scarlet fever]] ("red strawberry tongue"). | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Glossitis''' can mean soreness of the tongue, or more usually inflammation with depapillation of the dorsal surface of the tongue (loss of the [[lingual papilla]]e), leaving a smooth and [[erythema]]tous (reddened) surface,<ref name="Scully 2008">{{cite book|last=Scully|first=Crispian|title=Oral and maxillofacial medicine : the basis of diagnosis and treatment|year=2008|publisher=Churchill Livingstone|location=Edinburgh|isbn=978-0443068188|edition=2nd|page=356}}</ref><ref name="Rogers 2010" /> (sometimes specifically termed '''atrophic glossitis'''). In a wider sense, glossitis can mean inflammation of the tongue generally.<ref name="Domino 2012" /> Glossitis is often caused by [[nutritional deficiency|nutritional deficiencies]] and may be painless or cause discomfort. Glossitis usually responds well to treatment if the cause is identified and corrected. Tongue soreness caused by glossitis is differentiated from [[burning mouth syndrome]], where there is no identifiable change in the appearance of the tongue, and there are no identifiable causes.<ref name=McMillan2016>{{Cite journal|last=McMillan|first=Roddy|last2=Forssell|first2=Heli|last3=Buchanan|first3=John Ag|last4=Glenny|first4=Anne-Marie|last5=Weldon|first5=Jo C.|last6=Zakrzewska|first6=Joanna M.|date=2016|title=Interventions for treating burning mouth syndrome|url=|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|volume=11|pages=CD002779|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002779.pub3|issn=1469-493X|pmid=27855478|via=}}</ref>
== Symptoms == [[File:Glossite.jpg|thumbnail|right|Patchy depapillation of filiform papillae with prominence of the fungiform papillae.]] Depending upon what exact meaning of the word glossitis is implied, signs and symptoms might include:
* Smooth, shiny appearance of the tongue, caused by loss of lingual papillae. * Tongue color changes, usually to a darker red color than the normal white-pink color of a healthy tongue. * Tongue swelling. * Difficulty with chewing, [[Dysphagia|swallowing]], or speaking (either because of tongue soreness of tongue swelling). * Burning sensation.<ref name="Scully 2008" /> Some use the term secondary burning mouth syndrome in cases where a detectable cause, such as glossitis, for an oral burning sensation.<ref name=McMillan2016 />
Depending upon the underlying cause, there may be additional signs and symptoms such as [[pallor]], oral ulceration and angular cheilitis.<ref name="Scully 2008" />
== Causes ==
===Anemias=== [[Iron-deficiency anemia]] is mainly caused by blood loss, such as may occur during [[menses]] or [[gastrointestinal hemorrhage]]. This often results in a depapilled, atrophic glossitis, giving the tongue a bald and shiny appearance, along with [[pallor]] (paleness) of the lips and other mucous membranes a tendency towards recurrent [[oral ulceration]],<ref name="Bruch 2010" /> and [[cheilosis]] (swelling of the lips).<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> The appearance of the tongue in iron deficiency anemia has been described as diffuse or patchy atrophy with tenderness or burning.<ref name="Neville 2001" /> One cause of iron deficiency anemia is [[sideropenic dysphagia]] (Plummer–Vinson or Paterson–Brown–Kelly syndrome) which is also characterized by [[esophageal web]]bing and dysphagia.<ref name="Bruch 2010" />
[[Pernicious anemia]] is usually caused by [[autoimmunity|autoimmune]] destruction of [[stomach|gastric]] [[parietal cell]]s. Parietal cells secrete [[intrinsic factor]] which is required for the absorption of vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 deficiency results in [[megaloblastic anemia]] and may present as glossitis. The appearance of the tongue in vitamin B12 deficiency is described as "beefy" or "fiery red and sore".<ref name="Bruch 2010">{{cite book|vauthors=Treister NS, Bruch JM |title=Clinical oral medicine and pathology|year=2010|publisher=Humana Press|location=New York|isbn=978-1-60327-519-4|pages=149}}</ref> There may be linear or patchy red lesions.<ref name="Scully 2008" />
===Vitamin B deficiencies=== [[Vitamin B1 deficiency]] ([[thiamin]] deficiency) can cause glossitis.<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> [[Vitamin B2 deficiency]] (ariboflavinosis) can cause glossitis, along with [[angular cheilitis]], [[cheilosis]], [[peripheral neuropathy]] and other signs and symptoms.<ref name="Yamada GI textbook">{{cite book|veditors = ((Tadataka Yamada)), ((David H. Alpers, et al.))|title=Textbook of gastroenterology|year=2009|publisher=Blackwell Pub.|location=Chichester, West Sussex|isbn=978-1-4051-6911-0|edition=5th|pages=1717–1744}}</ref> The glossitis in vitamin B2 deficiency is described as [[magenta]].<ref name="Park 2011">{{cite journal|last=Park|first=KK|author2=Brodell RT|author3=Helms SE.|title=Angular cheilitis, part 2: nutritional, systemic, and drug-related causes and treatment.|journal=Cutis|date=July 2011|volume=88|issue=1|pages=27–32|pmid=21877503|url=http://www.skinandallergynews.com/fileadmin/qhi_archive/ArticlePDF/CT/088010027.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419015237/http://www.skinandallergynews.com/fileadmin/qhi_archive/ArticlePDF/CT/088010027.pdf|archivedate=2014-04-19|df=}}</ref> [[Vitamin B3 deficiency]] (pellagra) can cause glossitis.<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> [[Vitamin B6 deficiency]] ([[pyridoxine]] deficiency) can cause glossitis, along with angular cheilitis, cheilosis, peripheral neuropathy and [[seborrheic dermatitis]].<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> [[Folate deficiency]] (vitamin B9 deficiency) can cause glossitis, along with macrocytic anemia, [[thrombocytopenia]], [[leukopenia]], [[diarrhea]], [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]] and possibly [[neurological]] signs.<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> Apart from pernicious anemia discussed above, any other cause of vitamin B12 deficiency can cause glossitis, which tends to be painful, smooth and shiny.<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" />
===Infections=== [[Bacteria]]l, [[virus|viral]] or [[fungal]] infections can cause glossitis. ''Candida'' species are involved in median rhomboid glossitis. {{clarify span|''Candida'' species also may be involved in creating a more generalized glossitis with erythema, burning, and atrophy,<ref name="Chi 2010" />|date=October 2016}}
{{clarify span|e.g. erythematous candidiasis (e.g. as may occur in [[HIV/AIDS]]) may involve the tongue giving glossitis with depapillation.<ref name="Scully 2008" />|date=October 2016}}
[[Syphilis]] is now relatively rare, but the tertiary stage can cause diffuse glossitis and atrophy of lingual papillae, termed "syphilitic glossitis",<ref name="Scully 2008" /> "luetic glossitis" or "atrophic glossitis of tertiary syphilis".<ref name="Neville 2001">{{cite book|vauthors=Neville BW, Damm DD, Allen CA, Bouquot JE |title=Oral & maxillofacial pathology|year=2002|publisher=W.B. Saunders|location=Philadelphia|isbn=0721690033|pages=169, 170|edition=2nd}}</ref> It is caused by [[Treponema pallidum]] and is a [[sexually transmitted infection]].
===Other causes=== Many conditions can cause glossitis via [[malnutrition]] or [[malabsorption]],<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> which creates the nutritional deficiencies described above, although other mechanisms may be involved in some of those conditions listed.
* [[Alcoholism]]<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * [[Sprue (disambiguation)|Sprue]] ([[celiac disease]],<ref name="Pastore 2008">{{cite journal | vauthors = Pastore L, Carroccio A, Compilato D, Panzarella V, Serpico R, Lo Muzio L | title = Oral manifestations of celiac disease | journal = J. Clin. Gastroenterol. | volume = 42 | issue = 3 | pages = 224–32 | date = March 2008 | pmid = 18223505 | doi = 10.1097/MCG.0b013e318074dd98 }}</ref> or [[tropical sprue]]), secondary to nutritional deficiencies<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * [[Crohn’s disease]]<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * [[Whipple disease]]<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * [[Glucagonoma]] syndrome<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * [[Cowden disease]]<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * [[Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome]] (AIDS)<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * [[Carcinoid syndrome]]<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * Kwashiorkor amyloidosis<ref name="Yamada GI textbook" /> * [[Veganism]] and other [[list of diets|specialized diets]],<ref name="Scully 2008" /> *Poor hydration and low [[saliva]] in the mouth, which allows bacteria to grow more readily *Mechanical irritation or injury from burns, rough edges of teeth or dental appliances, or other trauma *[[Tongue piercing]]<ref name="AMLevin">{{cite journal | vauthors = Levin L, Zadik Y | title = Oral piercing: complications and side effects | journal = Am J Dent | volume = 20 | issue = 5 | pages = 340–4 | date = October 2007 | pmid = 17993034 }}</ref> Glossitis can be caused by the constant irritation by the ornament and by colonization of [[Candida albicans]] in site and on the ornament<ref name="Candida">{{cite journal | vauthors = Zadik Y, Burnstein S, Derazne E, Sandler V, Ianculovici C, Halperin T | title = Colonization of Candida: prevalence among tongue-pierced and non-pierced immunocompetent adults | journal = Oral Dis | volume = 16 | issue = 2 | pages = 172–5 | date = March 2010 | pmid = 19732353 | doi = 10.1111/j.1601-0825.2009.01618.x }}</ref> *Exposure to irritants such as [[tobacco]], [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]], hot foods, or [[spice]]s *Allergic reaction to [[toothpaste]], [[mouthwash]], breath fresheners, dyes in confectionery, plastic in dentures or retainers, or certain blood-pressure medications ([[ACE inhibitors]]) *Administration of [[ganglion blockers]] (e.g., [[Tubocurarine]], [[Mecamylamine]]). *Oral [[lichen planus]], [[erythema multiforme]], [[aphthous ulcer]], [[pemphigus]] vulgaris *Heredity *[[Albuterol]] (bronchodilator medicine) A painful tongue may be an indication of an underlying serious medical condition and nearly always merits assessment by a [[physician]] or [[dentist|dental surgeon]].
==Diagnosis== ===Classification=== [[File:Glossitis.jpg|thumbnail|right|Median rhomboid glossitis]] [[File:Landkartenzunge 005.jpg|thumbnail|right|Geographic tongue (benign migratory glossitis)]] Glossitis could be classified as a group of [[tongue disease]]s or [[gastrointestinal disease]]s.<ref name="Domino 2012">{{cite book|veditors = ((Frank J. Domino (editor-in-chief))), ((Robert A. Baldor, associate editors))|title=The 5-minute clinical consult 2012|publisher=Wolters Kluwer Health/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia, Pa.|isbn=978-1451103038|edition=20th|pages=532–33|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uhslTCenOQsC&pg=PA533&dq=%22glossitis%22#v=onepage&q=%22glossitis%22&f=false|displayauthors=etal |date=2012-03-07}}</ref> It may be primary, where there is no underlying cause, or secondary where it is a sign or symptom of another condition.<ref name="Rogers 2010">{{cite book|veditors =Rogers, K |title=The digestive system|year=2010|publisher=Britannica Educational Pub., in association with Rosen Educational Services|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-1615301317|page=146|edition=1st}}</ref> It can be acute or chronic.<ref name="Domino 2012" /> Generally speaking, there are several clinical patterns of glossitis, some more common than others.
====Atrophic glossitis==== Atrophic glossitis, also known as bald tongue,<ref name="Rogers 2010" /> smooth tongue, Hunter glossitis, Moeller glossitis, or Möller-Hunter glossitis,<ref name="Falco" >{{cite book|author=O. Braun-Falco|title=Dermatology|year=2000|publisher=Springer|location=Berlin [u.a.]|isbn=3540594523|page=1173|edition=2nd}}</ref> is a condition characterized by a smooth glossy tongue that is often tender/painful,<ref name="Andrews" /> caused by complete atrophy of the lingual papillae (depapillation).<ref name="Rogers 2010" /> The dorsal tongue surface may be affected totally, or in patches, and may be associated with a burning sensation, pain and/or erythema.<ref name="Chi 2010" /> Atrophic glossitis is a non-specific finding,<ref name="Chi 2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Chi AC, Neville BW, Krayer JW, Gonsalves WC | title = Oral manifestations of systemic disease | journal = Am Fam Physician | volume = 82 | issue = 11 | pages = 1381–8 | date = December 2010 | pmid = 21121523|type = review}}</ref> and has a great many causes, usually related to [[iron-deficiency anemia]], [[pernicious anemia]], [[B vitamins|B vitamin complex]] deficiencies,<ref name="Chi 2010"/> unrecognized and untreated [[celiac disease]] (which often presents without gastrointestinal symptoms),<ref name=RashidZarkadas2011>{{cite journal|vauthors= Rashid M, Zarkadas M, Anca A, Limeback H|title= Oral manifestations of celiac disease: a clinical guide for dentists|date= 2011|journal= J Can Dent Assoc|volume= 77|pages=b39|url= http://www.jcda.ca/article/b39|pmid= 21507289|type=Review}}</ref><ref name=NIH>{{cite web|url=http://celiac.nih.gov/PDF/Dental_Enamel_Defects_508.pdf|title=Dental Enamel Defects and Celiac Disease|publisher=National Institute of Health (NIH)|access-date=Mar 7, 2016|quote=Tooth defects that result from celiac disease may resemble those caused by too much fluoride or a maternal or early childhood illness. Dentists mostly say it’s from fluoride, that the mother took tetracycline, or that there was an illness early on}}</ref><ref name=GiucaCei2010>{{cite journal|vauthors=Giuca MR, Cei G, Gigli F, Gandini P|title=Oral signs in the diagnosis of celiac disease: review of the literature|date=2010 |journal=Minerva Stomatol|volume=59|issue=1-2|pages=33–43|pmid=20212408|type=Review|quote=There are enough evidence making the correlation between CD and oral defects scientifically sustainable. This recognition should lead dentists to play more significant roles in screening for CD, as otherwise, if not properly diagnosed and not treated with a gluten-free diet, may eventually cause some malignancies.}}</ref> or other factors such as [[xerostomia]] (dry mouth). Although the terms Möller and Hunter glossitis were originally used to refer to specifically the glossitis that occurs in vitamin B12 deficiency secondary to pernicious anemia, they are now used as synonyms for atrophic glossitis generally.<ref name="Falco" /> In this article, the term glossitis, unless otherwise specified, refers to atrophic glossitis.
Candidiasis may be a concurrent finding or an alternative cause of erythema, burning, and atrophy.
====Median rhomboid glossitis==== {{Main article|Median rhomboid glossitis}} This condition is characterized by a persistent erythematous, rhomboidal depapillated lesion in the central area of the dorsum of the tongue, just in front of the [[circumvallate papilla]]e.<ref name="Scully 2008" /><ref name="Andrews">{{cite book|author1=James, William D. |author2=Berger, Timothy G. |title=Andrews' Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology|year=2006|publisher=Saunders Elsevier|isbn=0721629210|page=803|edition=14th|displayauthors=etal }}</ref> Median rhomboid glossitis is a type of [[oral candidiasis]], and rarely causes any symptoms. It is treated with [[antifungal medication]]. Predisposing factors include use of [[corticosteroid]] sprays or inhalers or [[immunosuppression]].
====Benign migratory glossitis==== {{main article|Geographic tongue}} Geographic tongue, also termed benign migratory glossitis, is a common condition which usually affects the dorsal surface of the tongue. It is characterized by patches of depapillation and erythema bordered by a whitish peripheral zone. These patches give the tongue the appearance of a map, hence the name. Unlike glossitis due to nutritional deficiencies and anemia, the lesions of geographic tongue move around the tongue over time.<ref name="Adeyemo 2011">{{cite journal|last=Adeyemo|first=TA|author2=Adeyemo, WL |author3=Adediran, A |author4=Akinbami, AJ |author5= Akanmu, AS |title=Orofacial manifestations of hematological disorders: anemia and hemostatic disorders.|journal=Indian Journal of Dental Research |date=May–Jun 2011|volume=22|issue=3|pages=454–61|pmid=22048588|url=http://www.ijdr.in/article.asp?issn=0970-9290;year=2011;volume=22;issue=3;spage=454;epage=461;aulast=Adeyemo|doi=10.4103/0970-9290.87070}}</ref> This is because in geographic tongue, new areas of the tongue become involved with the condition whilst previously affected areas heal, giving the appearance of a moving lesion.<ref name="Rogers 2010" /> The cause is unknown,<ref name="Reamy 2010">{{cite journal|last=Reamy|first=BV|author2=Derby, R |author3=Bunt, CW |title=Common tongue conditions in primary care.|journal=American Family Physician|date=Mar 1, 2010|volume=81|issue=5|pages=627–34|pmid=20187599|url=http://www.aafp.org/afp/2010/0301/p627.html}}</ref> and there is no curative treatment. Rarely are there any symptoms associated with the lesions, but occasionally a burning sensation may be present, which is exacerbated by eating hot, spicy or acidic foodstuffs. Some consider geographic tongue to be an early stage of [[fissured tongue]], since the two conditions often occur in combination.<ref name="Greenberg 2008">{{cite book|author1=Greenberg, MS |author2=Glick, M |author3=Ship, JA |title=Burket's oral medicine|year=2008|publisher=BC Decker|location=Hamilton, Ont.|isbn=1550093452|pages=|edition=11th|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Q2SP8cOZPvkC&pg=PA103&dq=geographic+tongue#v=onepage&q=geographic%20tongue&f=false}}</ref>
====Geometric glossitis==== Geometric glossitis, also termed herpetic geometric glossitis,<ref name="Domino 2012" /> is a term used by some to refer to a chronic lesion associated with [[herpes simplex virus]] (HSV) type I infection,<ref name="Cohen 1995">{{cite journal|last=Cohen|first=PR|author2=Kazi, S |author3=Grossman, ME |title=Herpetic geometric glossitis: a distinctive pattern of lingual herpes simplex virus infection.|journal=Southern Medical Journal|date=December 1995|volume=88|issue=12|pages=1231–35|pmid=7502116|doi=10.1097/00007611-199512000-00009}}</ref> in which there is a deep fissure in the midline of the tongue, which gives off multiple branches.<ref name="Neville 2001" /> The lesion is usually very painful, and there may be erosions present in the depths of the fissures. Similar fissured lesions which are not associated with HSV, as may occur in fissured tongue, do not tend to be painful.<ref name="Cohen 1995" /> The name comes from the geometric pattern of the fissures which are longitudinal, crossed or branched.<ref name="Grossman 1993">{{cite journal|last=Grossman|first=ME|author2=Stevens, AW |author3=Cohen, PR |title=Brief report: herpetic geometric glossitis.|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=Dec 16, 1993|volume=329|issue=25|pages=1859–60|pmid=8247038|url=http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199312163292506|doi=10.1056/NEJM199312163292506}}</ref> It is described as occurring in immunocompromized persons, e.g. who have [[leukemia]]. However, the association between herpes simplex and geometric glossitis is disputed by some due to a lack of gold standard techniques for diagnosis of intraoral herpetic lesions, and the high prevalence of asymptomatic viral shedding in immunocompromized individuals.<ref name="Neville 2001" /> Treatment is with systemic [[aciclovir]].<ref name="Cohen 1995" />
====Strawberry tongue==== Strawberry tongue (also called raspberry tongue),<ref name="Mosby's">{{cite book|veditors = ((Scott Stocking, associate editor)), ((Jyothimai Gubili))|title=Mosby's dental dictionary|year=2004|publisher=Mosby|location=St. Louis, Mo.|isbn=978-0323025102}}</ref> refers to glossitis which manifests with [[hyperplasia|hyperplastic]] (enlarged) [[fungiform papilla]]e, giving the appearance of a strawberry. White strawberry tongue is where there is a white coating on the tongue through which the hyperplastic fungiform papillae protrude.<!-- <ref name="Neville 2001" /> --> Red strawberry tongue is where the white coating is lost and a dark red, erythematous surface is revealed, interspaced with the hyperplastic fungiform papillae.<!-- <ref name="Neville 2001" /> --> White strawberry tongue is seen in early [[scarlet fever]] (a systemic infection of [[Streptococcus#Group A|group A β- hemolytic streptococci]]),<ref name="pmid17719644">{{cite journal |vauthors=Yang SG, Dong HJ, Li FR |title=Report and analysis of a scarlet fever outbreak among adults through food-borne transmission in China |journal=J. Infect. |volume=55 |issue=5 |pages=419–24 |date=November 2007 |pmid=17719644 |doi=10.1016/j.jinf.2007.07.011 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0163-4453(07)00701-3 |displayauthors=etal }}</ref> and red strawberry tongue occurs later, after 4–5 days.<ref name="Neville 2001" /> Strawberry tongue is also seen in [[Kawasaki disease]] (a vasculitic disorder primarily occurring in children under 5),<ref name="Singh 2005">{{cite journal|last=Singh|first=S|author2=Kansra, S|title=Kawasaki disease.|journal=The National Medical Journal of India|date=Jan–Feb 2005|volume=18|issue=1|pages=20–24|pmid=15835487}}</ref><ref name="pmid9184977">{{cite journal | vauthors = Park AH, Batchra N, Rowley A, Hotaling A | title = Patterns of Kawasaki syndrome presentation | journal = Int. J. Pediatr. Otorhinolaryngol. | volume = 40 | issue = 1 | pages = 41–50 | date = May 1997 | pmid = 9184977 | doi = 10.1016/S0165-5876(97)01494-8}}</ref> and [[toxic shock syndrome]].<ref name="pmid7106318">{{cite journal | vauthors = Baehler EA, Dillon WP, Cumbo TJ, Lee RV | title = Prolonged use of a diaphragm and toxic shock syndrome | journal = Fertil. Steril. | volume = 38 | issue = 2 | pages = 248–50 | date = August 1982 | pmid = 7106318}}</ref> It may mimic other types of glossitis or [[Vitamin B12 deficiency]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.pediatrics.wisc.edu/education/derm/tutc/strawberry.html |title= Skin Lesions: Strawberry Tongue|accessdate=2007-08-14 |author1=Gary Williams |author2=Murray Katcher |work=Primary Care Dermatology Module (University of Wisconsin Madison)}}</ref>
== Prevention == Good [[oral hygiene]] (thorough tooth brushing and flossing and regular professional cleaning and examination) may be helpful to prevent these disorders. Drinking plenty of water and the production of enough saliva, aid in the reduction of bacterial growth. Minimizing irritants or injury in the mouth when possible can aid in the prevention of glossitis. Avoiding excessive use of any food or substance that irritates the mouth or tongue may also help.
== Treatment == The goal of treatment is to reduce inflammation. Treatment usually does not require hospitalization unless tongue swelling is severe. Good [[oral hygiene]] is necessary, including thorough tooth brushing at least twice a day, and flossing at least daily. Corticosteroids such as prednisone may be given to reduce the inflammation of glossitis. For mild cases, topical applications (such as a prednisone mouth rinse that is not swallowed) may be recommended to avoid the side effects of swallowed or injected corticosteroids. Antibiotics, antifungal medications, or other antimicrobials may be prescribed if the cause of glossitis is an infection. Anemia and nutritional deficiencies (such as a [[pellagra|deficiency in niacin]], [[riboflavin]], iron, or [[Vitamin E]]) must be treated, often by dietary changes or other supplements. Avoid irritants (such as hot or spicy foods, alcohol, and tobacco) to minimize the discomfort. In some cases, tongue swelling may threaten the airway, a [[medical emergency]] that needs immediate attention.
==Epidemiology== One review reported overall [[prevalence]] ranges of 0.1–14.3% for geographic tongue, 1.3–9.0% for "atrophy tongue" (atrophic glossitis), and 0.0–3.35% for median rhomboid glossitis.<ref name="pmid1291323">{{cite journal | vauthors = Dombi C, Czeglédy A | title = [Incidence of tongue diseases based on epidemiologic studies (review of the literature)] | language = Hungarian | journal = Fogorv Sz | volume = 85 | issue = 11 | pages = 335–41 | date = November 1992 | pmid = 1291323 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Medical resources | ICD10 = {{ICD10|K|14|0}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|529.0}} | DiseasesDB = 5252 | MedlinePlus = 001053 }} {{Oral pathology}} {{Inflammation}}
