revision.text:
{{for|the heritage building which houses the foundation|Gota de Leche Building}} {{Infobox organization | name = Gota de Leche | type = Non-governmental organization | founded_date = 1906 | founder = Trinidad Rizal, Concepcion Felix | location = 859 S. Loyola St., [[Sampaloc, Manila]], [[Philippines]] | area_served = Philippines | mission = To provide nutritional and medical needs of indigent mothers and their children | owner = La Protección de la Infancia Inc. }}
'''Gota de Leche''' (lit. A Drop of Milk<ref>{{cite web|title=Gota de Leche|url=http://gotadeleche.com/about/|website=Gota de Leche June 2014}}</ref>) is a foundation started by Trinidad Rizal (sister of Philippine National Hero, Dr. [[José Rizal]]) and [[Concepción Felix]] on 1906 that primarily aims to provide nutritional and medical needs of indigent Filipino mothers and their children. Founded by La Protección de la Infancia Inc., the foundation continues to deliver daily milk rations to Filipino infants
Its headquarters, the Gota de Leche building located at 859 S. Loyota St., Sampaloc, Manila, Philippines, designed by architects [[Juan Arellano]] and Arcadio Arellano (founding father of Philippine architecture), was awarded Honourable Mention by the [[UNESCO Asia Pacific Heritage Awards]] for [[Cultural Heritage]] Conservation in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title=Winners for the 2003 UNESCO Asia-Pacific Heritage Awards|url=http://www.unescobkk.org/culture/wh/asia-pacific-heritage-awards/previous-heritage-awards-2000-2013/2003/|website=UNESCO Bangkok|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref> This opened further support from the [[National Commission on Culture and the Arts]].
The [[Gota de Leche Building]] was declared by the [[National Museum of the Philippines]] as an Important Cultural Property in August 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.facebook.com/GotaDeLecheManila/photos/a.1385224825033376.1073741833.1374978069391385/1408851679337357/?type=1|title = Declaration of the Gota de Leche Manila as an Important Cultural Property, attested to and confirmed 18th of August, 2014 by the National Museum|date = October 2, 2014|accessdate = |website = Facebook|publisher = Gota de Leche Manila|last = |first = }}</ref>
== History == [[File:Gota de Leche 09.jpg|thumb|The [[Gota de Leche Building]]]] [[File:Milk and Brown Rice Canisters.jpg|thumb|''Milk and Brown Rice Canisters''|300x200px]] ''[[Beriberi]]'', a sickness caused by a nutritional deficit in Vitamin B1 or Thiamine, was discovered among Filipino women after the Philippine–American War in 1902. Hundreds of infants died before ever reaching 3 months old and it was found that the milk coming from affected mothers were causing these deaths. This distressing condition moved a group of women to address the situation. And so in 1905, Asosación Feminista Filipina was born. It was led by Trinidad Rizal and Concepcion Felix, together with other educated women of the time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gota de Leche|url=http://gotadeleche.com/timeline/|website=Gota de Leche|accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref>
Gota de Leche was established the year after, in 1906, as station that manages the daily distribution of pasteurized cow’s milk to Filipino infants. They also provide nutrition education programs to Filipino mothers.
This project was recognized as heroic and in order for it to further succeed, the founders needed to collaborate with other professionals who were willing to lend a helping hand to the cause. The collaboration subsequently led to the formation of La Protección de la Infacia Inc., the Philippines’ first independent charity organization constituted by doctors and business leaders among others.
La Protección de la Infancia Inc. opened Gota de Leche, the brainchild of Dr. Calderon, who was inspired after witnessing the noble act of the organization.
Initially headquartered on ''Calle San Pedro'' (now Evangelista Street) in [[Santa Cruz, Manila|Santa Cruz]] near [[Plaza Miranda]], the society moved to its present location in Sampaloc upon the completion of the Gota de Leche Building in 1917.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/cu31924023437738 |title=The Philippines, the land of palm and pine: an official guide and hand book (1912) |publisher=Manila Bureau of Print |accessdate=11 July 2014}}</ref>
Gota de Leche continues its charitable activities. It still provides nutritional and medical assistance to qualified Filipino mothers and children while closely monitoring their improvement. This landmark building also houses the first national center for women’s rights that provides counselling services. Other services include dental assistance, educating families on common illnesses, and playing educational games with the children.
Gota de Leche has also started their Brown Rice program, for impoverished families ensuring access to complementary food rations for both mother and child. Volunteers come and provide information on diet and keeping healthy to their parents.
In the wake of the recent disaster caused by Typhoon Yolanda, the institution has also opened its doors, literally, to those displaced by the typhoon.
The careful restoration of Gota de Leche established the importance of heritage structures and the value of historical buildings as an alternative to demolition.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Gota de Leche}} * [http://gotadeleche.com/ Official website of Gota de Leche]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} '''Health in Indonesia''' is affected by [[air pollution|air quality]], disease, poverty and smoking. 29% of the population of Indonesia are under 15 years old, and only 5% are over 65. Life expectancy at birth is 70.8 years. It has been suggested that over a third of the children under 5 have stunted growth. More than 28 million live below the poverty line of US$17 a month and about half the population have incomes not much above it. The rate of smoking is the highest in the world - 76%{{cite book|last1=Ballas|first1=Dimitris|last2=Dorling|first2=Danny|last3=Hennig|first3=Benjamin|title=The Human Atlas of Europe|date=2017|publisher=Policy Press|location=Bristol|isbn=9781447313540|page=77}} and about 400,000 die each year from smoking related illnesses.{{cite book|last1=Britnell|first1=Mark|title=In Search of the Perfect Health System|date=2015|publisher=Palgrave|location=London|isbn=978-1-137-49661-4|page=46}} ==Life expectancy== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !Period !Life expectancy in
Years !Period !Life expectancy in
Years |- |1950–1955 |43.5 |1985–1990 |62.4 |- |1955–1960 |47.0 |1990–1995 |64.2 |- |1960–1965 |50.2 |1995–2000 |65.8 |- |1965–1970 |53.1 |2000–2005 |66.7 |- |1970–1975 |55.9 |2005–2010 |67.7 |- |1975–1980 |58.5 |2010–2015 |68.6 |- |1980–1985 |60.7 | | |} Source: United Nations{{cite web|title=World Population Prospects - Population Division - United Nations|periodical=|publisher=|url=https://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/DataQuery/|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2017-07-16|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=|pages=|quote=}} ==Water quality== Unsafe [[drinking water]] is a major cause of [[diarrhoea]], which is a major killer of young children in Indonesia.[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Indonesia.pdf Indonesia country profile]. [[Library of Congress]] [[Federal Research Division]] (December 2004). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].'' According to [[UNICEF]] diarrhoea caused by untreated drinking water contributed to the death of 31% of children between the age of 1 month to a year, and 25% of children between a year to 4 years old.{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/indonesia/A8-_E_Issue_Brief_Water_Sanitation_REV.pdf|title=IssueBriefs: Water, sanitation & hygiene|publisher=UNICEF Indonesia|date=October 2012|accessdate=4 February 2017}} ==Disease== [[Image:Polio worldwide 2005.png|thumb|In 2005 there were 303 reported cases of [[Poliomyelitis|polio]] in Indonesia.]] [[HIV/AIDS]] has posed a major public health threat since the early 1990s. In 2003 Indonesia ranked third among ASEAN nations in Southeast Asia, after [[Myanmar]] and [[Thailand]], with a 0.1 percent adult prevalence rate, 130,000 HIV/AIDS cases, and 2,400 deaths. In Jakarta it is estimated that 17 percent of prostitutes have contracted HIV/AIDS; in some parts of [[Papua (Indonesian province)|Papua]], it is thought that the rate of infection among village women who are not prostitutes may be as high as 26 percent. Three other health hazards facing Indonesia in 2004 were [[dengue fever]], [[dengue haemorrhagic fever]] (DHF) and [[avian influenza]]. All 30 provincial-level units were affected by dengue fever and DHF, according to the WHO. The outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (A/H5N1) in chickens and ducks in Indonesia was said to pose a significant threat to human health. By 2010, there were three [[malaria]] regions in Indonesia: [[Nusa Tenggara Barat]] with 20 cases per 1,000 citizens, [[Nusa Tenggara Timur]] with 20-50, and [[Maluku Islands|Maluku]] and [[Papua (province)|Papua]] with more than 50 cases per thousand. The medium endemicity in [[Sumatra]], [[Kalimantan]] and [[Sulawesi]], whereas low endemicity is in [[Java]] and [[Bali]] which almost 100 percent of malaria cases have been confirmed clear.{{cite news|last=Leksono|first=Ageng Wibowo|title=Malignant malaria still haunts Indonesia|url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/70567/malignant-malaria-still-haunts-indonesia|agency=[[Antara (news agency)|Antara]]|date=23 April 2011|accessdate=4 February 2017}} At 1990 malaria '''average''' incidence was 4.96 per 1,000 and declined to 1.96 per 1000 at 2010. The government is targeting to rid the country of malaria by 2030 and elimination means to achieve less than 1 incidence per 1,000 people.{{cite news|title=Govt to rid RI of malaria by 2030|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/04/26/govt-rid-ri-malaria-2030.html|work=[[The Jakarta Post]]|date=26 April 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427104339/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/04/26/govt-rid-ri-malaria-2030.html|archivedate=27 April 2011}} Diabetes is increasing at a rate of about 6% a year.{{cite book|last1=Britnell|first1=Mark|title=In Search of the Perfect Health System|date=2015|publisher=Palgrave|location=London|isbn=978-1-137-49661-4|page=49}} ==Air quality== [[1997 Southeast Asian haze]], [[2006 Southeast Asian haze]], [[2013 Southeast Asian haze]] and [[2015 Southeast Asian haze]] - In all countries affected by the smoke haze, an increase of acute health outcomes was observed. Health effects including emergency room visits due to respiratory symptoms such as [[asthma]], upper respiratory infection, decreased lung function as well as eye and skin irritation, were caused mainly by this particulate matter. ==Vaccination== Indonesia has routine vaccination to children below age 5 years as [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) recommendations including vaccination of [[Hepatitis B]] which has high prevalency in Indonesia. Almost all of the vaccines provided by [[Bio Farma]] which one of the 29 companies with a prequalification certificate from the WHO among 200 vaccine company in the world. It also has been exported to 110 countries in the world.{{cite news|last=Hitipeuw|first=Jimmy|title=Indonesian Company Exports Vaccines to 110 Countries|url=http://english.kompas.com/read/2011/03/10/06253496/Indonesian.Company.Exports.Vaccines.to.110.Countries|work=[[Kompas]]|agency=Antara|date=10 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713164325/http://english.kompas.com/read/2011/03/10/06253496/Indonesian.Company.Exports.Vaccines.to.110.Countries|archivedate=13 July 2011}} Bio Farma as a global vaccine producer will produce [[pentavalent vaccine]] ([[diphtheria]], [[pertussis]], [[tetanus]], [[hepatitis B]] and [[Influenzavirus B|haemophilus influanzae type B]] or HiB). In 2012 the GAVI (Global Alliance for Vaccine and Immunization) will donate 80 percent of the needs of pentavalent vaccine and in the third year government should self-fulfilment.{{cite news|title=Biofarma ready to produce new vaccines|url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/71328/biofarma-ready-to-produce-new-vaccines|accessdate=4 February 2017|agency=Antara|date=12 May 2011}} In June 2011, the third phase test of dengue vaccine involving 800 humans with ages of 2 and 14 years old have been held in 5 community health centre around [[Jakarta]] and will be conducted also in [[Bandung]], [[West Java]] and [[Denpasar]], [[Bali]] with 800 and 400 participants, respectively. The first test was performed on a limited number of soldiers and the second phase was conducted on a small number of children and if within the next 5 years the vaccine is found to be safe for humans, government will apply the dengue vaccine to public.{{cite news|last=Aditya|first=Andreas D.|title=Jakarta begins testing new dengue vaccine|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/06/08/jakarta-begins-testing-new-dengue-vaccine.html|work=The Jakarta Post|date=8 June 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608032152/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/06/08/jakarta-begins-testing-new-dengue-vaccine.html|archivedate=8 June 2011}} ==Maternal and child health care== [[File:Indonesian midwives.jpg|thumb|right|Newly certified midwives in [[South Sulawesi]], [[Indonesia]]]] The 2010 maternal mortality rate per 100,000 births for Indonesia is 240. This is compared with 228.6 in 2008 and 252.9 in 1990. The under 5 mortality rate, per 1,000 births is 41 and the neonatal mortality as a percentage of under 5's mortality is 49. In Indonesia the number of [[midwives]] per 1,000 live births is unavailable and the lifetime risk of death for pregnant women is 1 in 190.{{cite web|url=http://www.unfpa.org/sowmy/report/home.html|title=The State Of The World's Midwifery|publisher=United Nations Population Fund|accessdate=August 2011}} The 2012 maternal mortality rate per 100,000 live births is 359 deaths, a significant increased from 2010 data with 220 deaths and far from the MDGs goal of 102 deaths by the end of 2015. The main cause of deaths are severe post-natal bleeding due to lack of pregnancy regular control, although National Family Planning Coordination Board and the Central Statistics Agency data showed improvement from 93 percent of women received prenatal care in 2007 increased to 96 percent in 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/indonesia-still-haunted-by-high-number-of-maternal-and-post-natal-deaths/ |title=Indonesia Still Haunted by High Number of Maternal and Post-Natal Deaths |first=Basten |last=Gokkon |work=[[Jakarta Globe]] |date=29 January 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140130202316/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/indonesia-still-haunted-by-high-number-of-maternal-and-post-natal-deaths/ |archivedate=30 January 2014}} ==See also== {{portal|Indonesia}} * [[Healthcare in Indonesia]] * [[HIV/AIDS in Indonesia]] * [[Water supply and sanitation in Indonesia]] * [[Environmental issues in Indonesia]] * [[Smoking in Indonesia]] * [[Disability in Indonesia]] * ''[[Afflictions: Culture & Mental Illness in Indonesia]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * The State of the World's Midwifery - [http://www.unfpa.org/sowmy/resources/docs/country_info/profile/en_Indonesia_SoWMy_Profile.pdf Indonesia Country Profile] {{Indonesia topics}} {{Health care}} {{Asia topic|Health in}} [[Category:Health in Indonesia|*]]

The '''Hellenic Rescue Team''' (HRT; {{lang-el|Ελληνική Ομάδα Διάσωσης}} or Elliniki Omada Diasosis) is a [[Non-governmental organization|non-governmental organization]] of [[Search and Rescue]] that operates in [[Greece]]. It is run by volunteers and operating since 1978. Since 1994 it is run as an association. HRC is cooperating with the [[Greek Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] and the [[European Union]].<ref name=Concorde>{{cite web|url=http://www.concorde-project.eu/index.php/who-is-concorde/partners/hellenic-rescue-team| title= ''Hellenic Rescue Team''|work=Concorde-Project|date=3 September 2014|language=en|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> The Hellenic Rescue Team was awarded with the [[Nansen Refugee Award]] in 2016<ref name=UNHCR>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/news/stories/2016/9/57bc12e37/heeding-cries-help-lands-hellenic-rescue-team-2016-nansen-award.html| title= ''Heeding cries for help lands Hellenic Rescue Team 2016 Nansen Award''|work=[[UNHCR]]|date=6 September 2016|language=en|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> and Mother Teresa Award in 2017<ref name="motherTerezaAward">[http://www.balkaneu.com/mother-teresa-award-goes-to-the-hellenic-rescue-team/ "Mother Teresa" award goes to the Hellenic Rescue Team]</ref> for its role in the [[European migrant crisis|European refugee and migrant crisis]]. The headquarter of the organization is in Thessaloniki. Overall there are 34 divisions of HRT in Greece.<ref name="HRT">{{cite web|last1=Hellenic Rescue Team|title=Divisions|url=http://www.hrt.org.gr/divisions.en.aspx|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> The [[International Search and Rescue Advisory Group|United Nations International Search and Rescue Advisory Group]] has officially recognized HRT on the 23 of June 2005.<ref name="INSARG">{{cite web|last1=INSARG|title=USAR Directory|url=https://vosocc.unocha.org/USAR_Directory/USARTeamsByCountry.asp|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref>
HRT is also in continuous cooperation with both the [[OCHA]] (Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs), the Greek Ministry of foreign Affairs and [[ECHO (European Commission)|ECHO]] (European Community Humanitarian Office).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hellenic Aid|title=Εκδήλωση με θέμα «Επίτευξη της Ατζέντας 2030 και των Στόχων Βιώσιμης Ανάπτυξης (ΣΒΑ) - Ανταλλαγή Εμπειριών και Βέλτιστων Πρακτικών»,|url=http://hellenicaid.mfa.gr/|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> It also the only greek organization that is part of the International Mountain Rescue Federation (IKAR- CISA)<ref>{{cite web|last1=International Commission for Alpine Rescue|title=Members|url=http://www.alpine-rescue.org/xCMS5/WebObjects/nexus5.woa/wa/icar?menuid=1081|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> and the [[International Maritime Rescue Federation]] (IMRF). Furthermore it is also part of the International Rescue Dog Organization ([[International Rescue Dog Organisation|IRDO]]).<ref>{{cite web|last1=International Rescue Dog Organization|title=Member Organizations|url=http://www.iro-dogs.org/en/about-us/member-organisations|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> The Hellenic Rescue Team works closely with the Civil Protection Secretariat, the greek Coast Guard, the greek Air Force, greek Army Air Force, the Hellenic Navy Helicopters School, the Directorate of Transmission of Air Transport and the TENEF.
The organization has over 3.000 volunteers working for it. It carries out search and rescue operations in emergencies and disasters within Greece or in sea surrounding Greece. The staff and volunteers and scientifically and technically trained to carry out the missions.
==International Work and Recognition== The organization has provided aid in international emergency situations since 1999. The first international deployment was in the [[1999 İzmit earthquake|earthquakes of Turkey (1999)]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=IN News Greece|title=Ελλάδα|url=http://news.in.gr/greece/article/?aid=322857|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref>, Algeria (2003), Morocco (2004), Iran (2004) and Indonesia (2005) - where full equipment was sent for the operation of a pre-hospital care center for 10,000 people for two months - Pakistan (2005) and lastly the Lebanese crisis where it sent 23.5 tons of food and pharmaceutical products gathered through its network. The Greek Rescue Team also participated in the relieve efforts in the Haiti earthquake in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mega TV|title=H τέχνη που υπερβαίνει τα σύνορα|url=http://www.megatv.com/warzone/pages.asp?catid=16909|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> The HRT received the [[Nansen Refugee Award]] in 2016 for its rescue efforts in 2015 where the organizations saved over 2.500 people in the [[Aegean Sea|Aegean sea]]. During that year the organization undertook 1.035 rescue operations and additionally assisted over 7.000 people to safety<ref name=UNHCR>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/news/stories/2016/9/57bc12e37/heeding-cries-help-lands-hellenic-rescue-team-2016-nansen-award.html| title= ''Heeding cries for help lands Hellenic Rescue Team 2016 Nansen Award''|work=[[UNHCR]]|date=6 September 2016|language=en|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> In 2017 the organization received the Mother Teresa award from the "Harmony Foundation" based in [[Mumbai]], [[India]]. They received the award for their "heroic actions" during the migrant and refugee crisis.<ref name="motherTerezaAward" />
==Awards== * [[Nansen Refugee Award]], 2016.<ref name=UNHCR>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/news/stories/2016/9/57bc12e37/heeding-cries-help-lands-hellenic-rescue-team-2016-nansen-award.html| title= ''Heeding cries for help lands Hellenic Rescue Team 2016 Nansen Award''|work=[[UNHCR]]|date=6 September 2016|language=en|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> * Mother Teresa Award, 2017.<ref name="motherTerezaAward"/>
==External Links== * [http://www.hrt.org.gr Official website]
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Humanitarian aid organizations in Europe]] [[Category:Sea rescue organisations]] [[Category:Organizations based in Thessaloniki]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Greece]] [[Category:Nansen Refugee Award winners]] [[Category:1978 establishments in Greece]] [[Category:Mountain rescue]]

revision.text:
{{Taxobox | image = Kaposi's Sarcoma.jpg | image_caption = Kaposi's sarcoma | virus_group = i | ordo = ''[[Herpesvirales]]'' | familia = ''[[Herpesviridae]]'' | subfamilia = ''[[Gammaherpesvirinae]]'' | genus = ''[[Rhadinovirus]]'' | species = '''''Human herpesvirus 8''''' }} '''Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus''' ('''KSHV''') is the ninth known human [[herpesvirus]]; its formal name according to the [[International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses]] (ICTV) is '''HHV-8'''. Like other herpesviruses, its informal name (KSHV) is used interchangeably with its more formal ICTV name. This virus causes [[Kaposi's sarcoma]], a cancer commonly occurring in [[AIDS]] patients, as well as [[primary effusion lymphoma]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Cesarman | first1 = E. | last2 = Chang | first2 = Y. | last3 = Moore | first3 = P. S. | last4 = Said | first4 = J. W. | last5 = Knowles | first5 = D. M. | title = Kaposi's Sarcoma–Associated Herpesvirus-Like DNA Sequences in AIDS-Related Body-Cavity–Based Lymphomas | doi = 10.1056/NEJM199505043321802 | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 332 | issue = 18 | pages = 1186–1191 | year = 1995 | pmid = 7700311 | pmc = }} [[HHV-8-associated MCD|HHV-8-associated multicentric Castleman's disease]] and [[KSHV inflammatory cytokine syndrome]]. It is one of seven currently known human cancer viruses, or [[oncovirus]]es.{{Cite journal | last1 = Boshoff | first1 = C. | last2 = Weiss | first2 = R. | doi = 10.1038/nrc797 | title = Aids-related malignancies | journal = Nature Reviews Cancer | volume = 2 | issue = 5 | pages = 373–382 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12044013 | pmc = }} ==History== In 1872, [[Moritz Kaposi]] described a blood vessel tumor{{cite journal |last=Kaposi |first=M |year=1872 |title=Idiopathisches multiples Pigmentsarkom der Haut |journal=Archiv für Dermatologie und Syphilis |volume=4 |issue= 2|pages=265–273 | url= |accessdate= |doi=10.1007/BF01830024}}
Translated in {{cite journal |author=Kaposi |first=M |title=Idiopathic multiple pigmented sarcoma of the skin |journal=CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians |volume=32 |issue=6 |pages=342–347 |year=2008 |doi=10.3322/canjclin.32.6.342}} (originally called "idiopathic multiple pigmented sarcoma of the skin") that has since been eponymously named [[Kaposi's sarcoma]] (KS). KS was at first thought to be an uncommon tumor of Jewish and Mediterranean populations until it was later determined to be extremely common throughout sub-Saharan African populations. This led to the first suggestions in the 1950s that this tumor might be caused by a virus. With the onset of the [[AIDS]] epidemic in the early 1980s, there was a sudden resurgence of KS affecting primarily gay and bisexual AIDS patients,with up to 50% of reported AIDS patients having this tumor—an extraordinary rate of cancer predisposition. Careful analysis of epidemiologic data by Valerie Beral, Thomas Peterman and Harold Jaffe,{{cite journal |vauthors=Beral V, Peterman TA, Berkelman RL, Jaffe HW |title=Kaposi's sarcoma among persons with AIDS: a sexually transmitted infection? |journal=Lancet |volume=335 |issue=8682 |pages=123–8 |year=1990 |pmid=1967430 |doi=10.1016/0140-6736(90)90001-L|url=https://zenodo.org/record/1258307 |type=Submitted manuscript }} led these investigators to propose that KS is caused by an unknown sexually transmitted virus that rarely causes tumors unless the host becomes [[immunosuppressed]], as in AIDS. [[Image:Kaposi sarcoma high mag.jpg|thumb|right|[[Micrograph]] of Kaposi sarcoma. [[H&E stain]].]] As early as 1984, scientists reported seeing herpesvirus-like structures in KS tumors examined under [[electron microscopy]]. Scientists had been searching for the agent causing KS, and over 20 agents were proposed as the possible cause, including [[cytomegalovirus]] and [[HIV]] itself. The pathogen was ultimately identified in 1994 by [[Yuan Chang]] and [[Patrick S. Moore]], a wife and husband team at [[Columbia University]], through the isolation of DNA fragments from a [[herpesvirus]] found in a KS tumor in an AIDS patient.{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.7997879 | last1 = Chang | first1 = Y. | last2 = Cesarman | first2 = E. | last3 = Pessin | first3 = M. S. | last4 = Lee | first4 = F. | last5 = Culpepper | first5 = J. | last6 = Knowles | first6 = D. M. | last7 = Moore | first7 = P. S. | title = Identification of herpesvirus-like DNA sequences in AIDS-associated Kaposi's sarcoma | journal = Science | volume = 266 | issue = 5192 | pages = 1865–1869 | year = 1994 | pmid = 7997879}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Moore PS, Chang Y |title=Detection of herpesvirus-like DNA sequences in Kaposi's sarcoma in patients with and without HIV infection |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=332 |issue=18 |pages=1181–5 |date=May 1995 |pmid=7700310 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199505043321801}}{{Cite journal | last1 = Antman | first1 = K. | last2 = Chang | first2 = Y. | doi = 10.1056/NEJM200004063421407 | title = Kaposi's Sarcoma | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 342 | issue = 14 | pages = 1027–1038 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10749966| pmc = }} Chang and Moore used [[representational difference analysis]], or RDA, to find KSHV by comparing KS tumor tissue from an AIDS patient to his own unaffected tissue. The idea behind this experiment was that if a virus causes KS, the genomic DNA in the two samples should be precisely identical except for DNA belonging to the virus. In their initial RDA experiment, they isolated two small DNA fragments that represented less than 1% of the actual viral genome. These fragments were similar (but still distinct from) the known herpevirus sequences, indicating the presence of a new virus. Starting from these fragments, this research team was then able to sequence the entire genome of the virus less than two years later. The discovery of this [[herpesvirus]] sparked considerable controversy and scientific in-fighting until sufficient data had been collected to show that indeed KSHV was the causative agent of Kaposi's sarcoma.{{cite journal |vauthors=Boshoff C, Weiss RA |title=Addressing Controversies Over Kaposi's Sarcoma |journal=Journal of the National Cancer Institute |volume=92 |issue=9 |pages=677–679 |pmid=10793096 |doi=10.1093/jnci/92.9.677 |date=May 2000}} The virus is now known to be a widespread infection of people living in sub-Saharan Africa; intermediate levels of infection occur in Mediterranean populations (including Israel, Saudi Arabia, Italy and Greece) and low levels of infection occur in most Northern European and North American populations. Gay and bi-sexual men are more susceptible to infection (through still unknown routes of sexual transmission) whereas the virus is transmitted through non-sexual routes in developing countries.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} ==Virology== KSHV is a [[herpesvirus]], and is a large double-stranded DNA virus with a protein covering that packages its nucleic acids, called the [[capsid]], which is then surrounded by an amorphous protein layer called the [[viral tegument|tegument]], and finally enclosed in a lipid envelope derived in part from the cell membrane. KSHV has a [[genome]] which is approximately 165,000 nucleic acid bases in length. KSHV is a [[rhadinovirus]], and is remarkable since it has stolen numerous genes from host cells including genes that encode for [[Complement system|complement]]-binding protein, [[Interleukin 6|IL-6]], [[BCL-2]], [[cyclin]]-D, a [[G protein-coupled receptor]], [[interferon regulatory factor]] and Flice inhibitory protein ([[CFLAR|FLIP]]), as well as DNA synthesis proteins including [[dihydrofolate reductase]], [[thymidine kinase]], [[thymidylate synthetase]], DNA [[polymerase]] and many others. While no other human tumor virus possesses these same genes, other tumor viruses target the same cellular pathways illustrating that at a basic level, all tumor viruses appear to attack the same cellular control pathways, so-called tumor suppressor pathways.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} After infection, the virus enters into lymphocytes via [[macropinosome]]s where it remains in a latent ("quiet") state expressing the viral latency-associated nuclear antigen, [[LANA]]. Crucial for the Entry of the KSHV {{Cite journal|last=Kumar|first=Binod|last2=Chandran|first2=Bala|date=11 14, 2016|title=KSHV Entry and Trafficking in Target Cells-Hijacking of Cell Signal Pathways, Actin and Membrane Dynamics|journal=Viruses|volume=8|issue=11|pages=305|doi=10.3390/v8110305|issn=1999-4915|pmc=5127019|pmid=27854239}} is the [[EPH receptor A2]]{{cite journal |vauthors=Neipel F, Fleckenstein B, Hahn A, etal |title=The ephrin receptor tyrosine kinase A2 is a cellular receptor for Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus|journal=Nature Medicine |volume=18 |issue=6 |pages=961–968 |date=June 2012 |doi=10.1038/nm.2805|pmid=22635007|pmc=3645317 }} , Hrs{{Cite journal|last=Veettil|first=Mohanan Valiya|last2=Kumar|first2=Binod|last3=Ansari|first3=Mairaj Ahmed|last4=Dutta|first4=Dipanjan|last5=Iqbal|first5=Jawed|last6=Gjyshi|first6=Olsi|last7=Bottero|first7=Virginie|last8=Chandran|first8=Bala|date=2016-4|title=ESCRT-0 Component Hrs Promotes Macropinocytosis of Kaposi's Sarcoma-Associated Herpesvirus in Human Dermal Microvascular Endothelial Cells|journal=Journal of Virology|volume=90|issue=8|pages=3860–3872|doi=10.1128/JVI.02704-15|issn=1098-5514|pmc=4810545|pmid=26819309}} , [[TSG101]]{{Cite journal|last=Kumar|first=Binod|last2=Dutta|first2=Dipanjan|last3=Iqbal|first3=Jawed|last4=Ansari|first4=Mairaj Ahmed|last5=Roy|first5=Arunava|last6=Chikoti|first6=Leela|last7=Pisano|first7=Gina|last8=Veettil|first8=Mohanan Valiya|last9=Chandran|first9=Bala|date=2016-10|title=ESCRT-I Protein Tsg101 Plays a Role in the Post-macropinocytic Trafficking and Infection of Endothelial Cells by Kaposi's Sarcoma-Associated Herpesvirus|journal=PLoS Pathogens|volume=12|issue=10|pages=e1005960|doi=10.1371/journal.ppat.1005960|issn=1553-7374|pmc=5072609|pmid=27764233}} and a few [[Integrin]]s, whose identity has yet to be confirmed.{{cite journal |vauthors=Campadelli-Fiume G, Collins-McMillen D etal |title=Integrins as Herpersvirus Receptors and Mediators of the Host Signalosome|journal=Reviews in Advance |date=July 2016 |doi=10.1146/annurev-virology-110615-035618 |pmid=27501260|volume=3 |issue=1|pages=215–236}} The virus exists as a circular piece of DNA called an [[plasmid#Episomes|episome]] and uses the cellular replication machinery to replicate itself. The viral episome is chromatinized upon entry into the host cell nucleus.{{cite journal |vauthors=Purushothaman, etal |title=KSHV Genome Replication and Maintenance |journal=Frontiers in Microbiology|volume=7 |pages=54 |date=February 2016 |doi=10.3389/fmicb.2016.00054|pmid=26870016 |pmc=4740845 }} LANA tethers the viral DNA to cellular chromosomes, inhibits [[p53]] and [[retinoblastoma protein]] and suppresses viral genes needed for full virus production and assembly ("lytic replication"). Various signals such as inflammation may provoke the virus to enter into lytic replication. When lytic replication occurs, the viral episome starts replicating itself in the form of linear DNA molecules that are packaged into virus particles which are expelled from the cell, to infect new cells or to be transmitted to a new host. When the virus enters into lytic replication, thousands of virus particles can be made from a single cell, which usually results in death of the infected cell. The viral genome consists of a ~145 kbase long unique region, encoding all of expressed viral genes, which is flanked by ~20-30 kbases of terminal repeat sequences.{{cite journal |vauthors=Russo JJ, Bohenzky RA, Chien MC, etal |title=Nucleotide sequence of the Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (HHV8) |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |volume=93 |issue=25 |pages=14862–7 |date=December 1996 |pmid=8962146 |pmc=26227 |doi=10.1073/pnas.93.25.14862}} Each terminal repeat unit is 801 bp in length, has 85% G+C content and is oriented in a repetitive head-to-tail fashion. During latency, the virus genome depends on the host replication machinery and replicates as closed circular episome ("plasmid") using sequences within the terminal repeats as a replication origin. When the virus reactivates into lytic replication, it is believed that the virus genome is replicated as a continuous linear molecule off from an episome (so called rolling circle model). As each unit genome is replicated, it is cut within the terminal repeat region, and then packaged into a virus particle (virion). The virus then becomes enveloped with a lipid membrane as it transits the nucleus and the cytoplasm to exit the cell. Thus, whereas KSHV genome is circular in the nucleus of latently infected cells, it is packaged into infectious viruses as a linear molecule. Once the virus newly infects a cell, the lipid membrane is shed and the virion travels to the nucleus. The viral genome is released where it recircularizes through a poorly understood process that appears to involve [[homologous recombination]]. The primary viral protein responsible for the switch between latent and lytic replication is known as the ORF50 Replication Transactivation Activator (RTA). When cell signaling conditions activate the generation of RTA, it in turn activates synthesis of a stereotypic cascade of secondary and tertiary viral proteins that ultimately make components of the virus capsid and also the DNA synthesis enzymes required to replicate the virus genome.{{cite journal |vauthors=Bu W, Palmeri D, Krishnan R, etal |title=Identification of Direct Transcriptional Targets of the Kaposi's Sarcoma-Associated Herpesvirus Rta Lytic Switch Protein by Conditional Nuclear Localization |journal=Journal of Virology |volume=82 |issue=21 |pages=10709–23 |date=November 2008 |pmid=18715905 |pmc=2573185 |doi=10.1128/JVI.01012-08}} ==Pathophysiology== The mechanisms by which the virus is contracted are not well understood. Healthy individuals can be infected with the virus and show no signs or symptoms, due to the immune system's ability to keep the infection in check. Infection is of particular concern to the [[immunodeficiency|immunocompromised]]. Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, AIDS patients, and organ transplant patients are all at a high risk of showing signs of infection. Infection with this virus is thought to be lifelong, but a healthy immune system will keep the virus in check. Many people infected with KSHV will never show any symptoms. Kaposi's sarcoma occurs when someone who has been infected with KSHV becomes immunocompromised due to AIDS, medical treatment, or very rarely aging. KSHV is a known causative agent of four diseases:{{cite journal|last1=Goncalves|first1=Priscila H.|last2=Ziegelbauer|first2=Joseph|last3=Uldrick|first3=Thomas S.|last4=Yarchoan|first4=Robert|title=Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus-associated cancers and related diseases|journal=Curr Opin HIV AIDS|date=2017|volume=12|issue=1|pages=47–56|doi=10.1097/COH.0000000000000330|pmid=27662501|url=https://zenodo.org/record/1234919}} * [[Kaposi's sarcoma]] – an angioproliferative tumor that can involve skin (most often), lymph nodes, or viscera, * [[HHV-8-associated MCD|HHV-8-associated multicentric Castleman's disease]] – a [[lymphoproliferative disorder]], * [[Primary effusion lymphoma]] – KSHV-associated aggressive mature monoclonal B-cell lymphoma, * [[KSHV inflammatory cytokine syndrome]] – a syndrome with MCD-like symptoms but without associated pathology. ==Epidemiology== The seroprevalence of HHV-8 varies significantly geographically and infection rates in northern European, southeast Asian, and Caribbean countries are between 2-4%,{{cite journal|last1=Zhang|first1=Tiejun|last2=Wang|first2=Linding|title=Epidemiology of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated Herpesvirus in Asia: Challenges and Opportunities|journal=Journal of Medical Virology|year=2016|issn=0146-6615|doi=10.1002/jmv.24662|pmid=27531516|volume=89|issue=4|pages=563–570}} in Mediterranean countries at approximately 10%, and in sub-Saharan African countries at approximately 40%.{{Cite journal | pmid = 10343069| year = 1999| author1 = Chatlynne| first1 = L. G.| title = Seroepidemiology of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV)| journal = Seminars in Cancer Biology| volume = 9| issue = 3| pages = 175–85| last2 = Ablashi| first2 = D. V.| doi = 10.1006/scbi.1998.0089}} In South America, infection rates are low in general but are high among [[Amerindian]]s.{{Cite journal | pmid = 16095940| year = 2005| author1 = Mohanna| first1 = S| title = Epidemiology and clinical characteristics of classic Kaposi's sarcoma, seroprevalence, and variants of human herpesvirus 8 in South America: A critical review of an old disease| journal = International Journal of Infectious Diseases| volume = 9| issue = 5| pages = 239–50| last2 = Maco| first2 = V| last3 = Bravo| first3 = F| last4 = Gotuzzo| first4 = E| doi = 10.1016/j.ijid.2005.02.004}} Even within individual countries, significant variation can be observed across different regions, with infection rates of about 19.2% in [[Xinjiang]] compared to about 9.5% in [[Hubei]], China.{{Cite journal | pmid = 19551832| pmc = 2755560| year = 2009| author1 = Fu| first1 = B| title = Seroprevalence of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus and risk factors in Xinjiang, China| journal = Journal of Medical Virology| volume = 81| issue = 8| pages = 1422–31| last2 = Sun| first2 = F| last3 = Li| first3 = B| last4 = Yang| first4 = L| last5 = Zeng| first5 = Y| last6 = Sun| first6 = X| last7 = Xu| first7 = F| last8 = Rayner| first8 = S| last9 = Guadalupe| first9 = M| last10 = Gao| first10 = S. J.| last11 = Wang| first11 = L| doi = 10.1002/jmv.21550}} Although seroprevalence has been consistently shown to increase with age in a linear manner,{{Cite journal | pmid = 19777527| pmc = 2784645| year = 2009| author1 = Pelser| first1 = C| title = Socio-economic and other correlates of Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus seroprevalence among older adults in Sicily| journal = Journal of Medical Virology| volume = 81| issue = 11| pages = 1938–44| last2 = Vitale| first2 = F| last3 = Whitby| first3 = D| last4 = Graubard| first4 = B. I.| last5 = Messina| first5 = A| last6 = Gafà| first6 = L| last7 = Brown| first7 = E. E.| last8 = Anderson| first8 = L. A.| last9 = Romano| first9 = N| last10 = Lauria| first10 = C| last11 = Goedert| first11 = J. J.| doi = 10.1002/jmv.21589}}{{Cite journal | pmid = 22168313| pmc = 3266657| year = 2011| author1 = Wang| first1 = H| title = Seroprevalence and risk factors of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus infection among the general Uygur population from south and north region of Xinjiang, China| journal = Virology Journal| volume = 8| pages = 539| last2 = Liu| first2 = J| last3 = Dilimulati| last4 = Li| first4 = L| last5 = Ren| first5 = Z| last6 = Wen| first6 = H| last7 = Wang| first7 = X| doi = 10.1186/1743-422X-8-539}}{{Cite journal | pmid = 9792393| year = 1998| author1 = Olsen| first1 = S. J.| title = Increasing Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus seroprevalence with age in a highly Kaposi's sarcoma endemic region, Zambia in 1985| journal = AIDS| volume = 12| issue = 14| pages = 1921–5| last2 = Chang| first2 = Y| last3 = Moore| first3 = P. S.| last4 = Biggar| first4 = R. J.| last5 = Melbye| first5 = M| doi=10.1097/00002030-199814000-00024}} countries with high infection rates may see higher seroprevalence in younger age groups.{{Cite journal | pmid = 11234789| year = 2001| author1 = Wawer| first1 = M. J.| title = Prevalence of Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus compared with selected sexually transmitted diseases in adolescents and young adults in rural Rakai District, Uganda| journal = Sexually Transmitted Diseases| volume = 28| issue = 2| pages = 77–81| last2 = Eng| first2 = S. M.| last3 = Serwadda| first3 = D| last4 = Sewankambo| first4 = N. K.| last5 = Kiwanuka| first5 = N| last6 = Li| first6 = C| last7 = Gray| first7 = R. H.| doi=10.1097/00007435-200102000-00003}} Educational level has shown an inverse correlation with infection rates. Individuals infected with HIV-1 or genital warts are generally more likely to be co-infected with HHV-8.{{Cite journal | pmid = 15543582| year = 2005| author1 = Klaskala| first1 = W| title = Epidemiological characteristics of human herpesvirus-8 infection in a large population of antenatal women in Zambia| journal = Journal of Medical Virology| volume = 75| issue = 1| pages = 93–100| last2 = Brayfield| first2 = B. P.| last3 = Kankasa| first3 = C| last4 = Bhat| first4 = G| last5 = West| first5 = J. T.| last6 = Mitchell| first6 = C. D.| last7 = Wood| first7 = C| doi = 10.1002/jmv.20242| url = http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1144&context=virologypub}}{{Cite journal | pmid = 18515794| pmc = 2727264| year = 2008| author1 = Minhas| first1 = V| title = Early childhood infection by human herpesvirus 8 in Zambia and the role of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 coinfection in a highly endemic area| journal = American Journal of Epidemiology| volume = 168| issue = 3| pages = 311–20| last2 = Crabtree| first2 = K. L.| last3 = Chao| first3 = A| last4 = m'Soka| first4 = T. J.| last5 = Kankasa| first5 = C| last6 = Bulterys| first6 = M| last7 = Mitchell| first7 = C. D.| last8 = Wood| first8 = C| doi = 10.1093/aje/kwn125}} In countries with low seroprevalence, HHV-8 is primarily limited to AIDS and KS patients.{{Cite journal | pmid = 15231079| year = 2004| author1 = Kourí| first1 = V| title = Seroprevalence of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus in various populations in Cuba| journal = Revista Panamericana de Salud Publica = Pan American Journal of Public Health| volume = 15| issue = 5| pages = 320–5| last2 = Eng| first2 = S. M.| last3 = Rodríguez| first3 = M. E.| last4 = Resik| first4 = S| last5 = Orraca| first5 = O| last6 = Moore| first6 = P. S.| last7 = Chang| first7 = Y| doi=10.1590/s1020-49892004000500006}} In countries with high seroprevalence, infection is frequent in childhood,{{Cite journal | pmid = 10855768| year = 2000| author1 = Schulz| first1 = T. F.| title = Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (human herpesvirus 8): Epidemiology and pathogenesis| journal = The Journal of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy| volume = 45 Suppl T3| issue = 90004| pages = 15–27| doi=10.1093/jac/45.suppl_4.15}} indicating a likely [[Vertically transmitted infection|mother-to-child transmission]].{{Cite journal | pmid = 12599072| year = 2003| author1 = Brayfield| first1 = B. P.| title = Postnatal human herpesvirus 8 and human immunodeficiency virus type 1 infection in mothers and infants from Zambia| journal = The Journal of Infectious Diseases| volume = 187| issue = 4| pages = 559–68| last2 = Phiri| first2 = S| last3 = Kankasa| first3 = C| last4 = Muyanga| first4 = J| last5 = Mantina| first5 = H| last6 = Kwenda| first6 = G| last7 = West| first7 = J. T.| last8 = Bhat| first8 = G| last9 = Marx| first9 = D. B.| last10 = Klaskala| first10 = W| last11 = Mitchell| first11 = C. D.| last12 = Wood| first12 = C| doi = 10.1086/367985}} In a [[Zambia]]n survey, all children with KS had mothers who were positive for HHV-8, whereas not all children whose mothers had KS were HHV-8 positive.{{Cite journal | pmid = 9815235| year = 1998| author1 = He| first1 = J| title = Seroprevalence of human herpesvirus 8 among Zambian women of childbearing age without Kaposi's sarcoma (KS) and mother-child pairs with KS| journal = The Journal of Infectious Diseases| volume = 178| issue = 6| pages = 1787–90| last2 = Bhat| first2 = G| last3 = Kankasa| first3 = C| last4 = Chintu| first4 = C| last5 = Mitchell| first5 = C| last6 = Duan| first6 = W| last7 = Wood| first7 = C| doi=10.1086/314512}} In another Zambian survey, 13.8% of children were seropositive for HHV-8 by age 4. Seroprevalence has not been shown to vary significantly because of gender or marital status. ==Evolution== The [[most recent common ancestor]] of this virus in the Mediterranean, Iran, and Xinjiang, China, has been estimated to have evolved 29,872 years (95% highest probability density 26,851-32,760 years) ago.Liu Z, Fang Q, Zuo J, Minhas V, Wood C, He N, Zhang T (2017) Was Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus introduced into China via the ancient Silk Road? An evolutionary perspective. Arch Virol the most recent common ancestor for viruses isolated in Xinjiang was 2037 years (95% highest probability density 1843–2229 years) ago. Given the historical links between the Mediterranean and Xinjiang during the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] period it seems likely that this virus was introduced to Xinjiang along the [[Silk Road]]. The mutation rate was estimated to be 3.44 × 10−6 substitutions per site per year (95% highest probability density 2.26 × 10-6 to 4.71 × 10−6). However, the global distribution of different genotypes of KSHV and the potential transmission path need further studies. ==Prevention== Since persons infected with KSHV will asymptomatically give the virus, caution should be used by [[sex partner]]s in having [[unprotected sex]] and activities where saliva might be shared during sexual activity. Prudent advice is to use [[condom]]s when needed and avoid [[deep kissing]] with partners with KSHV and HIV infections or whose status is unknown. Blood tests to detect antibodies to virus exist. ==Treatment== Kaposi's sarcoma is usually a localized tumor that can be treated either surgically or through local irradiation. Chemotherapy with drugs such as liposomal [[anthracycline]]s or [[paclitaxel]] may be used, particularly for invasive disease. Antiviral drugs, such as [[ganciclovir]], that target the replication of herpesviruses such as KSHV have been used to successfully prevent development of Kaposi's sarcoma,{{cite journal |vauthors=Martin DF, Kuppermann BD, Wolitz RA, Palestine AG, Li H, Robinson CA |title=Oral ganciclovir for patients with cytomegalovirus retinitis treated with a ganciclovir implant. Roche Ganciclovir Study Group |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=340 |issue=14 |pages=1063–70 |date=April 1999 |pmid=10194235 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199904083401402}} although once the tumor develops these drugs are of little or no use. For patients with AIDS-KS, the most effective therapy is [[Antiretroviral drug|highly active antiretroviral therapy]] to reduce HIV infection.{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/ncponc0253 | last1 = Yarchoan | first1 = R. | last2 = Tosato | first2 = G. | last3 = Little | first3 = R. F. | title = Therapy insight: AIDS-related malignancies--the influence of antiviral therapy on pathogenesis and management | journal = Nature Clinical Practice Oncology | volume = 2 | issue = 8 | pages = 406–415; quiz 415 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16130937| url = https://zenodo.org/record/1233371 }} AIDS patients receiving adequate anti-HIV treatment may have up to a 90% reduction in Kaposi's sarcoma occurrence. == KSHV genes == KSHV encodes for ~90 genes and multiple non-coding RNAs, such as microRNAs.{{cite journal | vauthors = Samols MA, Hu J, Skalsky RL, Renne R | title = Cloning and identification of a microRNA cluster within the latency-associated region of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus | journal = Journal of Virology | volume = 79 | issue = 14 | pages = 9301–5 | date = Jul 2005 | pmid = 15994824 | doi = 10.1128/JVI.79.14.9301-9305.2005 | pmc=1168752}} The "ORF" genes are named based on genome position of the homologous genes in the first rhadinovirus described, herpesvirus saimiri. The "K" genes are unique to KSHV, Some KSHV genes have well-characterized functions, while others remain uncharacterized. ORF2 – [[dihydrofolate reductase]] ORF8 – gB – envelope [[glycoprotein]] involved in viral entry ORF9 – Pol8 – [[DNA polymerase]] required for viral DNA replication ORF10 – regulates RNA export and responses to type I IFNs ORF16 – v[[Bcl2]] ORF18, ORF24, ORF30, ORF31, ORF34, ORF66 – viral transcription factors required for the expression of late genes ORF21 – vTK – [[thymidine kinase]] ORF22 – gH – envelope [[glycoprotein]] involved in viral entry ORF23 – uncharacterized ORF25, ORF26 and ORF65 – [[capsid]] proteins ORF33 – involved in viral particle formation ORF34 – unclear function ORF35 – unclear function, mutant does not express early viral genes ORF36 – vPK – viral protein kinase with multiple roles in replication cycle ORF37 – SOX – dual function protein – [[Deoxyribonuclease|DNase]] activity required for genome packaging and [[Ribonuclease|RNase]] activity regulates host gene expression ORF38 – involved in viral particle formation ORF39 – gM – envelope [[glycoprotein]] ORF40 and ORF41 – [[helicase]] and [[primase]] – DNA replication ORF42 – uncharacterized ORF45 - [[Viral tegument|tegument]] protein, interacts with p90 ribosomal S6 kinases (RSKs) to modulate the ERK/RSK [[MAPK/ERK pathway|MAPK]] signaling pathway ORF47 – gL – envelope glycoprotein involved in viral entry ORF49 – may be required for viral gene expression ORF50 – RTA, replication and transcription activator – the major transcription factor driving lytic KSHV reactivation ORF52 – KicGAS – [[Viral tegument|tegument]] protein required for formation of virions and inhibition of [[CGAS–STING cytosolic DNA sensing pathway|cGAS]] ORF53 – gN – envelope glycoprotein ORF55 – uncharacterized ORF57 – MTA – regulates RNA stability, export and translation of viral genes ORF59 – PF–8 – polymerase processivity factor, accessory subunit of viral DNA polymerase ORF67 and ORF69 – nuclear egress ORF70 – [[thymidylate synthase]] ORF72 – v[[Cyclin]] ORF73 – [[LANA]], latency-associated nuclear antigen– tethers genome to chromosome during latency, also regulates host gene expression. A cytoplasmic form of LANA may inhibit activation of immune responses. ORF74 – vGPCR ORF75 – FGARAT PAN, [[polyadenylated]] nuclear [[RNA]] – non–coding linear and circular RNAs [[miRNA]]s (mirKs) – viral microRNAs expressed during latency to regulate proliferation and cell death K1 – involved in oncogenesis K3 and K5 – [[ubiquitin]] [[E3 ligase]]s – regulate antigen presentation K4 – vCCL2 – [[chemokine]] K4.1 – vCCL3 – [[chemokine]] K8 – transcriptional repressor – modulates chromatin K8.1 – envelope [[glycoprotein]] K9 – v[[Interferon Regulatory Factor|IRF]]1, viral [[interferon regulatory factor]] 1 K10 – v[[Interferon Regulatory Factor|IRF]]4. A circular RNA ([[circRNA]]) is also generated from this [[Locus (genetics)|locus]]. K10.5 – vIRF3/LANA2 – expressed during latency in [[B cell]]s K11 – v[[Interferon Regulatory Factor|IRF]]2 K12 – kaposin K13 – v[[CFLAR|FLIP]] ==See also== *[[Oncovirus]] (cancer virus) ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |author=Edelman DC |title=Human herpesvirus 8 – A novel human pathogen |journal=Virology Journal |volume=2 |issue= |pages=78 |year=2005 |pmid=16138925 |pmc=1243244 |doi=10.1186/1743-422X-2-78}} ==External links== *[http://hivinsite.ucsf.edu/InSite?page=kbr-06-02-01 Human Herpesvirus-8: Related Resources] HIV InSite {{STD/STI}} {{Viral cutaneous conditions}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q983850}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kaposi's Sarcoma-Associated Herpesvirus}} [[Category:Gammaherpesvirinae]] [[Category:Sexually transmitted diseases and infections]] [[Category:Infectious causes of cancer]] [[Category:IARC Group 1 carcinogens]]

{{short description|South Korean personal care and cosmetics producer}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox company | name =LG Household & Health Care Ltd. | logo = LG Household & Health Care logo (english).svg | logo_size = 200px | type = [[Public company|Public]] | caption = |native_name = 주식회사 LG생활건강 |native_name_lang = ko |romanized_name = ''Jusikhoesa LG (El-Ji) Saenghwalgeongang'' | traded_as = {{Kse|051900}} | foundation = {{Start date|5 January 1947}} (as Lucky Chemical) | founder = {{Plainlist| Koo In-Hwoi }} | location = [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Suk Y. Cha(Vice Chairman and CEO) | industry = [[Fast-moving consumer goods|Consumer goods]] | products = Cosmetics, Household Goods, Beverages | brands = | revenue = [[South Korean won|KRW]] 4,677 billion (2014)<ref name=10K>{{cite web|url=http://www.lgcare.com/global/ir/audit_report.jsp|title=LG Household & Health Care 2014 Auditor's report|publisher=LG Household & Health Care|accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref> | operating_income = [[South Korean won|KRW]] 511 billion (2014)<ref name=10K/> | net_income = [[South Korean won|KRW]] 355 billion (2014)<ref name=10K/> | assets = [[South Korean won|KRW]] 3,828 billion (2014)<ref name=10K/> | equity = [[South Korean won|KRW]] 1,709 billion (2014)<ref name=10K/> | parent = [[LG Corporation]] | subsid = [[The Face Shop]] | num_employees = 9,566 (2014)<ref name=10K/> | homepage = {{URL|lgcare.com/global}} }}
'''LG Household & Health Care''' is a major [[South Korea]]n consumer goods company that manages [[cosmetics]], [[household goods]], and [[beverages]] business.
==Summary==
===History=== Founded in 1947, Koo In-Hwoi (Founder of LG Corp) established Lucky Chemical Industrial Corp, and launched "Lucky Cream," the very first cosmetics product in Korea. In 1954, the company also launched Korea’s first toothpaste brand, ‘Lucky Toothpaste’. In February 1995, the company changed its name to [[LG Chemical]] Ltd. In April 2001, LG Household & Health Care spun off from [[LG Chemical]], and was listed on the Korean Stock Exchange.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://localbusinessreports.net/lg-household-health-care-leading-way-cosmetics/ |title=LG Household & Health Care: Leading the Way in Cosmetics |access-date=November 18, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119023714/http://localbusinessreports.net/lg-household-health-care-leading-way-cosmetics/ |archive-date=November 19, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Since current CEO & Vice Chairman, Suk Y. Cha joined the company in 2005, the business made a successful turnaround, and the company’s growth was further driven by strategic M&As.<ref>[http://khnews.kheraldm.com/view.php?ud=20141208000888&md=20141208211421_BL Cha’s success reveals secret of CEO longevity]</ref> Currently, LG Household & Health Care is expanding its cosmetics and personal care business into global market.<ref>[http://khnews.kheraldm.com/view.php?ud=20150316001020&md=20150317003306_BL LG’s cosmetics unit bets big on Chinese market]</ref>
===M&A=== When LG Household & Health Care was established, there were only two business divisions of [[cosmetics]] and [[household goods]]. From the acquisition of [[Coca-Cola]] Beverage(former Coca-Cola Korea Bottling Co., Ltd) in 2007, the company completed its current business structure of [[cosmetics]], [[household goods]], and [[beverages]]. Currently, LG Household & Health Care is an exclusive manufacturer and distributor of [[Coca-Cola]] brand products in Korea.<ref>[http://www.lgcare.com/global/news/press/view.jsp?seq=82&title= Acquisition of CCKBC Finalized]</ref> In 2009, the company acquired Diamond Water Co., Ltd to strengthen its drinking water business, and in 2011, the company acquired Haitai Beverage Co., Ltd, the third largest beverages company in Korea at the time.<ref>[http://www.lgcare.com/global/news/press/view.jsp?seq=106&title= LG HH Announces Takeover of Haitai Beverage]</ref>
Since 2005, cosmetics business made a successful turnaround through new high-end brand launches including ‘The History of Whoo’, ‘SU:M37’, and ‘belif’. In 2010, the company acquired low-end cosmetics brandshop, ‘[[TheFaceShop]]’, and a complete cosmetics product portfolio consisting of high-end, mid-end, to low-end was achieved.<ref>[http://www.lgcare.com/global/news/press/view.jsp?seq=93&title= LG H&H Takes over Korea’s No. 3 Cosmetics Brand]</ref> In 2012, LG Household & Health Care acquired cosmetics brand, ‘Violet Dream’ (former VOV) to strengthen its color cosmetics business.<ref>[http://www.lgcare.com/global/news/press/view.jsp?seq=120&title= LG H&H Concludes an Agreement to Acquire VOV]</ref> In 2014, the company acquired local cosmeceutical firm, CNP Cosmetics Co., Ltd, in order to expand into newly growing cosmeceutical category.<ref>[http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/business/2014/10/22/53/0501000000AEN20141022008100320F.html LG Household to acquire local cosmeceuticals maker CNP Cosmetics ]</ref>
==Business Division==
===Cosmetics=== LG Household & Health Care is the second largest [[cosmetics]] company in [[South Korea]], and it has continued to narrow the gap with its competitor.<ref>[http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2015/05/618_179398.html Cosmetics vs. creative economy]</ref> Its major high-end cosmetics brands include ‘The History of Whoo’, ‘O Hui’, ‘SU:M37’, and ‘belif’.<ref>[http://www.lgcare.com/global/brand/list.jsp?type=BEAUTIFUL LG Household & Health Care official site]</ref> The high-end cosmetics business is growing fast with ‘The History of Whoo’ recording the highest sales among all other brands in major duty-free stores in Korea.<ref name="lgcare.com">[http://www.lgcare.com/global/news/press/view.jsp?seq=181&title= LG H&H reports net sales of 1.3 trillion won, and operating profit of 178 billion won for 1Q 2015]</ref> The major brands in mid-to-low end cosmetics include ‘ISA KNOX’, ‘Sooryehan’, ‘BEYOND’, and ‘THEFACESHOP’, the number one brandshop in Korea.<ref>[http://khnews.kheraldm.com/view.php?ud=20150122000710&md=20150122213254_BL Missha announces domestic downsizing, global expansion]</ref>
===Household Goods=== LG Household & Health Care has maintained a dominant number one position in Korean [[household goods]] industry, and still continues to increase its market share through product differentiation, and category expansion.<ref name="lgcare.com"/> The major business units are personal care and home care. Personal care includes oral care, hair care, and body care, while home care includes dishwashing detergent, laundry detergent, and fabric softener. The major brands are ‘Perioe’·’Bamboo Salt’(oral care), ‘Elastine’·’Reen’(hair care), ‘ON: THE BODY’(body care), ‘TECH’(laundry detergent), ‘Jayeonpong’(dishwashing detergent), and ‘Saffron’(fabric softner).<ref>[http://www.lgcare.com/global/brand/list.jsp?type=HEALTHY LG Household & Health Care official site]</ref>
===Beverages=== Beverages business division was established through the M&A of [[Coca-Cola]] Beverage(former Coca-Cola Korea Bottling Co., Ltd) in 2007, and is currently the second largest beverage company in Korea.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=awoWdM5rHQw8&refer=home LG Household to Buy Coca-Cola Amatil's Korean Unit (Update3) ]</ref> The major brands are ‘[[Coca-Cola]]’, ‘[[Fanta]]’, ‘[[Sprite (soft drink)|Sprite]]’, ‘Minute-Maid’, ‘Sunkist’, ‘Georgia’, and ‘POWERADE’.<ref>[http://www.lgcare.com/global/brand/list.jsp?type=REFRESHING LG Household & Health Care official site]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
