revision.text:
'''STDs in the porn industry''' deals with the [[occupational safety and health]] issue in the [[sex industry]] of transmission of [[sexually transmitted infections]] (STIs/STDs), especially [[HIV/AIDS]], which became a major cause of concern since the 1980s, especially for [[pornographic film actor]]s. {{As of|2009}}, there had been twenty-two reported [[HIV]] cases in the U.S. pornography industry; roughly half were among men who work in gay films, and the other half were men and women working in heterosexual productions.{{cite news |author= |date=24 June 2009 |title=L.A. pushes for condoms in porn legislation, but state lawmakers balk |url=http://capitolweekly.net/l-a-pushes-for-condoms-in-porn-legislation-but-state-lawmakers-balk/ |newspaper=Capitol Weekly |location=Sacramento, California |accessdate=11 March 2014}} ==Types of diseases== Because pornographic film making involves [[unsimulated sex]], usually without [[condom]]s ([[Bareback (sex)|barebacking]]), pornographic actors are particularly vulnerable to [[sexually transmitted disease]]s including [[Chlamydia infection|chlamydia]], [[gonorrhea]], [[syphilis]], and [[HIV/AIDS]].{{cite journal|last1=Rodriguez-Hart|first1=C|last2=Chitale|first2=RA|last3=Rigg|first3=R|last4=Goldstein|first4=BY|last5=Kerndt|first5=PR|last6=Tavrow|first6=P|title=Sexually transmitted infection testing of adult film performers: is disease being missed?|journal=Sexually Transmitted Diseases|date=December 2012|volume=39|issue=12|pages=989–94|doi=10.1097/OLQ.0b013e3182716e6e|pmid=23191956}}{{cite journal|last1=Grudzen|first1=CR|last2=Meeker|first2=D|last3=Torres|first3=J|last4=Du|first4=Q|last5=Andersen|first5=RM|last6=Gelberg|first6=L|title=HIV and STI risk behaviors, knowledge, and testing among female adult film performers as compared to other California women|journal=AIDS and Behavior|date=February 2013|volume=17|issue=2|pages=517–22|doi=10.1007/s10461-011-0090-0|pmid=22101890}}{{cite journal|last1=Goldstein|first1=BY|last2=Steinberg|first2=JK|last3=Aynalem|first3=G|last4=Kerndt|first4=PR|title=High Chlamydia and gonorrhea incidence and reinfection among performers in the adult film industry|journal=Sexually Transmitted Diseases|date=July 2011|volume=38|issue=7|pages=644–8|doi=10.1097/OLQ.0b013e318214e408|pmid=21844714}} ==HIV cases== ===1980s and 1990s=== [[File:BrookeAshley lg.jpg|thumb|Brooke Ashley became [[HIV positive]] in 1998 but returned to pornography in 2005 in a film with her boyfriend Eddie Wood, who was also HIV positive.[http://business.avn.com/articles/22639.html "Powers Shoots HIV-Positive, Hetero Scene"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505083252/http://business.avn.com/articles/22639.html |date=2010-05-05 }}, by Mark Kernes, ''[[Adult Video News]]'', 2005-08-11. [http://www.avn.com/movies/62281.html "AVN Reviews: Dirty Debutantes 2005 327 & 328"], Marc Star, ''[[Adult Video News]]''. Both retrieved 2007-07-17]] According to former pornographic actress [[Shelley Lubben]], a 1980s outbreak of HIV led to the death of 27 porn stars between 1985 and 1992, including [[Wade Nichols]] (who died in 1985), [[John Holmes (actor)|John Holmes]] (1988), [[Marc Stevens (actor)|Marc Stevens]] (1989), and [[Al Parker]] (1992).{{cite web |last=Lubben |first=Shelley |date=September 3, 2013 |title=STD and HIV Outbreaks in the Porn Industry Since the 1980's |url=http://pornharmsresearch.com/2013/09/std-and-hiv-outbreaks-in-the-porn-industry-since-the-1980s/ |type=compilation |website=pornharmsresearch.com |publisher=Morality in Media |accessdate=10 September 2014}} When Nichols died in 1985, his fellow porn star [[Ron Jeremy]] denied that Nichols' death was AIDS-related.{{cite book |last=Jennings |first=David |year=2000 |chapter=Chapter 20: AIDS and Other Four-Letter Words |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=3VCVm7sc5JsC&pg=PA403 |title=Skinflicks: The Inside Story of the X-Rated Video Industry |url= |location= |publisher=David Jennings |page= |isbn=978-1-58721-184-3 |accessdate=10 September 2014}}{{rp|406}} In February 1986, Holmes was diagnosed as HIV-positive. Six months previously, he had tested negative. During the summer of 1986, Holmes, knowing his HIV status, agreed to perform in two pornographic films to be filmed in Italy, without informing the producers of his HIV status. Performers in one film, ''The Rise and Fall of the Roman Empress'', were [[Ilona Staller|Ilona "Cicciolina" Staller]], who later became a member of the Italian parliament, [[Tracey Adams]], [[Christoph Clark]], and [[Amber Lynn]].{{cite book |author=Various |year=2008 |editor-last=Patrick |editor-first=John |title=Huge |publisher=STARbooks |page=13 |isbn=978-1-934187-29-6}} Performers in the other film, ''The Devil In Mr. Holmes'', were Adams, Lynn, [[Karin Schubert]], and [[Marina Hedman]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} Subsequently, it was revealed that Holmes had consciously chosen not to reveal his HIV status to his producers or co-stars before engaging in unprotected sex for the filming.{{cite news |last=Holden |first=Stephen |date=12 January 2001 |title= WADD: The Life and Times of John C. Holmes |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?_r=1&res=940CE0DF1F3AF931A25752C0A9679C8B63 |type=movie review |newspaper=New York Times}}{{cite book |last=Hawes |first=William |year=2009 |title=Caligula and the fight for artistic freedom: the making, marketing and impact of the Bob Guccione film |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oflL1anesoYC |publisher=[[McFarland & Company|McFarland]] |page=203 |isbn=978-0-7864-3986-7}}{{cite news |last=Viladevall |first=Ferrán |date=16 May 2014|title=La mala vida del rey del porno |url=http://www.elmundo.es/magazine/2004/242/1084286415.html |language=Spanish |newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)]] |location= |accessdate=4 September 2011}} As his health failed, Holmes disingenuously attributed his condition to colon cancer and first confided that he had [[AIDS]] in January 1987.{{cite book |last=Basten |first=Fred |author2=Laurie Holmes |author3=John C. Holmes |title=Porn King: The John Holmes Story |year=1998 |publisher=John Holmes Inc. |isbn=978-1-880047-69-9}} He died from AIDS-related complications on March 13, 1988, aged 43.{{cite web |last=Scheeres |first=Julia |title=The Wonderland Murders |publisher=Turner Entertainment Networks |accessdate=20 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/celebrity/john_holmes/11.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024195434/http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/celebrity/john_holmes/11.html |archivedate=24 October 2007 |df= }} Stevens died of [[AIDS]]{{rp|405}} in 1989, aged 46.{{cite book |last=Edmonson |first=Roger |year=2000 |title=Clone: The Life and Legacy of Al Parker, Gay Superstar |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xTHijC4DkGEC |publisher=Alyson Books |location= |page=205 |isbn=978-1555835293 }} Parker died in 1992 from complications of AIDS, aged 40. [[Marc Wallice]], a known IV drug user,[http://www.excaliburfilms.com/pornlist/malepgs/Marc_Wallice.htm Excalibur's Porn Star Mall. Biography - Marc Wallice Porn Star] tested HIV positive in 1998. On April 30, 1998, he was diagnosed by [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation|Adult Industry Medical]] (AIM) as HIV positive.{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/AIDS/story?id=4130615&page=1 |title=Porn Industry Still Struggles With Condom Issue |work=ABC News |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]] |accessdate=2012-02-08}} It was alleged that he had hidden his HIV positive status for two years, with rumors that he accomplished this by using fake blood work through several HIV testing cycles to continue working.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} This speculation has been disputed and investigated using Wallice's tests,{{cite web |last=Staff |title=Marc Wallice Closer to Vindication? |url=http://business.avn.com/articles/video/Marc-Wallice-Closer-to-Vindication-36253.html |publisher=Adult Video News |accessdate=2 March 2014}}{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Marc Wallice Speaks Out on his Role in the HIV Controversy: "Brooke Ashley Is Off Her Fucking Rocker!"|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/video/Marc-Wallice-Speaks-Out-on-his-Role-in-the-HIV-Controversy-8220-Brooke-Ashley-Is-Off-Her-Fucking-Rocker-8221-36300.html|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=2 March 2014}} but it has not been doubted that during this period Wallice infected seven women on the set: Brooke Ashley,{{cite news |title=Powers Shoots HIV-Positive, Hetero Scene |first=Mark |last=Kernes |url=http://business.avn.com/articles/22639.html |newspaper=[[Adult Video News]] |publisher=Adult Video News, Inc. |location=Philadelphia, PA |issn=0883-7090 |oclc=12197226 |date=2005-08-11 |accessdate=2012-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505083252/http://business.avn.com/articles/22639.html |archivedate=2010-05-05 |df= }} [[Tricia Devereaux]],{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/AIDS/hiv-actors-positive-test-unsettles-hub-us-porn/story?id=11892877&page=3 |title=Actor's Positive HIV Test Disrupts Filming as Clinic Traces On-Screen Sex Partners |first=Jane E. |last=Allen |year=2010 |work=ABC News |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]] |accessdate=2012-02-08}} Caroline, Nena Cherry, Jordan McKnight, Barbara Doll, and Kimberly Jade. ===2000s=== After four years of no reported HIV-issues within the industry, in April 2004, AIM diagnosed [[Darren James]] as being HIV-positive. It was concluded that James had been infected while engaging in unprotected [[anal sex]] with Brazilian actress Bianca Biaggi during a scene for the video ''Split That Booty 2'' in [[Rio de Janeiro]].[http://business.avn.com/articles/15953.html AVN - Test Results Pending for Two Performers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618141354/http://business.avn.com/articles/15953.html |date=2009-06-18 }}{{cite web |url = http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=22883 |title = Lara Roxx Timeline Begs Questions: Darren James got it from Lara Roxx, not the other way around? |author = Gene Ross |publisher = Adult FYI |date = 2007-05-27 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080313070354/http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=22883 |archivedate = 2008-03-13 |df = }}{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-041604adult-g,1,4216028.graphic |title=Pyramid of potential infection |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=2004-04-16 |accessdate=2008-03-20 |quote=Time line of potential first and second generation infections }} AIM initiated an urgent search for other potentially infected performers.{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?&res=9C05EEDF123CF933A25756C0A9629C8B63 |title=Voice of Health in a Pornographic World |accessdate=2007-02-26 |author=Nick Madigan |date=2004-05-10 |publisher=The New York Times |quote=
Sharon Mitchell — ''Well-behaved women rarely make history'' }} It was discovered that three actresses who had worked with James shortly after his return to the [[United States]] had also become infected. These were Canadians [[Lara Roxx]] and Miss Arroyo, and Czech-born [[Jessica Dee]].{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9506E4DD143DF933A05757C0A9629C8B63 |title =New H.I.V. Infection Found in Sex-Film Industry |accessdate=2008-03-20 |author=Nick Madigan |date=2004-04-30 |publisher=The New York Times }}AVN, May 5th, 2004: [http://business.avn.com/articles/15987.html Another First-Gen Woman Diagnosed as HIV-Positive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821144824/http://business.avn.com/articles/15987.html |date=2009-08-21 }}AVN, April 26th, 2004: [http://business.avn.com/articles/15867.html Viral Load Results Indicate James was 'Patient Zero'] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120707155910/http://business.avn.com/articles/15867.html |date=2012-07-07 }} The heterosexual segment of the porn industry voluntarily shut down for 30 days (a 60-day moratorium was originally announced but it was lifted early) while it tried to deal with the situation.[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/7652.php AIDS in pornography industry of California contained says adult industry body] Darren James, Jessica Dee, and Lara Roxx were barred from further production of sexually explicit content. About 60 actors who had had contact with James or Roxx were barred from working until HIV tests were completed and they were declared HIV negative. A further estimated 130 actors who had had contact with James were tested and received an HIV-negative result. A total of five actors were diagnosed with the virus by the end of the moratorium: one male and four females, including one transgender woman named Jennifer. In June 2009, AIM reported that a female adult entertainer had tested positive, though it was believed that transmission occurred in her private life. LA County Public Health claimed that there had been 16 "unreported" HIV cases in the adult film industry. The AIM Healthcare Foundation claimed those cases did not involve actors in production companies that followed their testing protocols and included members of the general public who used AIM Healthcare testing services or individuals attempting to work in the porn industry who never were able to obtain employment in adult films because of their failure to provide proof negative status for HIV or other STD.[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-porn-hiv12-2009jun12,0,3569962.story More porn HIV cases disclosed] ===2010s=== On October 12, 2010, AIM reported that an actor or actress had been infected with HIV. The name and gender of the person was not released to the public.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/porn-actor-has-tested-positive-for-hiv-industry-clinic-officials-confirm.html|title=Porn Actor has Tested Positive for HIV; Industry Clinic Officials Confirm a Quarantine is in Effect|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=October 12, 2010|accessdate=October 13, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101013025742/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com//lanow//2010//10//porn-actor-has-tested-positive-for-hiv-industry-clinic-officials-confirm.html| archivedate= 13 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} [[Vivid Entertainment]] and [[Wicked Pictures]] were the first companies to announce a production shutdown. Although [[Wicked Pictures]] allow some performers to wear condoms, the company shut down to wait for the [[quarantine]] list.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/wicked-pictures-suspends-production-as-precaution-following-new-hiv-case-in-porn-performer-.html|title=Wicked Pictures and Vivid Entertainment Suspend Production as a Precaution Amid New HIV Case in Porn Performer|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=October 12, 2010|accessdate=October 13, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101016193546/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/wicked-pictures-suspends-production-as-precaution-following-new-hiv-case-in-porn-performer-.html| archivedate= 16 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} Several other porn studios shut down as a preventative measure.{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101014/ap_en_ot/us_porn_industry_hiv|title=Positive HIV Test Halts Porn Shoots at Companies |publisher=Yahoo! News|date=October 13, 2010|accessdate=October 15, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101015052803/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101014/ap_en_ot/us_porn_industry_hiv| archivedate= 15 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} At the time, no other performers tested HIV positive.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/hiv-tests-negative-for-porn-actors-who-performed-with-patient-zero-.html|title=HIV Tests Negative for Porn Actors Who Performed with 'Patient Zero'|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=October 22, 2010|accessdate=October 23, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101024210518/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/hiv-tests-negative-for-porn-actors-who-performed-with-patient-zero-.html| archivedate= 24 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} In December, the HIV positive performer was identified as Derrick Burts. Burts had worked in both heterosexual and gay pornography.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/health/la-me-porn-hiv-20101208,0,5306958.story | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Molly | last=Hennessy-Fiske | date=December 8, 2010 | title=HIV-positive porn performer speaks out}} Despite contracting [[gonorrhea]], [[chlamydia infection|chlamydia]] and [[syphilis]], Burts continued taking part in unprotected sex in films before quitting once he was diagnosed as being HIV positive. He was informed by the Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation that he had contracted the disease, which according to Burts, he received on a set outside the AIM system, while having oral sex scene with another "[[HIV positive]] male actor".{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/derrick-burts-hiv-in-pornography-the-naked-truth-2167532.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Derrick Burts: HIV in pornography: the naked truth | date=December 23, 2010}} In August 2011, the industry was temporarily shut down because of news of a performer was testing positive for the virus. [[Diane Duke]], executive director of the [[Free Speech Coalition]], confirmed the situation.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} Production later resumed production when a performer was retested and it came back negative.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} In June 2013, a gay male performer tested positive for HIV in a routine FSC-conducted blood test.{{cite web|title=FSC Pass|url=http://www.fscpass.com|accessdate=|date=2013}} The anonymous performer had previously worked exclusively on condom-only movies.{{cite web |url=http://www.sex.com/news/blog/adult-perfomer-tests-positive-hiv/ |title=Adult Performer Tests Positive for HIV » The Sex.com Blog |publisher=Sex.com |accessdate=2013-08-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130827212449/http://www.sex.com/news/blog/adult-perfomer-tests-positive-hiv/ |archive-date=2013-08-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} FSC determined that the infection did not take place on-set.{{cite web |title=ViralGenealogyConclusive:PositivePerformerfromDecemberMoratoriumContractedVirusinPersonalLife |url=http://blog.aphss.org/?p=499|accessdate=20 December 2013|work=PASS Blog|date=20 December 2013}} In August 2013, an adult female performer, Cameron Bay, tested HIV positive.{{cite news|title=Porn actress' positive HIV test roils adult entertainment world|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-porn-actress-positive-hiv-test-roils-adult-entertainment-world-20130824,0,75668.story|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=August 24, 2013|author=Abby Sewell}}{{cite news|title=Porn star Cameron Bay tests positive for HIV|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/confirmed-porn-star-cameron-bay-tests-positive-hiv-article-1.1434736|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=August 23, 2013|author=Joe Kemp}}{{cite news|title=Porn Star Cameron Bay Opens Up About HIV Scare|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/porn-stars-center-hiv-scare-speak/story?id=20050118|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=Nightline ABC News|date=August 23, 2013|author=Sydney Lupkin}}{{cite news|title=US porn actor's HIV test prompts calls for moratorium on production|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2013/aug/25/us-porn-industry-actor-hiv|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=August 25, 2013|author=Rory Carroll|location=Los Angeles}} In response, FSC organized an industry wide moratorium from August 21 to August 27. On September 4, Rod Daily, Cameron Bay's ex-boyfriend,http://therealpornwikileaks.com/cameron-bay-talked-michael-whiteacre-last-night/ announced he had also tested HIV positive.{{cite news|title=Rod Daily, Gay Porn Star, Says He is HIV Positive|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/04/rod-daily-gay-porn-star-hiv_n_3866682.html|accessdate= 4 September 2013|work=Huffington Post|date=4 September 2013}} Two days later, a third anonymous female performer tested positive {{cite news|title=Yet Another HIV-Positive Porn Performer Leads To Third Shutdown|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/06/fourth-hiv-porn_n_4401064.html|accessdate= 6 December 2013|work=Huffington Post|date=6 December 2013}} prompting FSC to organize a second moratorium from September 6 to September 20.{{cite web|title=FSC Announces Moratorium To Life On Friday, September 20|url=http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/component/content/article/232-fsc-announces-moratorium-to-lift-on-friday-september-20.html|work=FSC|date=September 2013|access-date=2014-06-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140612011243/http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/component/content/article/232-fsc-announces-moratorium-to-lift-on-friday-september-20.html|archive-date=2014-06-12|dead-url=yes|df=}} All three infections were found to have taken place off-set. Rumors surfaced of a fourth HIV positive test during September but they were never substantiated.{{cite web|title=Moratorium Update|url=https://www.freespeechcoalition.com/component/content/article/230-moratorium-update-september-9-2013.html|accessdate=9 September 2013|work=Free Speech Coalition|date=9 September 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205073222/http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/component/content/article/230-moratorium-update-september-9-2013.html|archive-date=2013-12-05|dead-url=yes|df=}} In December 2013, a male porn actor tested HIV positive, leading FSC to halt production for one week. This infection was also determined to have taken place off-set. ==Testing and clinics== The revelations led to the creation of the [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]] (AIM Healthcare or AIM) in 1998, which helped set up a monitoring system in the pornographic film industry in the United States, and pornographic film actors were required to be tested for HIV every 30 days.{{cite book|last=Basten|first=Fred |author2=Laurie Holmes |author3=John C. Holmes|title=Porn King: The John Holmes Story|year=1998|publisher=John Holmes Inc|isbn=978-1-880047-69-9}} The AIM system required all sexual contact to be logged, with positive test results leading to all sexual contacts for the last three to six months being contacted and re-tested. The use of condoms became standard in films featuring homosexual [[anal sex]].{{why?|date=January 2018}} Due to accurate and mandatory medical tests, HIV and [[AIDS]] cases became rare in the pornographic film industry.{{source needed|date=January 2018}} However, testing is voluntary (though refusal to be tested can result in the actor not being cast in a sex role) and there is no testing or monitoring of the pornographic film industry in other countries. There have been indications that actors have voluntarily left the industry, at least the industry in the United States, rather than be tested by AIM and have their AIDS and HIV status disclosed. AIM closed all its operations in May 2011, forcing the industry to look for other mechanisms for supporting and enforcing regular testing.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2011/05/porn_clinic_closed_aim_testing.php|title=Porn Clinic AIM Closes For Good: Valley-Based Industry Scrambles to Find New STD Testing System|last=Dennis Romero|date=May 3, 2011|work=[[LA Weekly]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011}} The gap was filled by the [[Free Speech Coalition]], which set up the APHSS system, now known as [[Performer Availability Screening Services]] (PASS).{{cite web|title=FSC Pass |url=http://www.fscpass.com|accessdate= |date=2013}} ==Legislation== ===Regulations to limit the spread of HIV=== Due to this limited outbreak, the California State government considered regulating the industry. Some proposed to mandate the wearing of [[condom]]s during sexually explicit scenes. Industry insiders say this would ruin sales of their wares since the unprotected content is one of the selling points of some of their films. They say the wearing of condoms ruins the sexual fantasies of many viewers. Insiders say that such regulation would force the industry underground, out of California or overseas where it would be more prone to health risks for performers. The non-profit [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]] (AIM Healthcare) worked with the government, to develop policies that both the industry and the government would find acceptable.{{cite journal | pmc = 1892037 | pmid=17579507 | doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040126 | volume=4 | issue=6 | title=The adult film industry: time to regulate? | year=2007 | journal=PLoS Med. | pages=e126 | last1 = Grudzen | first1 = CR | last2 = Kerndt | first2 = PR}} === 2012 ballot measure in Los Angeles === In the 2012 election voters in Los Angeles were presented with [[Measure B]] ("Safer Sex In the Adult Film Industry Act") with the following text:{{cite web|url=http://www.smartvoter.org/2012/11/06/ca/la/meas/B/|title=Measure B: Safer Sex In the Adult Film Industry Act - Los Angeles County, CA|accessdate=2012-11-07}} {{quote|Shall an ordinance be adopted requiring producers of adult films to obtain a County public health permit, to require adult film performers to use condoms while engaged in sex acts, to provide proof of blood borne pathogen training course, to post permit and notices to performers, and making violations of the ordinance subject to civil fines and criminal charges?}} Proponents of the measure claimed pornography performers were significantly more likely to acquire HIV than the general population and that they are generally not given health insurance by their employers and so the tax payer would foot the bill for HIV treatment. Opponents claimed it to be a waste of tax dollars because of existing stringent HIV testing protocols and because nobody has contracted HIV on set in the past eight years in the United States.{{When|date=September 2016}} The measure passed with 57% voting for and 43% voting against.{{cite news|last=Shergold|first=Adam|title=California votes to mandate condoms in porn industry|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2229232/Measure-B-California-votes-mandate-condoms-LA-porn-industry-amid-fears-industry-leave-state.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490|accessdate=8 November 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail (London)|date=8 November 2012}}{{cite news|title=Porn industry trade group vows to fight condom requirement|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/11/porn-industry-trade-group-plans-to-fight-condom-decision.html|accessdate=8 November 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=7 November 2012}} The [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]] tried several times to have California's Department of Industrial Relations, Division of Occupational Safety and Health's Appeals Board force companies in the pornography industry to treat actors and actresses as employees subject to [[occupational safety and health]] regulation; in a 2014 case brought against [[Treasure Island Media]] an administrative judge found that the company did have to comply with regulations.{{cite news|last1=Fitz-Gerald|first1=Sean|title=Condoms Required for CA Porn Performers: Judge|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/California-Judge-Issues-Landmark-Ruling-on-Unprotected-Porn-242117921.html|work=NBC Southern California|date=January 27, 2014|language=en}} == See also == * [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]] (AIM) * [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]] * [[Performer Availability Screening Services]] (PASS) ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |last1=Grudzen |first1=Corita R. |last2=Elliott |first2=Marc N. |last3=Kerndt |first3=Peter R. |last4=Schuster |first4=Mark A. |last5=Brook |first5=Robert H. |last6=Gelberg |first6=Lillian |date=April 2009 |title=Condom Use and High-Risk Sexual Acts in Adult Films: A Comparison of Heterosexual and Homosexual Films |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume= 99 Suppl 1|issue= S1|pages= S152–6|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2007.127035 |pmc=2724941 |pmid=19218178}} {{Pornography}} [[Category:Condoms]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS]] [[Category:Occupational safety and health]] [[Category:Research on the effects of pornography]] [[Category:STDs in the sex industry]]

'''Social quality''' is a way of understanding society which is also relevant for social and public policy. Social quality looks at elements that should constitute a good or decent society. It contributes to the body of work concerned with understanding social progress going beyond [[Gross domestic product|GDP]], taking into account the work of the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] and the [[European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions]]. Whilst most approaches have concentrated on the [[happiness economics|economics]] or [[Subjective well-being|psychology of well-being]], social quality can help understanding the social conditions that enable human flourishing.<ref name="social quality">{{cite journal |last=Abbott |first=Pamela |last2=Wallace |first2=Claire |date=2012 |title=Social Quality: A way to measure the quality of society |journal=Social Indicators Research |volume=108 |issue=1 |pages=153–167 |doi=10.1007/s11205-011-9871-0 |pmid=22773884 |pmc=3384781}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Social quality.png|400px|right|Social quality diagram]]
There are four elements shown in the diagram on the right. ''Economic security'' refers to the material conditions that enable people to have a long term perspective on their lives, and their confidence for the future. This can include social policies, such as pensions and social security, that ensure this. It also includes economic conditions that enable people to feel secure because they have enough income to cover their basic needs.<ref name="social quality" /> ''Social cohesion'' refers to the bonds that link societies together, deriving from the work of [[Émile Durkheim]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Durkheim |first=Émile |date=1952 |title=Suicide. A Study in Sociology |location=London |publisher=Routledge }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Durkheim |first=Émile |date=1952 |title=The Division of Labour in Society|location=New York |publisher=Free Press }}</ref> [[Émile Durkheim]]'s work considers the moral and social relationships between members of society and social groups, including factors such as trust in others, trust in social institutions, a sense of identity, a collective consciousness, solidarity and commitment to the common good of society.<ref>{{cite book |last=Dragolov |first=Georgi |last2=Ignácz |first2=Zsófia |last3=Lorenz |first3=Jan |last4=Delhey |first4=Jan| last5=Boehnke |first5=Klaus |date=2013 |title=Social Cohesion Radar. Measuring Common Ground. An international Comparison of Social Cohesion|location=Gutersloh |publisher=Bertelsmann }}</ref> ''Social inclusion'' refers to the way in which individuals and social groups are included into society, either through employment, networks and family or through access to social support of various kinds, this can come through support from other people or from social policies. Social policies that foster social inclusion, reduce poverty and tackle other forms of social exclusion can be important in this respect.<ref name="social quality" /> ''Social empowerment'' refers to the conditions that enable people to participate in their society, such as having good health, education and democratic opportunities for participation, such as voting and joining civil society. However, it can also mean the feelings of being empowered, being able to take control of one's circumstances. It derives from the work of [[Amartya Sen]], who suggests that people need to have the capability to be able to do the things that they wish to do.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sen |first=Amartya |editor-last=Nussbaum |editor-first=Martha Craven |editor-last2=Sen |editor-first2=Amartya|title=The Quality of Life |location=London|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |date=1993 |chapter=Capability and Well-being }}</ref>
However, the social quality approach is fundamentally relational. As such, it emphasises a complex field of conditional (i), constitutional (ii) and normative factors (iii). These are (i) Socio-Economic Security, Social Cohesion, Social Inclusion, Social Empowerment; (ii) Person/human security, Social Recognition, Social Responsiveness, Personal/human Capacity; and (iii) Social Justice (Equity), Solidarity, Equal Valuation, Human Dignity. On the one hand this rejects the Durkheimian view on society as an independent social fact sui generis; on the other hand it qualifies Sen's approach as social quality is not primarily focusing on the subjective side and individuals within society but on the constitution of society by way of people producing and reproducing their daily life and with this society.
==Origins and development== The idea of social quality began as a [[European Union]] project among a group of social scientists, concerned to develop a better way forward for social policies in Europe.<ref>{{cite book |last=Beck |first=Wolfang |last2=van der Maesen |first2=Laurent |last3=Walker |first3=Alan |date=1997 |title=The Social Quality of Europe|location=The Hague |publisher=Kluwer Law International}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Beck |first=Wolfang |last2=van der Maesen |first2=Laurent |last3=Walker |first3=Alan |last4=Thomes |first4=Fleur |date=2001 |title=Social Quality: A Vision for Europe|location=The Hague |publisher=Kluwer Law International }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor-last=van der Maesen |editor-first=Laurent |editor-last2=Walker |editor-first2=Alan |date=2012 |title=Social Quality. From Theory to Indicators|location=London |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan }}</ref> Later the concept underwent some fundamental development. Empirically it had been developed amongst others by Pamela Abbott, [[Claire Wallace]] and Roger Sapsford, who looked at how the model can be developed empirically in Europe, [[Eastern Europe]], [[Central Asia]], China and [[Rwanda]]. They have used a different variation, considering the impact on well being, measured through [[life satisfaction]] and human flourishing in order to understand how social quality might work in fostering the well being of people in society.<ref name="social quality" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Abbott |first=Pamela| last2=Wallace| first2=Claire |editor-last=Selin|editor-first=Helaine |editor-last2=Gareth|editor-first2=Gaveth|title=Happiness across Cultures: Views of Happiness and Quality of Life in Non-Western Cultures |location=London|publisher=Springer Verlag|date=2012 |chapter=Happiness in Post-Conflict Rwanda| pages= 361–376}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Abbott |first=Pamela| last2=Wallace| first2=Claire |editor-last=Selin|editor-first=Helaine |editor-last2=Gareth|editor-first2=Gaveth|title=Happiness across Cultures: Views of Happiness and Quality of Life in Non-Western Cultures |location=London|publisher=Springer Verlag|date=2012 |chapter=Satisfaction and Societal Quality in Kazakhstan| pages= 107–120}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Abbott |first=Pamela |last2=Wallace |first2=Claire |date=2014 |title='Rising economic prosperity and social quality. The case of new member states of the European Union |url= https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11205-012-9992-0|journal=Social Indicators Research |volume=115 |issue=1 |pages=419–439 |doi=10.1007/s11205-012-9992-0 |accessdate=5 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Abbott |first=Pamela |last2=Wallace |first2=Claire|last3=Sapsford |first3=Roger |date=2010|title='Surviving the transformation: Social quality in Central Asia and the Caucasus |url= https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10902-010-9187-9|journal=Journal of Happiness Studies |volume=12 |issue=2 |pages=199–223 |doi=10.1007/s10902-010-9187-9 |accessdate=5 January 2015}}</ref> This empirical work had been to a large extent emerging from the work undertaken by colleagues in Asia, in particular by Ka Lin.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lin |first=Ka |last2=Herrmann |first2=Peter |date=2015 |title=Social Quality Theory. A New Perspective on Social Development|location=New York/Oxford |publisher=Berghahn}}</ref> Another development is by a marked shift towards questions around 'overall sustainability'. Laurent van der Maesen is the main proponent of this strand contends. In a working paper we read that "international and national (and urban) strategies and policies for development toward 'overall' sustainability not only have to have a strong emphasis on development toward sustainability of cities themselves (internal sustainability) but also – simultaneously – address the development toward sustainability of the cities' surroundings ('Hinterland')".<ref>{{cite journal |last=International Association of Social Quality |date=2012 |title=The need for a Comprehensive Conceptual and Methodological Framework for new politics and policies: A social quality perspective; A contribution to the Rio+ 20 Conference on the sustainability of human existence on Earth |journal=IASQ working papers |issue=11 |pages=12 f.1}}</ref>
A more traditional line is maintained by [[Peter Herrmann (social philosopher)|Peter Herrmann]] who had been since the end of the 1990s advisor of the then European Foundation, later International Association of Social Quality. He claims that "[w]e have to reconceptualize ... indicators. They are not measurement instruments sui generis. Rather they are instruments to develop an understanding of complex issues and trends. As such they need to be guided by a sound conceptual reflection of what they are looking for".<ref>{{cite journal |last=Herrmann |first=Peter |date=2012 |title=Economic Performance, Social Progress and Social Quality |journal=International Journal of Social Quality |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=41–55 |doi=10.3167/IJSQ.2012.020104 }}</ref> Herrmann is on the one hand reclaiming the methodological and theoretical importance of Social Quality thinking, at least qualifying the empirical orientation. On the other hand, though this does not contradict the orientation on sustainability, Herrmann emphasises the need to reorient debates on "the kind of economy in place" instead of maintaining dichotomies, separations and hierarchies between different areas of societal development. This had been elaborated in a book on defining social policy as matter of producing society.<ref>{{cite book |last=Herrmann |first=Peter |date=2014 |title=Social Policy – Production rather than Distribution. A Rights-Based Approach|location=Bremen |publisher=EHV}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Eudaimonia]] – Greek word used as a translation for "human flourishing"
==Notes== <references />
==References== *{{cite news |last=Wallace |first=Claire |date=5 November 2014 |title=Beyond GDP: happiness is about more than just individuals |url=http://theconversation.com/beyond-gdp-happiness-is-about-more-than-just-individuals-33768 |newspaper=[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] |accessdate= 5 January 2015}}
== External links == * [http://www.socialquality.org/ Association for Social Quality] * [http://journals.berghahnbooks.com/ijsq/ ''International Journal of Social Quality'' website] * [http://www.abdn.ac.uk/socsci/research/new-europe-centre/ New Europe Centre website]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = St. Vincent's HealthCare | logo = StVincentLogo.PNG | type = Private Company | genre = | foundation = 1982 | founder = | location_city = [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], Florida | location_country = USA | location = <!-- this parameter modifies "Headquarters" --> | key_people = Tom VanOsdol, Interim President and CEO | area_served = United States | industry = Healthcare | products = | services = health care management | revenue = | income from recurring operation = | net_income = | num_employees = 4,700 (2009) | parent = [[Ascension Health]] | divisions = | subsid = | owner = | homepage = http://www.jaxhealth.com/ | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''St. Vincent's HealthCare''', based in [[Jacksonville, Florida]] is a network of three acute-care hospitals, a long-term skilled nursing facility, 30+ primary care centers, nearly a dozen medical laboratories, transportation and prescription services, and a health outreach ministry. St.Vincent's is also an affiliate of [[Ascension Health]].<ref name=HIST>[https://www.jaxhealth.com/about-us/history/ "Our history"] St. Vincent's HealthCare website</ref><ref>[http://www.jaxhealth.com/locations/ "Find a location"] St. Vincent's HealthCare website</ref>
==History== St. Vincent's Hospital was founded in 1916 by the Daughters of Charity and named after the 17th century [[Paris, France|Parisian]] [[St. Vincent de Paul]], who started the Daughters of Charity in 1633.
===Foundation=== The '''St. Vincent's HealthCare Foundation''' is the entity that financially supports the mission of Jacksonville's province of [[Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul|Daughters of Charity]]. The foundation and network, established in 1982, is dedicated to improving the present and future healthcare needs of the Jacksonville area, and has provided more than $1 million in support every year since its creation.<ref>[http://www.jaxhealth.com/foundation/ "Foundation"] St. Vincent's HealthCare website</ref>
The foundation stages fund-raising events throughout the year, including the ''Red Rose Ball'', begun in 1982 and Jacksonville's oldest charity ball. The 2008 event was attended by [[John Travolta]] and [[Kelly Preston]], who helped collect over $1 million in donations.<ref>Purcell, Myrlia: [http://www.looktothestars.org/news/549-travolta-and-preston-raise-funds-for-premature-babies "Travolta and Preston Raise Funds for Premature Babies"] Look to the Stars, February 18, 2008</ref>
John Ash was the celebrity chef at the 10th annual ''Delicious Destinations'' event in 2011. The three-day event attracts over a dozen executive chefs from notable restaurants and resorts around the country to prepare their favorite dishes for donors at the [[Ponte Vedra Inn and Club]].<ref>Trussel, Ilyssa: [http://jacksonville.com/opinion/blog/470157/ilyssa-trussel/2011-07-07/chef-john-ash-confirmed-celebrity-chef-st-vincent-s "Annual Gourmet Food and Wine Tasting Event"] Florida Times-Union, July 7, 2011</ref><ref>Mills, Gary: [http://jacksonville.com/opinion/blog/st-vincents-healthcare-foundation "St. Vincent's Healthcare Foundation"] Florida Times-Union, September 6, 2011</ref>
St. Vincent's HealthCare Foundation is also a charity recipient of proceeds from [[The Players Championship]], and conducts a two-day charity golf tournament early in the week known as ''The Tradition''.<ref>[http://www.jaxhealth.com/foundation/the-tradition/ "THE TRADITION 2012"] St. Vincent's HealthCare website</ref>
===Baptist merger=== During the 1990s, for-profit [[health maintenance organization]]s such as [[Hospital Corporation of America|Columbia/HCA]] captured a large share from non-profit hospitals. With William C. "Bill" Mason as CEO, St. Vincent's merged with rival [[Baptist Health]] in 1995 to become the dominant healthcare provider in northeast Florida and control rising costs. In 1998, John J Maher became CEO and ''Baptist/St. Vincents Health System'' had a 40% market share and had cut operating costs by $100 million in three years.<ref>Bryant-Friedland, Bruce: [http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/040298/met_2a1Mason.html "Hospital changes leadership"] Florida Times-Union, April 2, 1998</ref> However, the arrangement didn't last and a demerger occurred, with both groups going separate ways in 2000.<ref>Gordon, Mark: [http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/071401/bus_6681433.html "Companies need to be masters of their domain"] Florida Times-Union, July 14, 2001</ref>
==Facilities== St. Vincent's HealthCare includes 1,081 beds and 4,700 employees. The network's facilities and programs provide a full spectrum of care.
===The original=== St. Vincent's Hospital was begun in 1916 when the Daughters of Charity turned the DeSoto Sanitorium into the third hospital in Jacksonville. The institution grew from 42 beds into the [[St. Vincent's Medical Center Riverside]], with 528 beds. As the largest facility in the group, they offer the most diverse health care services in the system.<ref name=HIST />
===Expansion=== [[St. Vincent's Medical Center Southside]], a 313-bed [[acute care]] hospital, was purchased by St. Vincent's HealthCare in 2008 from [[Mayo Clinic Hospital]]. The present facility was opened in 1984, but St. Luke's Hospital was begun in 1873 and is the oldest private hospital in Florida.<ref>Clinton, Michael: [http://www.bizjournals.com/jacksonville/news/2012/01/05/st-lukes-hospital-changes-name.html "St. Luke's Hospital changes name"] Jacksonville Business Journal, January 5, 2012</ref>
===Elder care=== '''St. Catherine Labouré Manor''' is a [[chronic care]] facility on the campus of St. Vincent's Medical Center. The complex contains 240 beds, including a special unit for patients suffering [[dementia]] from [[Alzheimer's disease]].
Unlike the typical [[nursing home]], the staff tries to maintain a "home-like" atmosphere for the patients, who are called "residents". Many services are available in-house for the resident's convenience.
The ''Semmes Garden'' on the [[St. Johns River]], provides walkways through the landscaped grounds leading to fountains, gazebos, and a rose garden.
===Primary care=== '''St. Vincent's Primary Care''' is a network of more than 30 facilities and 80 physicians throughout the [[Jacksonville metropolitan area]], including [[Clay County, Florida|Clay]], [[Nassau County, Florida|Nassau]] and [[St. Johns County, Florida|St. Johns]] counties. Each is connected to the St. Vincent's Medical Centers.<ref>[http://www.jaxhealth.com/locations/svhc-primary-care/#St-Johns "St. Vincent's Primary Care"] St. Vincent's Healthcare website</ref>
===Laboratory testing=== There are eleven locations of '''Consolidated Laboratory Services''' (Consolidated Labs) in the Jacksonville area, including St. Vincent's Medical Center Riverside and St. Vincent's Medical Center Southside. They process blood and sample testing for all participants in the St. Vincent's HealthCare system and other facilities.<ref>[http://www.jaxhealth.com/locations/labs/?ignore=true "Find a location Labs"] St. Vincent's HealthCare website</ref>
===Transportation=== The network also includes the '''St. Vincent's Ambulance Service''', staffed by certified paramedics and EMTs and a fleet of 20 vans and Advanced Life Support ambulances for both emergency and non-emergency transport.<ref>[http://www.jaxhealth.com/services/advanced-patient-transportation/ "Advanced Patient Transportation"] St. Vincent's Healthcare website</ref>
===Prescriptions=== '''Consolidated Pharmacy Services''' and '''Seton Pharmacies''' were created to provide prescription drugs and medical equipment to St. Vincent HealthCare clients.<ref>[http://www.providerdata.com/jacksonville-fl/315680/consolidated-pharmacy-services-inc.aspx "Consolidated Pharmacy Services Inc"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120907100233/http://www.providerdata.com/jacksonville-fl/315680/consolidated-pharmacy-services-inc.aspx |date=September 7, 2012 }} Provider Data website</ref><ref>[http://www.manta.com/c/mmb52lq/seton-pharmacy "Seton Pharmacy"] Manta Business Info</ref>
===Clay County expansion=== Ground was broken in June, 2011 for '''St. Vincent's Medical Center Clay County''', the network's third acute-care hospital that opened in 2013. The 98-bed, 4-story building near [[Middleburg, Florida|Middleburg]] is expected to cost $110 million, but will be capable of expanding to 250 beds when needed. The company filed a "certificate of need" with the ''Agency for Health Care Administration'' in 2005, and it took several years of negotiation to reach a compromise with [[Memorial Hospital (Jacksonville, Florida)|Memorial Hospital]].<ref>Buehn, Debra W.: [http://jacksonville.com/community/clay/2011-06-30/story/st-vincents-breaks-ground-clay-hospital-due-2013 "St. Vincent's breaks ground in Clay, hospital due in 2013"] Florida Times-Union, June 30, 2011</ref>
===Name changes=== In early 2012, St. Vincent's HealthCare announced name changes for major facilities in their group. St. Vincent's Hospital became ''St. Vincent's Medical Center Riverside''; St. Luke's Hospital was renamed ''St. Vincent's Medical Center Southside''; and the new hospital under construction will be known as, ''St. Vincent's Medical Center Clay County''.<ref name=NAM>Patton, Charlie: [http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2012-01-05/story/st-lukes-becomes-st-vincents-medical-center-southside "St. Luke's becomes St. Vincent’s Medical Center Southside"] Florida Times-Union, January 5, 2012</ref>
==Outreach== ''St. Vincent's Community Health Outreach Ministries'' provides access to healthcare to poor children and families in the Jacksonville area. They sponsor and conduct many activities, including the School Nurse Program, St. Vincent's Mobile Health Outreach, the Seton Center for Women and Infants Health, and the Parish Nurse Ministry.<ref>Trussel, Ilyssa: [http://avenuesdeercreek.firstcoastnews.com/news/arts-culture/st-vincents-healthcare-foundation-announces-celebrity-chef-food-and-wine-tasting-event/56257 "St. Vincent’s HealthCare Foundation Announces Celebrity Chef for Food and Wine Tasting Event"] First Coast News, July 7, 2011</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.jaxhealth.com/}} * [http://www.ascensionhealth.org/about/main.asp Ascension Health web site]
{{Jacksonville Corporations}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:St. Vincent's Healthcare}} [[Category:Ascension Health]] [[Category:Companies based in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Hospital networks in the United States]] [[Category:Hospitals affiliated with the Catholic Church]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Privately held companies based in Florida]]

{{Infobox symptom | Name = Testicle pain | synonyms = Scrotal pain | Image = Illu testis surface.jpg | Caption = 1 - 6: [[Epididymis]] 7: [[Vas deferens]] | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = 003160 | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | eMedicine_mult = | MeshID = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''Testicular pain''', also known as '''scrotal pain''', occurs when part or all of either one or both [[testicles]] hurt. Pain in the [[scrotum]] is also often included. Testicular pain may be either short or long duration.
<!-- Cause --> Causes range from non serious muscular skeletal problems to [[Emergency medicine|emergency condition]]s such as [[Fournier's gangrene]] and [[testicular torsion]]. The diagnostic approach involves making sure no serious conditions are present. Testing may include [[ultrasound]] and blood tests.
<!-- Treatment --> Pain management is typically given with definitive management depending on the underlying cause.
==Definition== Testicular pain is when part or all of either one or both [[testicles]] hurt, the pain varies from male to male although it lasts around five minutes to an hour. Pain of the [[scrotum]] is often included. It may be either acute, subacute or chronic depending on its duration.
===Chronic scrotal pain=== [[Chronic scrotal pain]] (pain for greater than 3 months) may occur due to a number of underlying conditions.<ref name=PC2010/> It occurs in 15-19% of men post [[vasectomy]], due to infections such as [[epididymitis]], [[prostatitis]], and [[orchitis]], as well as [[varicocele]], [[hydrocele]], [[spermatocele]], [[polyarteritis nodosa]], [[testicular torsion]], previous surgery and trauma.<ref name=PC2010/> In 25% of cases the cause is never determined.<ref name=PC2010/> The pain can persist for a long and indefinite period of time following the [[vasectomy]], in which case it is termed [[post-vasectomy pain syndrome]] (PVPS).
==Differential diagnosis== {{See also|List of the causes of genital pain}} The differential diagnosis of testicular pain is broad and involves conditions from benign to life-threatening. The most common causes of pain in children presenting to the emergency room are [[testicular torsion]] (16%), torsion of a testicular appendage (46%), and [[epididymitis]] (35%).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lewis AG, Bukowski TP, Jarvis PD, Wacksman J, Sheldon CA |title=Evaluation of acute scrotum in the emergency department |journal=J. Pediatr. Surg. |volume=30 |issue=2 |pages=277–81; discussion 281–2 |date=February 1995 |pmid=7738751 |doi=10.1016/0022-3468(95)90574-X |url=}}</ref> In adults, the most common cause is epididymitis.
===Testicular torsion=== [[Testicular torsion]] usually presents with an acute onset of diffuse testicular pain and tenderness of less than 6 hrs of duration. There is often an absent or decreased [[cremasteric reflex]], the testicle is elevated, and often is horizontal.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Karmazyn B, Steinberg R, Kornreich L |title=Clinical and sonographic criteria of acute scrotum in children: a retrospective study of 172 boys |journal=Pediatr Radiol |volume=35 |issue=3 |pages=302–10 |date=March 2005 |pmid=15503003 |doi=10.1007/s00247-004-1347-9 |url= |displayauthors=etal }}</ref> It occurs annually in about 1 in 4000 males before 25 years of age,<ref name=PC2010>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wampler SM, Llanes M |title=Common scrotal and testicular problems |journal=Prim. Care |volume=37 |issue=3 |pages=613–26, x |date=September 2010 |pmid=20705202 |doi=10.1016/j.pop.2010.04.009 |url=}}</ref> is most frequent among adolescents ( 65% of cases presenting between 12 – 18 years of age ),<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Edelsberg JS, Surh YS |title=The acute scrotum |journal=Emerg. Med. Clin. North Am. |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=521–46 |date=August 1988 |pmid=3292226 |doi= |url=}}</ref> and is rare after 35 years of age.<ref name=AMP09/> Because it can lead to [[necrosis]] within a few hours, it is considered a surgical emergency.<ref name=AMP09/> Another version of this condition is a chronic illness called intermittent testicular torsion (ITT) which is characterized by recurrent rapid acute onset of pain in one testis which will temporarily assume a horizontal or elevated position in the scrotum similar to that of a full torsion followed by eventual spontaneous detortion and rapid solution of pain. Nausea or vomiting may also occur.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Genitourinary pain and inflammation: diagnosis and management |last=Uribe |first=Juan F. |edition= |volume= |year=2008 |origyear= |page=150 |pages= |publisher=Humana |place=Totowa, New Jersey |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SFhIAEdMs9IC&pg=PA149&dq=cremaster+spasm#v=onepage&q=cremaster%20spasm&f=false |accessdate= |isbn=978-1-58829-816-4 |oclc= |editor1-last=Potts |editor1-first=Jeannette M. }}</ref>
===Epididymitis and orchitis=== [[Epididymitis]] occurs when there is [[inflammation]] of the [[epididymis]] (a curved structure at the back of the [[testicle]]).<ref name=AMP09>{{cite journal |vauthors=Trojian TH, Lishnak TS, Heiman D |title=Epididymitis and orchitis: an overview |journal=Am Fam Physician |volume=79 |issue=7 |pages=583–7 |date=April 2009 |pmid=19378875 |doi= |url=}}</ref> This condition usually presents with gradual onset of varying degrees of pain, and the [[scrotum]] may be red, warm and swollen. It is often accompanied by symptoms of a [[urinary tract infection]], fever, and in over half of cases it presents in combination with [[orchitis]].<ref name=AMP09/> In those between the ages of 14 to 35 it is usually caused by either [[gonorrhea]] or [[Chlamydia infection|chlamydia]]. In people either older or younger ''[[E. coli]]'' is the most common bacterial infection.<ref name=AMP09/> Treatment involves the use of antibiotics.<ref name=AMP09/>
===Fournier's gangrene=== [[Fournier's gangrene]] ( an aggressive and rapidly spreading infection of the [[perineum]] ) usually presents with fever and intense pain. It is a rare condition but fatal if not identified and aggressively treated with a combination of [[debridement|surgical debridement]] and broad spectrum antibiotics.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Burch DM, Barreiro TJ, Vanek VW |title=Fournier's gangrene: be alert for this medical emergency |journal=JAAPA |volume=20 |issue=11 |pages=44–7 |date=November 2007 |pmid=18035764 |doi=10.1097/01720610-200711000-00020 |url=http://media.haymarketmedia.com/Documents/2/fournier1107_1568.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007042739/http://media.haymarketmedia.com/Documents/2/fournier1107_1568.pdf |archivedate=2009-10-07 |df= }}</ref>
===Others===
[[File:Segmental testicular infarction 112914968.jpg|thumb|Segmental testis infarction in a patient presenting with right testis pain.]]
Many other less common conditions can lead to testicular pain. These include [[inguinal hernia]]s, injury, [[hydrocele]]s, and [[varicocele]]s among others. [[Testicular cancer]] is usually painless.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/003160.htm |title=Testicle pain: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia |work=National Institute of Health|accessdate=}}</ref> Another potential cause is [[blue balls|epididymal hypertension]] (also known as "blue balls").<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Chalett JM, Nerenberg LT |title="Blue balls": A diagnostic consideration in testiculoscrotal pain in young adults: A case report and discussion |journal=Pediatrics |volume=106 |issue=4 |pages=843 |date=October 2000 |pmid=11015532 |doi= 10.1542/peds.106.4.843|url=}}</ref>
==Diagnostic approach==
===Physical findings=== The [[cremaster reflex]] (elevation of the testicle in response to stroking the upper inner thigh) is typically present in epididymitis but absent in testicular torsion as the testis is already elevated.<ref name=AMP09/> [[Prehn's sign]] ( the relief of pain with elevation ) though a classic physical exam finding has not been found to be reliable in distinguishing torsion from other causes of testicular pain such as [[epididymitis]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lavallee ME, Cash J |title=Testicular torsion: evaluation and management |journal=Curr Sports Med Rep |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=102–4 |date=April 2005 |pmid=15763047 |doi= 10.1097/01.CSMR.0000306081.13064.a2|url=}}</ref>
===Laboratory tests=== Useful tests that may help in the determination of the cause include a [[urinalysis]] (usually normal in testicular torsion). [[Pyuria]] and [[bacteriuria]] (white blood cells and bacteria in the urine) in patients with acute scrotum suggests an infectious cause such as epididymitis or orchitis and specific testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia should be done.<ref name=AMP09/> All people with chronic pain should be tested for [[gonorrhea]] and [[Chlamydia infection|chlamydia]].<ref name=PC2010/>
===Imaging=== [[medical ultrasonography|Ultrasound]] is useful if the cause is not certain based on the above measures.<ref name=Galejs>{{cite journal |author=Galejs LE |title=Diagnosis and treatment of the acute scrotum |journal=American Family Physician |volume=59 |issue=4 |pages=817–24 |date=February 1999 |pmid=10068706 |doi= |url=http://www.aafp.org/afp/990215ap/817.html}}</ref> If the diagnosis of torsion is certain, imaging should not delay definitive management such as physical maneuvers and surgery.<ref name=AMP09/>
