The tunnel will be 62 km long, 7 meters in diameter, and have a capacity of draining 150  m<sup>3</sup>/s wastewater.<ref name="WWF"/> All works on the tunnel system are expected to be completed in September 2012, at an expected cost of MXP 13 billion (approx. USD 1 billion).<ref>[http://www.conagua.gob.mx/CONAGUA07/NotaP/BOLETIN%20019-09.pdf Comunicado de Prensa de Conagua:En abril llegará el primero de tres escudos excavadores para iniciar la perforación del Túnel Emisor Oriente], February 14, 2009</ref>
Out of the discharge of the Emisor Oriental 23 m<sup>3</sup>/s would be treated in a planned wastewater treatment plant in [[El Salto, Hidalgo|El Salto]] in Hidalgo State to deliver water to the Tula Irrigation District.<ref name="Herrera">Cesar Herrera:Integrated Urban Water Resources Management - Mexico City Case Study, World Bank, February 2009</ref> Almost half of the investment (US$1.28 bn) will be for the construction of 6 wastewater treatment plants, the largest of which by far would be the Atotonilco (El Salto) plant.<ref name="Herrera" /> The US$900m contract to finance, build and operate the plant, allegedly the largest wastewater treatment plant in the world, was awarded in 2010 to a consortium led by the Spanish company Acciona.<ref>Global Water Intelligence:[http://www.globalwaterawards.com/ Global Water Awards 2011, Water Deal of the Year:Atotonilco WWTP financing], Retrieved on May 18, 2011</ref> The plant has a nominal treatment capacity of 23 m<sup>3</sup>/second, with an additional capacity for periods of high rainfall of 12 m<sup>3</sup>/second.<ref>{{cite web|title=Strategic Projects, 20 November 2012|url=http://www.conagua.gob.mx/english07/publications/StrategicProjects.pdf|publisher=Conagua, Department of Studies and Projects for drinking water and sewerage networks|accessdate=27 December 2013}}</ref>
The achievement of the program objective to both supply a growing population with water and to reduce pressure on the aquifer rests on the assumption that leakage will be reduced from 36% in 2005 to 25% in 2030.
'''Financing'''. The program is being financed from the following sources:
* '''Private sector''':The wastewater treatment plants are partly financed by the private sector through equity and debt under [[Build-Operate-Transfer]] (BOT) projects * '''Federal government''': The federal government directly finances some of the works, executed by Conagua * The '''Trust Fund No. 1928''', created by the Federal District, the State of Mexico and the Federal Government, will finance part of the works. The Trust Fund is replenished by the payments made by the Federal District and the State of Mexico for bulk water supplied to them by Conagua. It is administered financially by the public infrastructure Bank [[Banobras]], with Conagua acting as technical coordinator. The Trust Fund was modified in November 2008 to allow the financing of a broader range of projects.<ref>[http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/081127/35/gkhhid.html Conagua: Modificaciones a Fideicomiso 1928 facilitarán financiamiento de proyectos] Business News Americas, November 26, 2008</ref> * A '''Metropolitan Fund''', or National Infrastructure Fund, established at the national level for infrastructure investments, also finances some works * Loans from the state-owned investment bank Banobras.
=== Green Plan === [[File:Xochimilco.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Canals in [[Xochimilco]].]] Complementing the SARP, the Federal District launched in 2007 a 15-year Green Plan (''Plan Verde'') that aims at the sustainable development of the District along seven major axes, one of which is water. In 2008 it had a budget of US$6 million.<ref>[http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2007/08/31/index.php?section=capital&article=035n1cap Lanzan Plan Verde; en el primer año requerirá de $6 mil millones La Jornada] August 31, 2007</ref> Concerning water, it foresees reaching an equilibrium in the aquifer, reducing residential water use, reducing network losses, increasing the reuse and the treatment of wastewater, and the creation of parks around the lakes [[Tláhuac]] and [[Xochimilco]].<ref name="sma.df.gob.mx">[http://www.sma.df.gob.mx/sma/planverde/index.php?op=agua Plan Verde de la Ciudad de Mexico:Agua]</ref><ref name="Plan Verde de la Ciudad de Mexico">[http://planverde.org/diarioverde.php?idarticulo=7 Plan Verde de la Ciudad de Mexico]</ref>
More specifically, it foresees increased aquifer recharge through changes in land use and recharge wells; the [[Water metering|metering]] of all users by 2010 and making all users pay for water; identify and regularize illegal connections; the construction of tertiary wastewater treatment plants for the injection of treated wastewater into the [[aquifer]]. The Plan is expected to relieve pressure on the aquifer by 6.8 m<sup>3</sup>/s, including 3.3 m<sup>3</sup>/s by reducing leakage, 1 m<sup>3</sup>/s through water conservation and 2.5 m<sup>3</sup>/s by recharging groundwater with treated wastewater.<ref name="sma.df.gob.mx"/><ref name="Plan Verde de la Ciudad de Mexico"/>
These measures together, if successful, would reduce groundwater abstraction in Greater Mexico by 10% and the overdraft by 25%. They would still fall short from establishing an equilibrium between abstraction and recharge.
=== Enhanced private sector participation in the Federal District from 2010 onwards ===
In mid-2009 the finance chief of the Federal District, Mario Delgado, and the director general of the District's water company SACM announced that from mid-2010 onwards the District intends to enhance the participation of the private sector in water supply through concessions, under which the concessionnaires would buy bulk water and distribute it, thus providing an incentive to reduce [[non-revenue water]]. A total of four concession covering 11 of the District's 16 ''delegaciones'' would be bid out. The concessions would replace the existing four service contracts for metering and billing.
=== Rainwater harvesting === In 2003, the Water Law was enacted in Mexico City. It mandates that new building constructions accommodate practices of rainwater harvesting and promotes this practice in previous buildings.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.aldf.gob.mx/archivo-d0c1ac48ef930701568a2cbd52e7d29e.pdf|title=Water Law of Mexico City|last=Asamblea Legsilativa del Distrito Federal|first=|date=|website=ALDF|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2017}}</ref> It also states that in certain zones (Zone 1 and 2, according to the Construction Regulation of Mexico City), it is also obligatory that buildings have a [[Rainwater harvesting|stormwater harvest]] and recharge system, especially if near green areas, to promote [[Infiltration (hydrology)|infiltration]].<ref name=":4" /> Finally, it also states that recreational or free areas must be covered with permeable materials.
== Past responses to challenges ==
Past responses to the water challenges facing Greater Mexico City included an ambitious water conservation campaign initiated in 1989, as well as an increase in metering and a reduction in leakage through private sector participation begun in the early 1990s.
===Water conservation program in the 1990s===
In 1989, in parallel with the introduction of stricter national water efficiency standards for household appliances, Mexico City launched an ambitious program to replace conventional toilets (using 16 liters) with 6-liter models, replacing 350,000 toilets by 1991. The program also included a large-scale public information campaign and an increase in water tariffs.<ref>[[Sandra Postel]]:Last Oasis, 1992, p. 150-151</ref> The impact of the program is difficult to assess, since available figures on water consumption are difficult to compare over the years, because it is not clear whether they include water losses or not and whether they refer only to residential consumption or total consumption.
===Private sector participation in the Federal District since 1993===
[[Manuel Camacho Solís]], the [[Head of Government of the Federal District]] from 1988 to 1997 who was appointed by President [[Carlos Salinas]] (PRI), led the process of private sector participation in water supply in Mexico City in the early 1990s. At that time water revenues were extremely low, there was no functioning customer database, virtually no metering, and low bill collection efficiency. At least 22% of customers did not receive bills at all, partly because water connections were carried out by one department and billing by another which did not receive any information about water connections from the former.<ref name="Haggarty">Haggarty, Luke; Brook, Penelope; Zuluaga, Ana Maria: [http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/IW3P/IB/2001/11/22/000094946_01090705105228/Rendered/PDF/multi0page.pdf Thirst for reform ? private sector participation in providing Mexico City's water supply], Volume 1, 2001, World Bank Policy Research working paper No. WPS 2654</ref>
In November 1992 bids were launched, in March 1993 the results were announced and in November 10-year service contracts were signed with four firms, each for one block of the capital: * Block 1 with four boroughs in the North was awarded to SAPSA (Servicios de Agua Potable S.A.), constituted by the large Mexican construction firm Ingenieros Civiles Asociados (ICA), with the Bank [[Banamex]] and the French firm Générales Des Eaux ([[Vivendi]]), * Block 2 with three boroughs in the center was awarded to IASA, (Industrias del Agua S.A.), which included businessmen from Monterrey and the British firm [[Severn Trent]] * Block 3 with the impoverished Southeast was attributed to TECSA (Tecnología y Servicios de Agua S.A.), which included [[Bancomer]], Bufete Industrial, and the French firm Lyonnaise Des Eaux-Dumex ([[SUEZ]]-Ondeo Services) as well as the British firm [[Anglian Water]]. * Block 4 with five wealthy delegations in the Southwest was awarded to AMSA (Agua de México S.A.), which included the GUTSA group and the British firm North West Water International.
The process of private sector participation foresaw three phases: *First phase (1994–1995): Updating of the user registry. *Second phase (1995–1998): Meter reading, billing, and some aspects of collection. *Third phase (1998–2003): Leak detection and repair, extension and rehabilitation of the secondary distribution network.
The city remained in charge of the water production, treatment and main distribution infrastructure, as well as some aspects of collection and the sanitation infrastructure. It also set water tarirfs. The first two phases were successful. Under the contracts the number of metered connections increased from virtually none in 1994 to up to 1,264,500 in 2002, reaching more than 90% of all users.<ref name="Tortajada" /> The third phase, however, was less successful.<ref name="Tortajada">{{cite web|url=http://hdr.undp.org/en/reports/global/hdr2006/papers/Tortajada%20C.pdf|title=Reports|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.imacmexico.org/ev_es.php?ID=26291_201&ID2=DO_TOPIC Eugenia Gutiérrez y Arturo Ramírez:Agua privada en la Ciudad de México], Revista Rebeldía # 28, Febrero 2005</ref><ref>M.C. Martínez Omaña, La gestión privada de un servicio público:el caso del agua en el Distrito Federal, 1988-1995, Mexico City 2002, {{ISBN|968-856-996-8}}</ref>
Between 1994 and 1998 the amount billed increased by almost 30% in real terms. But the amount collected stagnated, since private operators were not in charge of bill collection. Collection efficiency actually declined from 84% to 69%<ref name="Haggarty"/> The service itself remained unchanged in terms of intermittency of supply and water quality, since these aspects were not part of the contracts. Tariffs and cost recovery also remained unchanged, with revenues covering less than 75% of operating costs.<ref name="Haggarty" /> The third phase of turning over increased responsibility to the private sector was abandoned after the PRD won elections in 1997 and renegotiated the contracts.<ref name="Haggarty" />
The PRD mayor [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]] (2000–2005) renewed the contracts in 2004 for another five years,.<ref>[http://www.archives-suez.com/en/presse/press/releases-archives/archives/?communique_id=746 SUEZ Environnement has its water services contracts renewed for 5 years by Mexico City], October 13, 2004</ref> His successor [[Alejandro Encinas Rodríguez]] initially announced that the District would terminate the contracts even before they expired, but his successor [[Marcelo Ebrard]] actually extended them for another year until mid-2010.
=== Valley of Mexico Sanitation Project ===
In 1996 the [[Inter-American Development Bank]] (IDB) approved a US$365 million loan for the Valley of Mexico Sanitation Project, in parallel with a loan of US$410 million by the [[Foreign aid institutions of Japan|Overseas Economic Cooperation Fund]] of Japan. The IDB project, which closed in 2005, foresaw the construction of 4 wastewater treatment plants with a total capacity of 74.5 m<sup>3</sup>/s as well as the rehabilitation of drainage systems.<ref>[http://www.iadb.org/projects/project.cfm?id=ME0179&lang=en IDB:ME0179 : Sanitation for the Valley of Mexico]</ref>
== Further reading ==
Cecilia Tortajada: Water Management in Mexico City Metropolitan Area, in: International Journal of Water Resources Development, Vol. 22, No. 2, p. 353-376, June 2006, Third World Centre for Water Management, Mexico.
== See also ==
*[[Valley of Mexico#Draining the basin and water issues|Drainage of the Valley of Mexico]] *[[Water supply and sanitation in Mexico]] *[[Water resources management in Mexico]]
== References == {{reflist|26em}}
== External links == *[http://www.cna.gob.mx/conagua/Default.aspx National Water Commission (Spanish)] *[http://www.comsoc.df.gob.mx/ Mexico City government (Spanish)] *[http://www.sacm.df.gob.mx/sacm/ Water utility of the Federal District (SACM) (Spanish)] *[http://www.edomex.gob.mx/portal/page/portal/caem Mexico State:Ministry of Water and Public Works-State Water Commission (Spanish)] * [[UNESCO]]: World Water Assessment Program - Case Study:[http://www.unesco.org/water/wwap/wwdr/wwdr2/case_studies/pdf/mexico.pdf Sustainable urban water management in the State of Mexico], 2006
[[Category:Mexico City metropolitan area]] [[Category:Valley of Mexico]] [[Category:Water in Mexico]] [[Category:Water resources management]] [[Category:Water supply and sanitation in Mexico]]

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/67.186.168.218|67.186.168.218]] to version by Runawayangel. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3549281) (Bot)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} [[File:Goulburn water restrictions.jpg|thumb|Level 5 water restrictions in [[Goulburn]] in 2006.]] [[File:PejarDam14November2005.JPG|thumb|Pejar dam, the water supply for Goulburn in November 2005]] '''Water restrictions''' have been enacted in many cities and regions in [[Australia]], which is the Earth's driest inhabited continent,{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/drought/livedrought.shtml|title=Living with Drought 20/3/2011|publisher=}} in response to chronic water shortages resulting from the widespread [[Drought in Australia|drought]]. Depending upon the location, these can include restrictions on watering [[lawn]]s, using [[irrigation sprinkler|sprinkler systems]], washing [[vehicle]]s, hosing [[Pavement (material)|pavement]], refilling [[swimming pool]]s, etc. Overpopulation, [[Climate change in Australia|evidence of drying climates]], coupled with corresponding reductions in the supply of drinking water has led various state governments to consider alternative water sources to supplement existing sources, and to implement "water inspectors" who can issue penalties to those who waste water. As of July 2007, some areas and towns have no [[Outdoor water-use restriction|water restrictions]], including the [[Northern Territory]], Regional [[Tasmania]], [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]], [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]] and [[Dubbo]]. There are also a few parts of Australia where the water storage levels are at or close to 100%, such as [[Taree, New South Wales|Taree]]. Many states describe the different levels of water restrictions in terms of "stages": starting at Stage 1, for the least restrictive, going up as far as Stage 8. The highest level reached in the current drought has been stage 7 for [[Kingaroy, Queensland|Kingaroy]]. There are different definitions given to each "stage" in different States. == Water restrictions by state or territory == === Australian Capital Territory === There are presently four stages of temporary water restrictions which can be imposed by [[ACTEW Corporation]]:{{cite web|url=http://www.actew.com.au/publications/TemporaryWaterRestrictionsScheme.pdf|title=SCHEME OF TEMPORARY RESTRICTIONS ON THE USE OF WATER FROM ACTEW CORPORATION WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! !! Stage 1 !! Stage 2 !! Stage 3 !! Stage 4 |- !Sprinklers and irrigation: |Alternate days, 7-10am & 7-10pm |Drippers only, 7-10am & 7-10pm |colspan=2|No reticulation |- !Hand-watering gardens and lawns: |No restrictions |Alternate days, 7-10am & 7-10pm |No watering lawns; watering plants alternate days, 7-10am & 7-10pm |[[Greywater]] only |- !Swimming pools: |colspan=2|No emptying or filling; Topping-up allowed |colspan=2|No topping-up, emptying or filling |- !Car washing: |Once a week, or at commercial car wash |Once a month, or at commercial car wash |Only at commercial car washes |No car washing |- !Window cleaning: |Only with bucket or high-pressure, low-volume cleaner |colspan=3|No window cleaning |} [[Canberra]] was subject to Stage 1 restrictions from 1 November 2005, which were increased to Stage 2 after a year on 1 November 2006. The continuing drought led to a further increase to Stage 3 from 16 December 2006; the restrictions were maintained at Stage 3 throughout 2007 and 2008. From 1 November 2010 Canberra moved to Permanent Water Saving Rules due to heavy rain bringing water storages close to capacity. === New South Wales === The different classification levels of water restrictions in New South Wales vary widely, and are set by the different authorities responsible for water throughout the state. ==== Sydney ==== The following Levels have been used by [[Sydney Water]] to describe the different stages of water restrictions it has imposed:[http://www.sydneywater.com.au/SavingWater/WaterRestrictions/WhenWereWaterRestrictionsIntroduced.cfm When were water restrictions introduced]{{cite web|url=http://www.sydneywater.com.au/SavingWater/WaterRestrictions/|title=Water Restrictions|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! !! Level 1 !! Level 2 !! Level 3 |- !Sprinklers and irrigation: |colspan=3|No sprinklers at any time; drippers only |- !Hand-watering gardens and lawns: |No restrictions |3 times weekly,
before 9am or after 5pm |2 times weekly,
before 10am or after 4pm |- !Swimming pools: |No restrictions |colspan=2|No filling pools over 10,000L without permit |- !Hard surfaces: |colspan=3|No hosing hard surfaces (paths, driveways, cars, floors and buildings) |} {{wikinews|New South Wales water supply problems continue}} Falling dam levels prompted Sydney Water to impose Level 1 water restrictions on the Sydney area from 1 October 2003.{{cite news | author = Stephanie Peatling |author2=Jacqueline Maley | title = Water-watchers Stalk The Streets As We Learn To Drip The Lawn | publisher = [[Sydney Morning Herald]] | page = 2 | date = 1 October 2003 | accessdate = 2008-03-12 }} When these restrictions failed to stem the reduction in the city's water supplies as a result of continuing drought, and with dam levels dropping below 50 per cent, Level 2 water restrictions were introduced from 1 June 2004. Further reductions in dam levels to below 40 per cent of capacity led to an increase to Level 3 water restrictions from 1 June 2005. Level 3 water restrictions were in place as of February 2008. Since June 2009, though, Sydney Water replaced water restrictions with Water Wise Rules. The Rules are: * All hoses must now have a trigger nozzle. * Hand held hoses, sprinklers and watering systems may be used only before 10 am and after 4 pm on any day - to avoid the heat of the day * No hosing of hard surfaces such as paths and driveways. Washing vehicles is allowed. * Fire hoses may be used for fire fighting activities only. To deal with its water shortage, New South Wales has followed the same path as Western Australia, announcing a new desalination plant for [[Sydney]] to cost $1.3 billion.[http://www.smh.com.au/news/scorchedearth/nsw-goes-against-flow-on-water-law/2007/01/02/1167500125064.html NSW goes against flow on water law], Sydney Morning Herald Sydney Water has imposed fines of $200 for violations of the rules for individuals, $500 for businesses, and $2,200 for water theft.[http://www.sydneywater.com.au/Water4Life/WaterWise/ Sydney Water - Water Wise Rules] Rules are enforced by Sydney Water staff through random checks. ==== Regional NSW ==== As different towns in regional New South Wales take their drinking water from different sources, different levels of water restrictions apply. The levels or stages which apply in certain towns are as follows: *[[Albury, New South Wales|Albury]] – no restrictions *[[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]] – no restrictions *[[Cobar, New South Wales|Cobar]] – stage 5 *[[Dubbo]] – no restrictions *[[Gosford, New South Wales|Gosford]] – stage 4 from 1 October 2006 *[[Goulburn, New South Wales|Goulburn]] had Stage 5 water restrictions imposed from 1 October 2004, and went on to win a National Water Conservation Award for Excellence due to the water which had been conserved.[http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/2006/s1800197.htm Goulburn wins water-saving award], ABC News 29 November 2006 From 5 July 2007, Goulburn relaxed its water restrictions to Level 3.{{cite web|url=http://goulburn.local-e.nsw.gov.au/roads/1439/5103.html|title=Goulburn - Level 3 Water Restrictions|publisher=}} *[[Griffith, New South Wales|Griffith]] – stage 2 introduced on 27 November 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.griffith.nsw.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=467&p=1|title=Griffith City Council - Water Restrictions|publisher=}} *[[Leeton, New South Wales|Leeton]] – level 3 introduced on 9 October 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.leeton.nsw.gov.au/|title=Leeton Shire Council|website=www.leeton.nsw.gov.au}} but lowered to level 2 on 1 November 2008{{cite news | last = Braham | first = Emily | title = Level 2 change on way | work = Fairfax Media | publisher = The Irrigator | date = 24 October 2008 | url = http://leeton.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/general/level-2-change-on-way/1341814.aspx | accessdate = 2008-11-08}} *[[Orange, New South Wales|Orange]] – level 5a from early 2010 *[[Port Macquarie]] – stage 1 from September 2006 *[[Taree, New South Wales|Taree]] – summer water saving restrictions *[[Wagga Wagga]] – Permanent Water Conservation Measure http://www.rwcc.nsw.gov.au/news/article/permanent-conservation-measure === Northern Territory === {{expand section|date=October 2014}} Currently, no water restrictions apply in [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]]. === Queensland === Some of the details of the different stages of water restrictions which apply in Queensland for the residential sector are as follows:{{cite web|url=http://www.qwc.qld.gov.au/Water+restrictions|title=Qld Water Commission : Restrictions|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! !! Stage 1 !! Stage 2 !! Stage 3 !! Stage 4 !! Stage 5 !! Stage 6 !! Stage 7 |- !Reticulation sprinklers: |3 days/week |rowspan=2 colspan=5|No sprinklers |rowspan=9|No external water use without permit |- !Sprinkler times: |4–8am & 4–8pm |- !Hose watering of gardens: |colspan=2|3 days/week |rowspan=2 colspan=4|No hosing |- !Hose watering times: |4–8am & 4–8pm |Before 7am & after 7pm |- !Bucket/watering can watering times: |colspan=3|Any time |3 days/week;
4–8am & 4–8pm |colspan=2|No watering lawns;
Otherwise 3 days/week, 4–7pm |- !Pool filling: |colspan=3|Any time |colspan=3|Requires approval |- !Topping-up pools: |4–8am & 4–8pm,
3 days/week |colspan=2|7pm–7am,
3 days/week |4–8am & 4–8pm,
3 days/week |4–7pm,
3 days/week |Log required |- !Hosing hard surfaces: |colspan=6|Prohibited at all times |- !Car/window washing: |colspan=2|Hose or bucket |colspan=2|Bucket only |colspan=2|Bucket only, to wash mirrors, lights & windows |} Although some regions of Queensland have had traditionally high rainfalls, some regions of Queensland have been subject to the toughest water restrictions in place in Australia. The highest level of water restrictions reached the drought was stage 7 for [[Kingaroy, Queensland|Kingaroy]]. [[Toowoomba, Queensland|Toowoomba]], [[Brisbane]] and South East Queensland reached Level 6 restrictions. On 13 May 2005, 13 local councils in southeast Queensland, including those in Brisbane, agreed to impose Stage 1 water restrictions, due to drying dams.{{cite news | author = Staff writer | title = Tap tightened on water use | work = [[The Courier-Mail]] | publisher = [[News Limited]] | page = 1 | date = 13 May 2005 | accessdate = 2008-03-17 }} These restrictions were increased to Stage 2 from 3 October 2005, which at the time were described as the "toughest water restrictions in southeast Queensland's history", except the Gold Coast which had been on Stage 5 restrictions since 2004.{{cite news | first = Jennifer | last = Dudley | title = Water crackdown toughest yet | work = [[The Courier-Mail]] | publisher = [[News Limited]] | page = 11 | date = 1 October 2005 | accessdate = 2008-03-17 }} Stage 3 water restrictions were imposed on the region from 13 June 2006 amid projections that water storage levels would drop to 5% within 26 months.{{cite news | first = Chris | last = Griffith | title = Water crisis to hit new depths | work = [[The Courier-Mail]] | publisher = [[News Limited]] | page = 3 | date = 13 June 2006 | accessdate = 2008-03-17 }} Water restrictions continued to increase, to Stage 4 from 1 November 2006,[http://www.qwc.qld.gov.au/tiki-read_article.php?articleId=41 Level 4 restrictions start 1 November], Queensland Water Commission stage 5 from 10 April 2007, and up to Stage 6 from 23 November 2007. The [[Queensland Water Commission]] has relaxed water restrictions, with the introduction of High Level Water restrictions as of 31 July 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.qwc.qld.gov.au/myfiles/uploads/high%20level%20restrictions/high%20level%20restrictions.pdf|title=High level restrictions|accessdate=13 February 2015}} Other towns and regions of Queensland are subject to different levels of water restrictions, as set out below: *[[Cairns]] – Level 1 restrictions from October 2002 till about January 2004. *[[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]] – stage 6 from 23 November 2007, stage 5 from 10 April 2007, stage 4 from 1 November 2006. The Hinze Dam, which is the Gold Coast's main water supply reached 100% in January 2008 and the coast now has no water restrictions. *[[Kingaroy]] – Stage 7 from 1 October 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.kingaroy.qld.gov.au/pdfs/200709waternewsletter.pdf|title=Water Restriction Document from Kingaroy Council|publisher=}} *[[Toowoomba]] – stage 6 from 23 November 2007, stage 5 from 26 September 2006. In 2006, the town council proposed the use of [[Sewage treatment|recycled wastewater]] to supplement town water from dams, however the scheme was rejected by the town's population and the town has since resorted to drilling [[Artesian aquifer|artesian]] and sub-artesian bores as an alternative source of drinking water. *[[Townsville]] – stage 2 from 15 November 2006, stage 1 from 12 February 2007 Source: [http://www.qwc.qld.gov.au/tiki-index.php?page=Water%20restrictions Queensland Water Restrictions], Queensland Water Commission === South Australia === The different levels of residential water restrictions which have been applied to different regions of South Australia by [[SA Water]] are as follows: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! !! Permanent Water Conservation Measures !! Eyre Peninsula !! Level 2 !! Level 3 |- !Reticulation sprinklers: |5pm–10am (6pm–10am in [[Daylight saving in Australia|DST]]) |6pm–8am (8pm–8am in [[Daylight saving in Australia|DST]]) |8pm–8am, 3 days/week. Sporting grounds and public facilities 2 days/week. |Prohibited |- !Hand-held hose watering and drippers: |colspan=3|Any time |1 day/week with trigger nozzle, 6–9am or 5–8pm |- !Bucket/watering cans: |colspan=4|Any time |- !Swimming pools and Spas: |No restrictions |colspan=3|No filling or emptying without permit. New pools or spas must have a cover. |- !Fountains and ponds: |No restrictions |colspan=3|Must not be operated and can not be topped up unless they support fish. |- !Car washing: |colspan=2|Bucket, commercial car wash or hose with trigger nozzle only |colspan=2|Bucket or commercial car wash only |- !Hard surfaces: |colspan=4|No washing or hosing down hard surfaces |} Different water restrictions levels apply to different parts of the state, depending upon the source of drinking water used in that region. SA Water have produced a [http://www.sawater.com.au/NR/rdonlyres/A1700B03-0CC3-401C-B338-C94F8C297DD4/0/WaterRestrictions_lvl3.pdf map] showing the current areas of water restrictions. ==== Areas using Murray River water ==== [[Adelaide]] and much of south-eastern South Australia takes its drinking water from the [[Murray River]]. Permanent water conservation measures were put into place in this region in 2003,{{cite news | first = Greg | last = Kelton | title = Words flow even if the water doesn't | work = [[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] | publisher = [[News Limited]] | page = 32 | date = 14 October 2006 | accessdate = 2008-03-17 }} and as a result of the most severe drought to hit the region since the 1940s, Level 2 water restrictions were imposed from 22 October 2006 on those areas (including metropolitan Adelaide) which use water from the Murray River.{{cite news | first = Greg | last = Kelton | title = LAST DROPS Tougher water controls | work = [[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] | publisher = [[News Limited]] | page = 1 | date = 13 October 2006 | accessdate = 2008-03-17 }} Even lower inflows to the Murray River over the course of 2006 led to the even tougher Level 3 water restrictions being imposed on the region from 1 January 2007,{{cite news | first = Clare | last = Peddie | title = RESTRICTIONS New round of cuts in force on Monday Record low flows into the Murray | work = [[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] | publisher = [[News Limited]] | page = 35 | date = 30 December 2006 | accessdate = 2008-03-17 }} which remain in place. ==== Other areas ==== The [[Eyre Peninsula]] draws most of its drinking water from underground basins,{{cite news | author = Greg Kelton & Nathan Cross | title = Constraints on gardens, parks and washing cars Peninsula hit with water restrictions. | work = [[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] | publisher = [[News Limited]] | page = 7 | date = 5 December 2002 | accessdate = 2008-03-17 }} which progressively became depleted through drought and high consumption, prompting the State Government to introduce water restrictions on the entire region from 6 December 2002, apart from [[Whyalla]]. The water restrictions for the peninsula remain in force as of 2008. Conversely, the areas in the south east of the State, south of the town of [[Keith, South Australia|Keith]], are subject to the permanent water conservation measures. Other areas in the state are not subject to water restrictions. These areas include [[Murray Mallee]], areas north of [[Port Augusta, South Australia|Port Augusta]], [[Kangaroo Island]], [[Cockburn, South Australia|Cockburn]], [[Hawker, South Australia|Hawker]], [[Melrose, South Australia|Melrose]], Ororoo, [[Parachilna, South Australia|Parachilna]], [[Quorn, South Australia|Quorn]], Warooka, Wilmington, [[Terowie, South Australia|Terowie]], Yunta, Olary and Manna Hill. The different levels of residential water restrictions which have been applied to different regions of South Australia by SA Water are as follows: Permanent Water Conservation Measures Eyre Peninsula Level 2 Level 3 Reticulation sprinklers: 5pm–10am (6pm–10am in DST) 6pm–8am (8pm–8am in DST) 8pm–8am, 3 days/week Prohibited Hand-held hose watering and drippers: Any time 1 day/week with trigger nozzle, 6–9am or 5– === Tasmania === Usually, there are no water restrictions for domestic consumption. Periodically, however, restrictions will be placed on how water can be used in domestic, commercial or rural areas. Examples[http://www.southernwatertas.com.au/ArticleDocuments/120/Water Restrictions Policy.pdf.aspx Stages of Water Restrictions] of such restrictions are: *watering with a hose is permitted but not using a fixed sprinkler system, *being able to use sprinkler systems only during certain hours, *the initial wetting and final rinsing of a car may be done with the hose but washing must be done using a bucket, *washing a car is permitted using a bucket of water but not using the hose, *watering of sports grounds allowed only during certain hours, *watering stock is acceptable but not irrigating.[http://www.dpiw.tas.gov.au/inter,nsf/WebPages/JMUY-4YB2FZ?open Restrictions] Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment One purpose of such restrictions is to keep the dam levels up and ensure adequate water pressure for the fire department's needs in the event of fires. === Victoria === The different stages of water restrictions which apply in different areas of Victoria are based upon the Victorian Uniform Drought Water Restriction Guidelines,{{cite web|url=http://www.vicwater.org.au/uploads/Water%20Restrictions/Final%20Version%20Uniform%20Drought%20Water%20Restriction%20Guidelines.pdf|title=Victorian Uniform Drought Water Restriction Guidelines|publisher=}} however they have been modified by the inclusion of a "Stage 3a", to reduce the likelihood of needing to impose Stage 4 restrictions in metropolitan Melbourne.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourwater.vic.gov.au/ourwater/water_restrictions/stage_3a|title=Our Water, Our Future - Stage 3a Water Restrictions|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! !! Stage 1 !! Stage 2 !! Stage 3 !! Stage 3a !! Stage 4 |- !Watering lawns: |Manual: Any time, any day with the use of a trigger-nozzle hose or bucket. Automatic: 6am–10am and 6pm–10pm on alternating days |colspan=3|Watering lawns is banned |rowspan=5|All outside watering banned |- !Reticulation watering days: |colspan=2|Alternating days |colspan=2|Drippers only, 2 days/week |- !Automatic reticulation: |colspan=3|Midnight–4am |Midnight–2am |- !Manual reticulation: |colspan=3|6–8am & 8–10pm |6–8am |- !Hose watering/ buckets/ watering cans: |colspan=2|Any time |2 days/week, 6–8am & 8–10pm |2 days/week, 6–8am |- !Hosing hard surfaces: |colspan=5|Banned at all times |- !Car washing: |Bucket/high pressure cleaner or trigger nozzle hose |Bucket/high pressure cleaner only |colspan=3|Buckets only to clean windows, mirrors and lights |- !Swimming pools: |Filling or topping up pools/spas up to 2000 L permitted. Over 2000 L, permit required |colspan=3|No filling |} The status of water restrictions in different regions of Victoria is as set out below: *[[Bairnsdale, Victoria|Bairnsdale]] – now off water restrictions and on permanent water saving rules as of 24 August 2007 *[[Ballarat]] – stage 3 from 1 January 2010, stage 1 from 1 August 2010.(23 June 2010). [http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/06/23/2934809.htm Ballarat water restrictions eased]. Jacqui Peake. ABC News Online. Australian Broadcasting Corporation. *[[Bendigo]] area – stage 3 from 1 January 2009 *[[Broadford, Victoria|Broadford]] – stage 4 from 1 February 2007 *[[Geelong]] – stage 3 from March 2010, stage 1 from 3 October 2010 *Central [[Gippsland]] – All Towns on Permanent Water Saving Rules *Coongulla & Glenmaggie – stage 4 from 24 February 2007 *[[Horsham, Victoria|Horsham]] – Stage 1 from 14 October 2009 *[[Mansfield, Victoria|Mansfield]] area – stage 4 for Mansfield from 16 December 2006; other areas nearby on stage 1 and 2 *[[Melbourne]] – stage 1 from 28 August 2006,[http://www.southeastwater.com.au/sewl/index.asp?link_id=1.1575 Stage 1 water restrictions introduced], South East Water stage 2 from 1 November 2006,[http://www.southeastwater.com.au/sewl/index.asp?link_id=1.1591 Stage 2 Water Restrictions From November], South East Water stage 3 from 1 January 2007, Stage 3a from 1 April 2007, Stage 3 from 2 April 2010, stage 2 from 1 September 2010. As of 1 December 2012, Melbourne was taken off water restriction stages, but new permanent water restrictions were implemented.{{cite web|url=http://www.melbournewater.com.au|title=Home - Melbourne Water|website=www.melbournewater.com.au}}[http://www.melbournewater.com.au/content/water_conservation/water_restrictions/water_restrictions.asp?bhcp=1] *[[Mildura]] – now off water restrictions and on permanent water saving rules as of 3 October 2010 *[[Omeo, Victoria|Omeo]] – stage 2 from 11 December 2006 *North east region – [[Bright, Victoria|Bright]] reverted to stage 2 and Springhurst reverted to stage 1 on 10 September 2007. Most of the Murray towns went to Stage 4 on 1 July 2007 (e.g. Wodonga, Yarrawonga, Rutherglen etc.), and on 11 July 2007 Devenish, St James and Tungamah went to stage 3. As of 2010, most towns/cities in the North East have moved to Permanent Water Saving Rules thanks to flooding rain over winter and spring. Source: [http://www.dpi.vic.gov.au/dpi/vro/map_documents.nsf/pages/water_urban_rest_aug06 Report and map] explaining the restrictions in Victoria as of September 2006 and [http://www.ourwater.vic.gov.au/monitoring/monthly/water_restrictions/table_of_urban_water_restrictions Water restrictions as of 2010] === Western Australia === The different stages of water restrictions which can currently be applied in Western Australia are as follows:[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/wa/consol_reg/waub2007297/sch2.html Schedule 2], Water Agencies (Water Use) By-Laws 2007 (WA) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! !! Stage 1 !! Stage 2 !! Stage 3 !! Stage 4 !! Stage 5 !! Stage 6 !! Stage 7 |- !Reticulation sprinklers: |Daily |Alternate days |3 times/week |Twice weekly |Once weekly |colspan=2 rowspan=2|No sprinklers |- !Sprinkler times: |colspan=5|Before 9.00am or after 6.00pm |- !Hose watering of gardens: |colspan=6|Any time |No hose watering |- !Swimming pools: |No restriction |colspan=3|No over-filling |colspan=2|No topping-up |No filling |- !Car washing: |colspan=6|No restriction |Bucket only |} [[File:Canning Dam, Perth (3).jpg|thumb|right|[[Canning Dam]], one of Perth's major dams, at 34.4% of capacity]] [[File:Victoria Dam, Perth (1).jpg|thumb|right|[[Victoria Dam (Western Australia)|Victoria Dam]], at 30.6% of capacity]] Water restrictions have been employed in various Western Australian towns when poor rainfall has led to water shortages. For instance, in the summer of 1977-1978, [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] was subject to a total sprinkler ban.{{cite news | first = Ben | last = Ruse | title = Total sprinkler ban warning | publisher = [[The West Australian]] | date = 13 October 2001 | quote = But Minister Assisting the Treasurer Nick Griffiths said a total ban - not seen since 1977 - would be put in place only if people were not able to save water. }} [[Newman, Western Australia|Newman]] and [[Nullagine, Western Australia|Nullagine]] experienced water restrictions from 1991 and 1992 onwards as the result of drought.{{cite news | first = Carmelo | last = Amalfi | title = Drought Towns 'used To Water Restrictions' | publisher = [[The West Australian]] | page = 31 | date = 5 October 1996 | accessdate = 2008-03-12 }} Similarly, the resort towns of [[Yallingup, Western Australia|Yallingup]] and [[Dunsborough, Western Australia|Dunsborough]] experienced water restrictions in 1997 during a heatwave,{{cite news | first = Carmelo | last = Amalfi |author2=Pennells, Steve | title = Heatwave Runs Course | publisher = [[The West Australian]] | page = 11 | date = 4 January 1997 | accessdate = 2008-03-12 }} and [[Kalgoorlie|Kalgoorlie-Boulder]] had temporary water restrictions imposed during 1998 due to shortages in its reservoirs (which contain water pumped through the [[Goldfields Water Supply Scheme]]). {{cite news | first = Kristen | last = Watts | title = Water restrictions in Kalgoorlie-Boulder may be lifted this week | publisher = [[The West Australian]] | page = 26 | date = 31 March 1998 | accessdate = 2008-03-12 }} A Stage 1 ban on using reticulation sprinklers between 9.00am and 6.00pm was imposed on [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] residents in 1996,{{cite news | first = Carmelo | last = Amalfi | title = Winter Rain Fails To Fill WA Dams | publisher = [[The West Australian]] | page = 7 | date = 19 August 1998 | accessdate = 2008-03-12 | quote = The sprinkler ban was introduced in 1996, the first restriction on Perth's water since the summer of 1977-78. }} and remains in place to this day. This was the first water restriction imposed on the state's most populous city since the total sprinkler ban in 1978. From September 2001, users of the Integrated Water Supply Scheme (covering Perth, its surrounds and towns on the [[Goldfields Water Supply Scheme|Goldfields pipeline]]) were subject to Stage 4 restrictions, only permitted to use reticulation sprinklers two days per week, according to a roster. The town of [[Northampton, Western Australia|Northampton]] in the Mid-West encountered a water shortage in 2006 where its underground aquifer could not meet demand. Stage 5 watering restrictions were imposed,{{cite news | first = Suellen | last = Jerrard | title = Tough sprinkler bans hit SW towns | publisher = [[The West Australian]] | page = 42 | date = 12 October 2006 | accessdate = 2008-03-12 | quote = One-day-a-week sprinkler restrictions have already been imposed in Northampton, in the Mid-West }} and the [[Water Corporation]] resorted to carting tankers of water to the town to maintain the supply.{{cite news | first = Suellen | last = Jerrard | title = Country in crisis as water tanks run dry | publisher = [[The West Australian]] | page = 13 | date = 18 December 2006 | accessdate = 2008-03-12 | quote = The Water Corporation has started carting water to Northampton, one of the areas hardest hit by the drought, because its ground water aquifer could not meet demand. }} Stage 4 water restrictions were imposed in the South-West towns of [[Bridgetown, Western Australia|Bridgetown]], [[Balingup, Western Australia|Balingup]], [[Boyup Brook, Western Australia|Boyup Brook]], [[Hester, Western Australia|Hester]], [[Kirup, Western Australia|Kirup]], [[Greenbushes, Western Australia|Greenbushes]] and [[Mullalyup, Western Australia|Mullalyup]] from 13 October 2006. On 1 October 2007, water restrictions were expanded to cover the entire state, including those towns serviced by utilities other than the [[Water Corporation]]. Under the new system, all areas of the state in the region south of Kalbarri and Kalgoorlie (including Perth and most of the state's population) which use scheme water are subject to Stage 4 restrictions.[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/wa/consol_reg/waub2007297/s6.html reg 6], Water Agencies (Water Use) By-Laws 2007 (WA) Areas north of the dividing line are subject to Stage 2 restrictions.[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/wa/consol_reg/waub2007297/s5.html reg 5], Water Agencies (Water Use) By-Laws 2007 (WA) Furthermore, whereas the water restrictions had previously only restricted the use of mains water to water gardens and lawns by sprinkler, under the new water restrictions unlicensed [[Borehole|bore]] operators in Perth and its surrounds are restricted to watering their gardens three times per week. [http://www.waterwisewaysforwa.com.au/go/secondary-navigation/faqs Waterwise Ways for WA - FAQs] This was to slow the depletion of underground aquifers from which Perth sources much of its drinking water. Around November 2013 the water restrictions were removed from the Water Agencies (Water Use) Bylaws 2010 and added to the Water Services Regulations 2013 [http://www.slp.wa.gov.au/gazette/gazette.nsf/searchgazette/7D00684E37ECBC8748257C22000DB0CE/$file/gg203.pdf], Western Australian Government Gazette 14 November 2013[http://www.slp.wa.gov.au/legislation/statutes.nsf/main_mrtitle_11731_homepage.html], Water Agencies (Water Use) Bylaws 2010[http://www.slp.wa.gov.au/legislation/statutes.nsf/main_mrtitle_13117_homepage.html], Water Services Regulations 2013 - See part 5 and schedules 1, 2 and 3 Efforts are being made to secure alternative water sources to ease water shortages in the Integrated Water Supply Scheme. Integral to the Government's strategy is the construction of desalination plants to service Perth. One has already been constructed in [[Kwinana Desalination Plant|Kwinana]], which supplies 17% of the city's water consumption and is the largest desalination plant in both the [[Southern hemisphere|Southern]] and [[Eastern hemisphere]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.watercorporation.com.au/S/sources_of_perths_water.cfm?uid=7488-4865-5888-4035|title=Integrated Water Supply System|publisher=}} A [[Binningup Desalination Plant|second desalination plant]] near Binningup was completed in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.watercorporation.com.au/D/desalination_plant2.cfm|title=Southern Seawater Desalination Project|publisher=}} A trial has also been announced to [[sewage treatment|treat wastewater]] and pump it into underground aquifers to undergo natural filtration as it returns to the dwindling groundwater supply.[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/perth-tests-treated-sewage-for-drinking/2007/01/01/1167500065933.html Perth tests treated sewage for drinking] The Age, 2 January 2007 == Water storage levels == The [[Australian Bureau of Meteorology]] collates national statistics (from 2009) for water storage levels and makes them available on their [http://water.bom.gov.au/waterstorage/awris/ water storage web tool] and via a [https://itunes.apple.com/au/app/water-storage/id380627384 water storage iPhone app]. Sources: [https://www.wsaa.asn.au/frameset2.html Water Services Association of Australia], [http://www.melbournewater.com.au/ Melbourne Water][http://www.qwc.qld.gov.au] {{small|(listed as percent)}} {| class="wikitable" !Location !Dec 2005 !Sep 2006 !Oct 2006 !Nov 2006 !Dec 2006 !Jan 2007 !Feb 2007 !Mar 2007 !Apr 2007 !May 2007 !Jun 2007 !Jul 2007 !Aug 2007 !Sep 2007 !Oct 2007 !Nov 2007 !Dec 2007 !Jan 2008 !Feb 2008 !Mar 2008 |- |[[Adelaide]] |89 |57.5 |58 |57 |55.9 |56.5 |55 | | | | | | | | |- |[[Brisbane]] |35 |26.9 |25.9 |24.87 |24.3 |22.7 |21.7 | | | |15.5 | | | |20.5 |- |[[Canberra]] |67 |47.8 |45.9 |42.56 |40.4 |36.7 |34.7 |31.4 | | | | | | |41.7 |- |[[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] |56 |85 | |77 | |79 | | | | | | | | | |- |[[Hobart]] | |81 |81 | |87 |85 |79 | | | | | | | | |- |[[Melbourne]] |58.1 |46 |44.1 |46 |39.8 |38.7 |36.5 |32.1 |33.1 |35.6 |39.1 |43.6 |42.7 |42.3 |40.1 |37.1 |- |[[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] |39 |32.3 |31.8 |29.53 |28.7 |26 |23.6 | | | | | | | | | | | | |- |[[Sydney]] |40.5 |42.6 |40.6 |38.6 |37.1 |34.8 |37.1 |38.5 |38.2 |37.3 |53.1 |57.5 |58.8 |58.9 |57.3 |58.8 |60.9 |61.0 |66.4 |66.1 |} == Criticism == Water restrictions have been criticised for hampering the economy and the lifestyles of people.(28 May 2007). [http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/restrictions-off-in-five-years-says-usage-report/2007/05/27/1180205077457.html Restrictions off in five years, says usage report]. David Rood. The Age. The [[National Water Commission]] chief has argued that Australia needs a source of water that is independent of the rainfall. [[Water desalination]] is touted as the solution for potentially unlimited water use.(18 May 2007). [http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/unlimited-water-could-be-on-tap/2007/05/17/1178995330217.html 'Unlimited' water could be on tap]. Ben Doherty. The Age. Former Australian Environment Minister, [[Malcolm Turnbull]] says that it does not make sense to have permanent water restrictions just as there are no electricity restrictions.{{cite web|url=http://www.malcolmturnbull.com.au/news/article.aspx?ID=495 |accessdate=27 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060820071310/http://malcolmturnbull.com.au/news/Article.aspx?ID=495 |archivedate=20 August 2006 }} == See also == {{Portal|Australia}} *[[Climate change in Australia]] *[[Drought in Australia]] *[[Peak water]] *[[Water data transfer format]] *[[Water supply and sanitation in Australia]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{oceania topic|Water restrictions in}} [[Category:Water conservation|Australia]] [[Category:Water supply and sanitation in Australia|Restrictions]] [[Category:Water scarcity|Australia]] [[Category:Rationing by country]]

page.title: Zimbabwe Rowing team at the 2016 Summer Paralympics

revision.text:
The '''Zimbabwe Rowing team at the 2016 Summer Paralympics''' was the first rowing team to represent [[Zimbabwe at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|their country]] at a [[Paralympic Games]]. The team entered the [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|para mixed coxed four]] finishing last in their event. The team consisted of rowers Margret Bangajena, Michelle Garnett, Takudzwa Gwariro and Previous Wiri and their [[Coxswain (rowing)|cox]] Jessica Davis. Managed by Davis' mother, Rachel Davies, the team captured the imagination of the press due to the unlikely story of the crew's formation and the hardships they faced on reaching the [[2016 Summer Paralympics]] in Rio de Janeiro.
==Formation== Rachel Davies, a Canadian sports administrator from [[Cambridge, Ontario]], was assigned to [[Zimbabwe]] in 1996 by her employers, [[Fédération Internationale des Sociétés d'Aviron]] (FISA), where her role was to improve the sport of rowing in Africa. The following year she married a Zimbabwean, had a family and settled down in the country.<ref name="Waterloo Record">{{cite web|url=http://www.therecord.com/sports-story/6791179-rowing-coach-is-rio-bound-against-all-odds/|work=Waterloo Region Record|accessdate=30 October 2016|title=Rowing coach is Rio-bound, against all odds|date=1 August 2016|first=Greg|last=Mercer}}</ref> In 2012 Davis successfully coached and registered two Zimbabwean rowers for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London, [[Micheen Thornycroft]] and [[James Fraser-Mackenzie]]. When Thornycrofy decided to part company from Davis to train permanently with the South African team, it left Davis with free time to spare, which resulted in a new FISA request.<ref name="Doucet">{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridgetimes.ca/sports-story/6826844-cambridge-woman-turns-fairy-tales-and-stories-into-zimbabwe-paralympic-reality-maybe/|work=Cambridge Times|accessdate=30 October 2016|title=Cambridge woman turns 'fairy tales and stories' into Zimbabwe Paralympic reality ... maybe|date=28 August 2016|first=Bill|last=Doucet}}</ref> In an attempt to widen the appeal of rowing the [[International Paralympic Committee]] assigned four berths for African teams in the rowing program at the [[2016 Summer Paralympics]] in Rio. [[Kenya at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|Kenya]] and [[South Africa at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|South Africa]] had already taken three of the positions, and FISA now asked Davis to put forward a Zimbabwe team for the last slot.<ref name="Doucet"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/rowing-five-things-we-learned-rio-2016|title=Rowing: Five things we learned from Rio 2016|website=www.paralympic.org|access-date=30 October 2016}}</ref>
Davis had no experience in adaptive rowing, and Zimbabwe had no program either.<ref name="Waterloo Record"/> With only two months before the Paralympic qualifying camp in Italy, Davis sent out a call on social media for people with disabilities who would be interested in rowing at the Paralympics. Eighteen people responded to her call, meeting at [[St. George's College, Harare]] where Davis taught.<ref name="Waterloo Record"/> None had any rowing experience and most could not swim. The candidates had little understanding of competitive rowing, and one sixty year-old applicant arrived in her Sunday best, wearing a shower cap to protect her hair.<ref name="Waterloo Record"/><ref name="Doucet"/> Overwhelmed by the response, as Davis was expecting only a handful of responders, she decided to assemble a team rather than enter single scull events.<ref name="Doucet"/> Initially Davis was concerned about understanding how adaptive rowers were classified, but fortunately two physiotherapists turned up at the first meet hoping to help out the athletes for "Olympic trials", who were able to assess the volunteers.<ref name="Doucet"/>
The initial meet gave Davis three members of her mixed cox team, but she needed a second male member.<ref name="worldrowing 13 June">{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldrowing.com/news/how-one-african-para-rowing-team-found-their-way-the-paralympics|title=How one African para-rowing team found their way to the Paralympics|website=worldrowing.com|access-date=30 October 2016|date=13 June 2016}}</ref> Noticing that Takudzwa Gwariro, a fellow PE teacher at the school, walked with a limp, she inquired if he would like to join the team.<ref name="worldrowing 13 June"/> He accepted, giving the team just three weeks to train together before the trials in Italy.<ref name="worldrowing 13 June"/> The team's preparations for Italy were far from perfect, training on a dam which was home to crocodiles with having to use antiquated boats.<ref name="Waterloo Record"/> Further problems came after a public transit boycott meant the rowers couldn't travel to the dam.<ref name="Waterloo Record"/>
==Competition== The team that travelled to Italy consisted of Takudzwa Gwariro, Margret Bangajena, Previous Wiri, Chipo Zhento and Davis' daughter Jessica as their able-bodied cox.<ref name="newsday"/> Their chances were almost dashed at the first hurdle after Zhento suffered a seizure. The team was asked to pull-out, but a Cameroon doctor, who knew the shame that would be brought onto Zheno's family if she caused the team to fail, cleared Zhento to compete.<ref name="newsday"/> Although the team finished second to last, ahead of Japan, they qualified for Rio after being offered a bipartite invitation.<ref name="Doucet"/><ref name="worldrowing 13 June"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/rowing-bipartite-invitations-rio-2016-announced|title=Rowing bipartite invitations for Rio 2016 announced|work=paralympic.org|date=9 July 2016|accessdate=30 October 2016}}</ref> After the team returned home Zhento suffered another seizure, and Davis was forced to find a replacement.<ref name="Doucet"/> With only a week before a World Cup race in Poland, an event the team had to compete in to show international competition experience, Michelle Garnett, was drafted in.<ref name="Doucet"/>
At the Rio Games, Zimbabwe finished sixth from a field of six in the heats, with a time of 4:08.63. In the Final B, they again finished in last place, but Davis stated that she was satisfied with the teams performance considering the limited time they team had to train together.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chronicle.co.zw/team-zimbabwe-struggles-at-rio/|title=Team Zimbabwe struggles at Rio |work=chronicle.co.zw| date=12 September 2016|accessdate=30 October 2016}}</ref>
==Team== ===Margret Bangajena=== Margret Bangajena (born 14 May 1977) answered the initial call for rowers, and rows in the bow seat. Bangajena had some experience in parasport having raced in wheelchair marathon events.<ref name="newsday">{{cite web|url=https://www.newsday.co.zw/2016/09/07/zims-para-rowing-team-defies-odds/|title=Zim’s para-rowing team defies odds|work=newsday.co.zw|accessdate=30 October 2016|date=7 September 2016}}</ref>
===Michelle Garnett=== Michelle Garnett (born 15 December 1998) was the youngest member of the Zimbabwe team at the Rio Paralympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rio2016.com/en/paralympics/athlete/michelle-garnett|title=Michelle Garnett|work=rio2016.com|accessdate=30 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldrowing.com/athletes/athlete/47576/garnett-michelle|work=worldrowing.com|accessdate=30 October 2016|title=Michelle Garnet: Recent results}}</ref> At the time of the Games Garnett was a student at [[Chisipite Senior School]].<ref name="ssn">{{cite web|url=https://ssn.co.zw/2016/09/05/zimbabwes-paralympic-rowing-team-defying-odds-rio/|work=ssn.co.zw|accessdate=30 October 2016|title=Zimbabwe’s Paralympic Rowing Team Defying Odds in Rio}}</ref>
===Takudzwa Gwariro=== Takudzwa Gwariro (born 23 January 1996) was the final member recruited to join the initial team for the trials in Italy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/static/info/rio-2016/eng/zb/engzb_rowing-athlete-profile-n1386063-gwariro-takudzwa.htm|title=Gwariro Takudzwa|work=Paralympic.org|accessdate=30 October 2016}}</ref> A former [[rugby union]] player, Gwariro injured his leg in his last year of high school whilst playing the sport, resulting in nerve damage to his right foot which left him with a limp.<ref name="Gwariro Bio">{{cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/asp/lib/theasp.asp?pageid=8937&sportid=530&personid=1529814|title=Gwariro Takudzwa|work=[[International Paralympic Committee|IPC]]|accessdate=30 October 2016}}</ref> At the time of the Rio Games he was working as a Physical Education teacher in [[Harare]].<ref name="Gwariro Bio"/> At the Games he was given the honour of flag bearer at the opening ceremony.<ref name="Gwariro Bio"/> He has ambitions of studying law and attending university outside of Africa.<ref name="newsday"/>
===Previous Wiri=== Previous Wiri (born 6 June 1987) was one of the athletes who turned up at the initial meet. Rowing from the stroke seat, Wiri had a long background in parasport having played wheelchair basketball and competed in para-swimming and wheelchair marathon events.<ref name="newsday"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldrowing.com/athletes/athlete/47404/wiri-previous|work=worldrowing.com|accessdate=30 October 2016|title=Previous Wiri: Recent results}}</ref>
===Jessica Davis=== Jessica Davis (born 2 October 1998) was the team cox, and daughter of head coach Rachel Davis. Davis was the only able-bodied member of the squad and at the time of the Games she was a high school student at [[Peterhouse Girls' School]].<ref name="ssn"/>
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Zimbabwe at the Paralympics]] [[Category:2016 in Zimbabwean sport]] [[Category:Rowing teams]] [[Category:2016 Summer Paralympics]]
